PETITION.PRESENTERS: CARRICK; HARRADINE; RAY; RICHARDSON; SCOTT; SIBRAA
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels', as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 23 citizens), Harradine (from 88 citizens), Robert Ray (from 19 citizens), Richardson (from 15 citizens), Scott (from 23 citizens) and Sibraa (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Ryan (from 30 citizens) and Scott (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Our opinion on paper: That ever since the early seventies, high interest rates of staggering magnitude have made a complete mockery of justice, unparalleled in our time.

Resulting in the elimination of employment on a vast scale, in every phase of production causing house ejections, with mind effects and mental disturbances, leading to interrupted education, road toll and social disruption.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians of all parties to nationally unite for the return of Justice by using the powers vested in them to immediately and drastically reduce these destructive interest rates. Further and to this end a conscience vote is essential, if justice is to be served.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 6 of the Public Service Act Amendment Act 1982, I present the first annual report of the Department of the Senate for 1982 -83. The report which I have just had the honour to present is the first report on the operations of the Department of the Senate. The Senate has itself been a pioneer in the call for greater public accountability of public bodies, and has determined that each annual report tabled in the Parliament stands automatically referred to the relevant legislative and general purpose committee for consideration. In addition, the Senate Estimates committees routinely examine the annual reports of those bodies whose financial accounts come before them. One particular Senate committee-the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-has issued a valuable series of detailed reports supporting the call for improved reporting standards and practices by public bodies. That Committee has recommended that parliamentary consideration be given to an annual reports Act, which could be set new standards for reporting and accountability.

INTERJECT.PARA: Also relevant is the report by the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. As a direct result of that Committee's recommendations, the Parliament generally has won a greater degree of autonomy and independence from the Executive. Parliamentary appropriations are now included in a separate Parliamentary appropriations Bill. In welcoming these new measures of independence, the Senate has accepted its corresponding obligation to present an open public account of the way in which it exercises control over its own appropriations and staffing. It is, in my view, a proper responsibility of parliamentary departments to publicly account for their operations in the same manner as government departments. I commend the report on the operations of the Department of the Senate for the year ended 30 June 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I think we all welcome the information that was made available in the presentation of the appropriations and outlays in the post-Budget form of program budgeting that was provided by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) yesterday. I want to refer to one or two remarks that were made in the statement which accompanied the tabling of that Budget paper. I think that in view of the discussion that arises around Budget time we need information in a program form such as has been presented. That information will be valuable to those who wish to look at the outcome of some of the Budget proposals. The booklet will be of use in many places in evaluating the objectives and outcomes of programs as we compare them with past efforts or alternatives.

I would like to refer to an aspect of the proposals mentioned in the Minister's speech which I think is of considerable interest to the Senate. The Minister referred to the special appropriation for the Minister for Finance under Division 312 in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84. The Minister, in talking about the way in which he would look at the management of resources and the operation of the manpower required for government programs, said:
Consequently, we have introduced a new division in the Budget, Division 312, entitled 'Special Funds of Expenditure in Relation to Government Programs at the Direction of the Minister for Finance'.

What I think is of interest to the Senate is the inclusion of these funds in Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I would think that the relevant Senate Estimates committee will be interested in pursuing the provisions of these funds in Appropriation Bill (No.1). As is well known to the Senate, there are Bills which relate to ordinary annual services and there is provision for funds that relate to new policies. The Minister for Finance has described it briefly in his statement, but not at all conclusively in the information supporting the Estimates committee's consideration. I think it will be timely when the Estimates committees meet to pursue the inclusion of Division 312 in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) as relating to new policies. I do not think that this is the time or the place to have any detailed discussion on that. With the information provided to the Senate in the Appropriation Bill and the explanatory notes, it is likely that a preliminary view could be formed that the proper place for such a fund, if it should exist at all, is perhaps in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which the Senate may amend, or in an Appropriation Bill to be introduced at a later time after the purpose of the funds in Division 312 is identified and sanctioned by Parliament. I make that introductory comment with regard to this new provision of funds. I feel sure that the Senate Estimates committees, or the Senate at some other opportunity, is the place to pursue that matter.

I want to make a brief reference also to some comments that were made in the speech yesterday by the Minister for Finance and to the Press conference which followed it in which some interest was shown in the fact that the Government had decided to provide financial impact statements at the time Ministers make second reading speeches in relation to legislative proposals. I think it will be recalled by the Senate that this proposal was adopted by me when I was Minister for Finance, following the very persistent efforts of Senator Lewis. He requested that information should be given of the financial implications of legislation introduced. At that time the Government agreed to provide the sort of information that was announced yesterday by the Minister for Finance as being an innovation. It was agreed that the sort of information that would be given was some assessment of the cost at the time the Minister made the second reading speech. It was also undertaken that if facts and information were available with regard to the impact on industry and other sections of the community, that also would be made available at that time. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Finance announced yesterday that he has adopted what was a conscious policy following the very strenuous efforts of Senator Lewis in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to congratulate the Government and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) for adopting the proposal I put before the Senate in the last Parliament that at the time of second reading speeches on legislation the Government should put down a financial impact statement. Honourable senators will recall that the former Government, under the guidance of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, accepted about 70 per cent of my proposal. It agreed to provide the Parliament and the public with details of the impact so far as it related to government revenues, and it left the balance of my proposal for consideration at some future stage. It seems as though the new Government, having considered that, has taken up the balance of my proposal. The Minister in his speech, when talking about second reading speeches, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers will also attempt to assess the impact on industry and other sections of the community when formulating legislation. While such effects are often indirect and not easily quantifiable, Ministers will endeavour to include this information wherever possible.

I am sincerely grateful that the Government has adopted this proposal, which is almost exactly as I requested. At the time I introduced the proposal I recognised that it was a new concept. I recognised that it always takes some time for people to appreciate the benefits and the merits of new concepts. At the time Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle responded to my proposal I indicated that I hoped that in due course the Government would see its way clear to adopt the balance of the proposal. I recognised then that it would take some time and I am delighted to see that it has now been accepted.

I want to say now-I am foreshadowing further pressure which I shall be putting on this Government and on my own Party-that it is not only legislation that has a substantial financial impact on the community at large but also, very clearly, regulations made under that legislation. I hope that in due course all parties will agree that some attempt will have to be made to assess the cost formulated in legislation, to the community and the impact on industry and other sections of the community of regulations, and that in due course the Government-either this Government or some future Liberal-National Party Government-will see its way clear to make that information available to the Parliament and the public at large.

I draw attention to the simple example I have given repeatedly about the Metric Conversion Act. I am sure that had some people in the government of the day made some attempt to assess the economic impact on this country of metric conversion the nonsense of the Metric Conversion Act would not have been proceeded with. How much has it cost this country? Surely $2,000m would be a modest estimate of the cost of metric conversion in this country, and for what? We can now measure kilometres instead of miles or the pressure in our tyres by some impossible calculation. Quite nonsensical changes have been inflicted upon this community at enormous cost for some stupid principle, mainly because at no time during the Committee's proceedings was an attempt made to assess the financial impact on the community at large. I am sure that if governments of the future, Ministers and their officers apply their minds to the matters that the Minister has agreed to in this proposal this country will be better served by its future governments .
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON STATUTORY AUTHORITY FINANCING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present volume 1 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Statutory Authority Financing, which is a report on the financing of statutory authorities and in particular, on the economic impact of statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In tabling the report I thank the Department of Foreign Affairs and the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, with whom the arrangements were made at the time, for releasing Mr Bill Bowen to undertake the major part of the work which comprises the report being tabled by the Committee. I also thank Dr Rae Weston of the Economics Department of the La Trobe University for her assistance throughout the study. I believe that both of these people have made a major contribution to the study of the financing of statutory authorities and many of the implications for Australia of the facts and methods by which that financial operation takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bowen has carried out major work for the Senate and for the Committee over a period of years. His work as a consultant to the Senate Select Committee on Finance and Government Operations, in its very early days, formed a major part of the original thrust of that Committee's work. I believe Mr Bowen's further work, which is evidenced in this report, reflects an expertise of a high magnitude and an incisiveness and novelty which is of great significance to Australia's future. I therefore congratulate and thank Mr Bowen for the work he has done for the Committee.

The study was motivated by a feeling that the role and economic impact of Commonwealth statutory authorities, together with the ways in which they are financed, had not received the attention that their importance in the Australian economy required. Previous reports by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations had raised serious reservations about the accountability of statutory authorities to the Parliament. I need hardly emphasise the importance of proper accountability to Parliament for moneys that are authorised by Parliament, yet some of the problems faced by a parliamentary committee in obtaining vital information give rise to the most serious doubts about what accountability means in practice. It was not possible, for example, to discover how much individual authorities contribute to the overall Budget deficit, for the publication of such information might mean that authorities would refuse to supply further information without which the Budget could not be prepared. This highlights the extent to which this crucial area of government has been allowed to operate without appropriate supervision. This report is an attempt to throw some much needed light on the operations of authorities.

I should add that throughout the study the principal objective has been to obtain approximate orders of magnitude for key economic variables which, the Department of the Treasury has readily acknowledged, have not been calculated before. To this end an extensive economic survey of the nine authorities mentioned in the report was conducted. This survey obtained information which hitherto was unknown. It has resulted in some important new aggregations which have been shown on a standardised basis. As a result of this and other research, the study has produced a set of results which enable standard comparisons to be made both between authorities and within a particular authority over a period of time. It is vital to recognise that both of these comparisons are necessary when evaluating the performance of authorities. In many cases there appears to be the most disturbing result that not only is the performance unsatisfactory, but also that things are getting worse.

There have recently been a number of inquiries into the operations and finances of specific authorities and while such inquiries are to be welcomed, they have not adopted the broader perspective which this report has taken. These inquiries have in most cases downplayed the significant impact of inflation upon the way in which authorities operate and the way in which their accounts are presented to Parliament. Until the fifth report of the Victorian Public Bodies Review Committee was tabled in 1981, there was not even a theoretical structure within which to analyse the effect of inflation on public authorities.

Inflation affects authorities in a number of ways, and the present study has estimated some of these effects on the nine largest Commonwealth business undertakings. They are Australian National Shipping Commission; Australian National Airlines Commission-that is, Trans Australia Airlines; Qantas Airways Ltd; Australian National Railways Commission; Australian Postal Commission- Australia Post; Australian Telecommunications Commission- Telecom; Overseas Telecommunications Commission; the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority and the Pipeline Authority. The importance of these organisations in the Australian economy is often not understood, which in part explains why their operations have not received sufficient attention. The value-I emphasise this, Mr Deputy President-of these nine authorities' net fixed assets is almost 40 per cent of the value of net fixed assets of 685 of the largest companies in Australia covered by the constant group of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It is obvious that the rates of return earned on these assets is of the utmost significance for the Australian economy and for our future prosperity. It is equally obvious that this importance transcends political persuasions, for this startling reality of necessity will confront whichever party is in power at any particular time. This study has been conducted on a basis of rationality and accountability and without political or ideological bias.

These organisations provide a large proportion of the infrastructure and services upon which the rest of the economy depends. We will all clearly pay a significant price for mistakes in this area, with a key problem being the liability of the rest of the community for such defects. In the same way that the real rates of return earned on these authorities' assets have been ignored, the question of the maintenance of the community's capital invested in these authorities has also been sadly neglected. In periods of significant inflation, as Australia has experienced in recent years, the calculation of depreciation on an historical cost basis is likely seriously to underestimate the amount which it really costs to replace an asset whose value has declined because of wear and tear. To measure adequately the true economic performance of a public authority over time the only sensible approach is to measure depreciation on a replacement cost basis and to value assets at their current, rather than their historical cost, value. A considerable amount of work has been devoted to this issue, and while there may be arguments about some of the assumptions used, it would be hard to dispute that this method discloses a more realistic picture of the financial position and performance of authorities than the historical cost figures published by most authorities.

The implications of some of the results of this historical cost bias are most serious, not the least of which is the fact that Parliament is deprived of the opportunity to assess the performance of these organisations and yet it must still appropriate moneys. If a public sector organisation is not setting aside sufficient funds to replace that part of its capital which has been used to produce a good or service, there is a prima facie case that that organisation is consuming its capital. While generalisations conceal the considerable diversity that exists among the nine authorities, since the 1972-73 financial year it seems that none of them have set aside sufficient funds to meet the real costs of replacing their assets. In the private sector a company which failed to make appropriate allocations for its continuing viability would either go bankrupt, be taken over, or be forced to raise additional finance to cover the real cost of eventually replacing its assets. If a large statutory authtority does the same thing, the taxpayer ends up footing the bill. The recent capital injections to TAA and ANL are examples of what can happen when the capital structure and/or real rates of return on assets are allowed to deteriorate over a long period. Similarly the present debate between OTC and the Department of Finance regarding the amount of profits to be retained for future investment points to the importance of replacement cost depreciation.

Statutory authorities have tended to rely more heavily on borrowings than private companies and this has confronted them with some very difficult problems . For the nine authorities included in the report capital liabilities are equal to 76 per cent of net fixed assets, while for the 685 largest private companies the figure is 53 per cent. Inflation is therefore likely to have a more significant impact on these authorities' capital structures than is the case for private companies. An important effect of inflation in Australia over the 1970s was the phenomenon of negative real interest rates, whereby borrowers received a substantial subsidy from lenders. The calculations shown in the report indicate that the purchasing power gain on net nominal liabilities as a result of negative real interest rates has been extensive, although with the return to positive real interest rates this effect will disappear. This will have a traumatic effect on a number of authorities and it is vital that this is fully understood in formulating policies to allow them to cope with these difficulties .

All the evidence, however, is that despite the relatively high levels of inflation in Australia in recent years', the distinction between real and nominal rates of return appears to have escaped both those responsible for the conduct of authorities finances, and most of the authorities themselves. A rate of return which may appear reasonable in nominal terms may very well correspond with a low or negative real rate of return, and the disappearance of the subsidy via negative real interest rates will make this worse. If we want simply to throw away all concepts of economic efficiency and pursue the path of subsidising the consumers of these services and let our national capital stock be run down, then the practices of some of our authorities could not be bettered . However, if Australia is to pay more than mere lip service to the objectives of economic rationality, there needs to be a radical change of attitudes by economic managers, the authorities and, in particular, the public who must be persuaded that any consequent higher charges by authorities to achieve reasonable rates of return on the nation's assets are in the longer term to everyone's benefit.

When depreciation is calculated on a replacement cost basis asset values are measured at current prices, which virtually all economists, including the Treasury, argue to be the only correct method. When the appropriate adjustments are made for the effect of inflation on debt the results for some authorities are alarming. Some of the key results are: ANR, ANL, Qantas, TAA and Australia Post have had negative real rates of return at some stage, and the trends in those rates are in most cases unfavourable; and OTC, Telecom and the Pipeline Authority have earned high rates of return on equity. Also, in a number of cases there has been a significant rate of increase in the equity holdings of the Australian people. However, this has not always been matched by a corresponding increase in the real rate of return earned on that equity.

The diversity in the rates of return raises serious questions about the allocation of the community's resources to these authorities. In addition to the problems caused by having such a high proportion of the nation's resources earning low or negative real economic rates of return, there are obvious equity problems in having such diversity in real rates of return. Consumers of services provided by authorities earning low or negative rates of return receive an indirect subsidy. The interests of economic efficiency dictate that such subsidies be made more explicit. If governments want to run these authorities as quasi welfare systems to redistribute the community's resources to particular groups, the interests of parliamentary accountability require that such subsidies be at least capable of identification and assessment by the Parliament . The dangers of perpetuating the present system of cross subsidies and implicit subsidies to particular consumers as a result of low or negative real economic rates of return should not be underestimated. The costs and benefits of such regulation must be obvious. The study recommends that in the interests of economic efficiency there should be a requirement that authorities set prices to earn a specified real economic rate of return on assets that the community has bestowed upon them. If specific groups are to be subsidised this should be done directly or identifiably through the Budget rather than by the 'sleight of hand' that governments seem to have traditionally preferred. The real costs and consequences of such procedures, although they may not be immediately obvious and are spread throughout the community, are, in the long term, severe.

As well as analysing the real economic rates of return the report considers the effects on the capital market of both the activities of authorities and their regulation. It is clear that some authorities have a particularly important effect on the capital markets. An example of the influence that can be exerted is the recently announced decision to issue index linked bonds for the State Electricity Commission of Victoria. Whatever the merits of such bonds, this will clearly have a significant impact on the capital market. I do not want to go over the many significant findings in relation to the capital market, except to point out that the shortening maturity structure of authorities' debts confronts both economic managers and the authorities themselves with some extremely complex issues. It is therefore important that proper consideration be given to measures which may alleviate these problems. Leasing and overseas borrowings offer the opportunities to overcome some of these problems, and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations commissioned two studies by Dr C. R. Weston on these issues. Those studies, together with other research, make it clear that the full range of considerations have not been adequately taken into account when formulating policies in this area. The studies by Dr Weston, commissioned by the Committee, are published as part of the report.

Finally, one of the most important findings relates to the leasing practices indulged in by at least one authority, ANL. Leasing offers the opportunity for a lessee to obtain lower lease costs as a result of certain tax advantages obtainable by a lessor. However, to receive these tax advantages there can be no understandings between the lessor and the lessee regarding ownership rights at the end of the lease. The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that if any such understanding exists that arrangement would be judged to be a hire purchase agreement and the tax advantages upon which these schemes depend would not be obtained. From information given by people in the leasing industry it appears that most lease agreements involve the provision that in such an event the lessee would have to meet the resulting tax obligations. The likelihood of this eventuating cannot be assessed at present as the ships which have been the subject of such arrangements have not yet reached the stage where ownership rights have been tested. However, the possible problems for the government of the day are clearly enormous. This example highlights the theme of this report. We ignore accountability and the full disclosure of relevant information at our national peril.

The report now tabled is volume 1. Volume 2 will comprise a further study, which has been held up, through no fault of the Committee, because of certain problems with an econometric computer model and will be published as soon as it is available. That volume will also contain the Hansard report of evidence given to the Committee in relation to the operation of the Australian Loan Council, the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and their impact in relation to capital markets and statutory authority borrowings, and certain other evidence which the Committee regarded as being of long term significance and important to be published in an available form such as a report. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make that statement in relation to the report tabled and the very important matters dealt with in the study which it contains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

That motion is moved in the hopeful anticipation that the computer problems will be overcome. But we are at the mercy of machinery and the model. As soon as this problem is overcome the report will be finalised and tabled in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- As honourable senators will be aware, the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service was established in January 1982 with the opening of a centre in Adelaide. From then on, centres were opened progressively in State capitals and Darwin. The financial year 1982-83 saw the first full year of operation of the Service, which has continued to develop to meet the needs of Vietnam veterans. Expenditure by the Department of Veterans' Affairs on the Service in 1982-83 was $660,500.

SPEECH.PARA: Functions of the Centres

The centres were established to assist Vietnam veterans and their families in an atmosphere not affected by a formal Government Department environment. Counselling centres, except in Hobart, operate from premises separate from the Department of Veterans' Affairs which are accessible to veterans and their families. The Hobart centre which is presently located at the Repatriation General Hospital is to be moved to separate premises in November this year. The centres were established to deal with a range of problems including marital and family relationships as well as vocational, financial and legal problems, with the assistance where necessary of other specialised community agencies. As many clients have presented with behavioural or psychological problems, the type of counselling required has predominantly been therapeutic rather than of an advice -problem solving nature. There have been relatively few referrals to community agencies. A close relationship is built up between counsellor and client in these circumstances and referral of clients to other agencies would be undesirable. The counsellors in the VVCS require a wide range of skills.
Demand

Mr Deputy President, the demand for counselling is continuing to grow. The Service has handled 1,721 individual veterans, 1,338 of them in the 1982-83 financial year. As wives and families are involved, the number of people assisted directly or indirectly by the Service is much higher. In 1982-83 there was a total of 14,914 client contacts, which included extensive interviews involving not only veterans but also their spouses and other members of the family. Some clients are reluctant to come to the centres and contact often is by telephone. Veterans coming to the centre have many problems. The most common group of problems is what might be termed behavioural problems embracing such things as violence, withdrawal, irritability, anxiety, insomnia and depression.
Staffing

I am advised on the operation of the Counselling Service by a national advisory committee which is chaired by the ex-service representative on the Repatriation Commission and includes representatives of the Returned Services League and the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia. On the recommendation of that committee, staff was increased in the Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth centres to provide additional counselling capacity to undertake country visits. Some difficulties have been experienced in filling vacancies in the Brisbane and Perth centres. Part time staff were also added to the Brisbane and Hobart centres to assist with the work there. The part time position in Hobart will become full time when the centre moves to its new location later this year. To improve the service to country areas, regional centres are being established in Canberra and Townsville. Staff have been selected for both centres and services should be available in November.

An evaluation of the operations of the counselling centres is being undertaken. Professor Ian Waterhouse of Macquarie University, the chairman of the review committee, has put to me three interim recommendations, pending the final report . These are: Firstly, the Counselling Service should be continued for at least three years. Secondly, consideration should be given to the reclassification of the counsellor positions to recognise fully the responsibilities involved and to assist in the retention and attraction of qualified and experienced staff. Thirdly, staffing of the Service should be slightly expanded to enable the current and potential workloads to be met with an acceptable professional level of counselling standards.

I have accepted Professor Waterhouse's advice and announce to the Senate that the Counselling Service will be continued till at least 31 December 1986. The Public Service Board is being asked to examine the classifications and establishments required for the centres. The Service has been performing a valuable task under difficult conditions and, in doing so, has the support of Vietnam veterans and the organisations which represent them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) concerning the first full financial year of the operation of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. It is pleasing indeed to see that that Service, which was started by the previous Government in early 1982, is fulfilling the purpose for which it was established. It is an extremely important purpose. As the Minister indicated, in its experience to date, the Service has directly involved itself with some 1,700-odd Vietnam veterans. Altogether, its contacts in the period of its operation have covered clients to the extent of nearly 15,000. Clearly, it is performing a very useful and proper task. It is also pleasing to note that the Counselling Service has extended itself geographically so that it exists not only in Adelaide, where it began, but in every capital city. I note that from now on country areas are to be brought into the range of this Service, because travel poses a severe problem for Vietnam veterans who live in country areas. The foreshadowed opening of centres in the cities of Canberra and Townsville-we hope this will occur promptly-is needed and appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that the basic reason for the establishment of a counselling service such as this is to be found in the somewhat peculiar and tragic circumstances of the Vietnam War itself. Significant mental as well as physical strain was placed on those who participated in that war. It must be remembered that the Vietnam veterans displayed all the courage, discipline and fighting characteristics of Australian forces throughout the decades. But they were placed in the extraordinary and difficult circumstances of being involved in a conflict for which total and absolute support was not always seen in their homeland. Also they fought in a difficult and unusual terrain and in an area in which it was, amongst other things, extraordinarily difficult to identify friend from foe. All of those problems must have added to the extreme mental pressure on Vietnam veterans, the effect of which is still being observed.

I am happy to see that the Government, in this statement, has accepted the three interim recommendations of Professor Waterhouse; that is, the scheme is to be expanded and is to continue for not less than a further three years; it is recognised that there is a particular quality necessary in counsellors; and there will be an opportunity to upgrade and slightly increase the numbers involved in this area. I welcome the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the fact that the Government is continuing the previous Liberal Government's counselling service to Vietnam veterans as set out in the statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). I wish to address myself to page 3 of the statement concerning the reference to the extension of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service into Canberra and Townsville. It has been a matter of some disappointment to Vietnam veterans in this area that the Service has not been available in the Canberra district. They have been expecting it for some time and felt that, under the previous announcement, it would have been available in Canberra long before this. This involves not only the veterans of Canberra but also the large population of Vietnam veterans in surrounding areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not use the opportunity to tell the Senate about the difficulties and cost of transport between Canberra and Sydney these days, but it is a difficult problem. It is appropriate that this Service should be available in Canberra. I think it should have been provided sooner than this. I note the Minister said that staff have been selected and the Service should be available in November. I hope that, if possible, it will be available earlier than that. I ask the Minister to keep the matter closely under his eye to see that the Service is available in this area at least by November, so that Vietnam veterans in Canberra and the vast surrounding districts can have the benefit of the Service which so clearly is being successfully provided in the other State capitals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I congratulate the Government on its prompt response to the interim recommendations of Professor Waterhouse and its adoption of them. The first recommendation, in particular, has always been of concern to the counsellors of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. The continuation of that Service has always been under a fairly tight time limitation. I have spoken to the counsellors on many occasions and the item which has always come to the fore is the necessity for continuation of the Service for some definite period. The three-year extension, I believe, would be the most welcome recommendation contained in the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt).

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw attention to two points. The first concerns the need during those three years for the Counselling Service to maintain an identity separate from the Repatriation Commission or the Department of Veterans' Affairs . It is extremely important for the veterans approaching the Counselling Service that its character not be that of a government department. The location now in Hobart, away from the repatriation hospital, will complete that severance from government. Veterans can feel that they are approaching a completely independent group; one which is not tied in any formal way to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The second point I draw attention to is similar to that which was alluded to by Senator Reid regarding counselling services away from the capital cities. She drew attention to the cost of travel between Canberra and Sydney. I could raise the cost of travel between Townsville and Brisbane, it being the same as that between Brisbane and Melbourne. The difficulty is compounded inasmuch as Queensland, for some reason which cannot really be determined, although there could be some guesses, has a much larger percentage per head of population of veterans seeking counselling than have other States. It may be that people move to Queensland because it is a nice place or for some other reason. Certainly, the demand on the Counselling Service in Brisbane has been enormous by comparison with other States. The difficulty has always been that the counsellors have not been able to move out of Brisbane as they operate on an extremely limited country travel budget.

I notice from the Minister's statement that this is to be rectified by enabling additional people to have greater flexibility of movement. I am sure that people , particularly those who live outside capital cities, will welcome that addition . I point to the fact that in my State Rockhampton is still disadvantaged. There is a fairly large number of veterans there. There is a very active group of the Vietnam Veterans Association there and the problems it has to deal with have convinced me that we need some type of part time assistance to support it in the immediate future, though I imagine that this may not be of long duration. In making these comments, I do not want to detract from the support that I wish to express to the Minister for his prompt and very reasonable acceptance of Professor Waterhouse's interim recommendations. I hope that the Government will continue to give the support it has shown in the statement to the Counselling Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Senator Reid, as did all the other representatives of Canberra, wrote to me in the last week about the problems of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service in Canberra. The difficulty that the Government faces is that there is an acute shortage of accommodation in Canberra. I have indicated to my Department that I know that to be the case because I have discussed the matter with the Department of Administrative Services and also with the Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, who has some responsibilities with respect to Canberra. I am hopeful that we will very shortly be able to open a service for Vietnam veterans in anticipation of the November date that was expressed in the statement. Unfortunately, we have accommodation problems for public administration in Canberra, but every step is being taken by me to see that those matters will be expedited.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to Queensland, we have the premises but they have to be redesigned and reconstructed to meet requirements. As all honourable senators have said in their response to the statement, we try to create conditions-I support what the previous Government did-which are non-departmental. This factor is considered in the design of the premises. It is part of the process of creating conditions in which the veterans feel free and happy to relate their problems to the counsellors. Unfortunately, that takes time, but I can assure honourable senators that the Government is aware of its responsibilities in this matter and will waste no time in getting construction completed and accommodation organised .

Consideration resumed from 7 September 1983.
Clause 25 (Powers of court in custodial proceedings).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support amendments Nos (25) and (26) proposed by Senator Walters as they were recommended by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. As it is hedged around it will not enable the courts to introduce fault. I think it would be a great mistake to have a great deal of consideration of litigation that dealt with the activities of the parties. Their conduct as parents is, I think, the point that is stressed. From this point of view it would widen what the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has done in his amendments. I think it would be well worth while to have these amendments in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)
Amendments negatived.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the clause stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Temporary Chairman, I think there is some confusion as to what we are dealing with. I understood that we were dealing with Senator Walters's amendments. Senator Walters does not happen to be here at present.
—That is her problem.

—I, too, was expecting that the debate on other matters would proceed for a little longer than it did. I wish to raise a matter in regard to clause 25 (d) which, in part, seeks to add proposed new sub-section (1B) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A court shall not make an order . . . unless-

(c) the court is satisfied that, having regard to the counselling and welfare facilities of the court, it is not practicable to require the parties to the proceedings to attend a conference as mentioned in paragraph (a).

Many matters relating to custody, access, the welfare of children and family relationships are already the subject of much counselling work in community family agencies. There has been a good deal of comment by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) that the counselling and welfare facilities of the Family Court are overloaded at present. The fact is that this argument has been used by the Attorney-General for his opposition to some of the measures that have been put forward and which otherwise he has agreed to in principle. I am now trying to suggest to the Minister that it might well be important to recognise that the welfare of children and family relationships are already the subject of much counselling work done by community family agencies. Again, the danger for parties can be that in trying to assess their own marital and family relationships they are confined within the legal framework which allows them little space for review and change. If we are going to maintain that the Court has this waiver power having regard to the counselling and welfare facilities of the Court, it would not be practicable to require the parties to the proceeding to attend the conference mentioned in paragraph (a) of proposed new sub-section (1B). All sorts of other counselling agencies are available that may well have been involved in discussions relating to family relationships and the welfare of children. In my view, one way of broadening the options that the parties have is to make an addition to proposed sub-section (1B). Proposed new sub-section (1B) (a) states:
the parties to the proceedings have attended a conference in relation to the matter to which the proceedings relate with a court counsellor or welfare officer;
I would like the Attorney-General to think about adding the following words to paragraph (a):
or a counsellor from an approved family counselling and welfare organisation.

I would like the Minister to direct his attention to the problem that seems to arise in proposed new sub-section (1B) (c). I remind the Committee that proposed new sub-section (1B) (c) is a new paragraph which the legislation before us seeks to include in the original Act. Does the Attorney-General consider that the idea of having other agencies-other words could be used-involved would be a suitable arrangement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly happy to take on board the matters that Senator Harradine has raised. I am not sure that it would be appropriate to try to tighten up the language of the section in this respect, although as a practical policy and administration matter there may be some room for further guidance to be given to the courts in the exercise of these powers. The main reason, as I understand it, why proposed new sub-section (1B) (c) is in the Bill, giving an out, as it were, in circumstances where it is said to be not practicable for counselling to take place, is to cover the situation primarily of country towns and regional centres where the magistrates exercise this jurisdiction and where there simply may not be the counselling facilities available, not only in the context of the official court counselling services but also, indeed, the voluntary marriage guidance organisations which play such a valuable supplementary role in the major cities. It is to cover those kinds of contingencies where the magistrate feels able to make the order on the basis of the evidence available to him, but it simply is not practicable to require the full panoply of counselling to precede that decision. That is why the paragraph is in the legislation. I would hope that that would only apply in the marginal case. It may be that we can make some administrative arrangements to ensure that that is so to the extent that it is not at the moment. I would certainly take the point that the honourable senator makes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Walters spoke to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) about the same subject I want to raise. When this clause was under consideration prior to the adjournment debate last night the Committee had before it amendments moved by Senator Walters. Although I did not indicate my support for the actual terms of the amendments, I did suggest to the Attorney-General that, having embarked upon the listing of criteria for the Court to take into account in custody matters, I thought there was in fact some substance, in aspects of Senator Walters's amendment and that the criteria in the Bill should be redrafted to take account of some of the considerations that were contained in those amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I instanced the criteria about education and upbringing. I think also that the reference in the first proposed new sub-paragraph to the conduct of the parents as parents, is not perhaps fully comprehended by one of the criteria in the Bill to which the Attorney-General referred. That may be the subject of some further debate. I am concerned about what has happened to the suggestion that the matter might be looked at again and a substitute amendment to this clause might be promoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry I was not in the chamber. I obviously missed the defeat of my amendments by, I suppose, one minute. I was outside talking to Senator Elstob regarding a committee matter. I had not, in the chamber last night, completed my argument, which I hoped would have convinced the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). When I spoke to him outside the chamber he told me-I do not want this to be confused-very clearly that he was sympathetic to the situation. He felt that while there may be a reintroduction of fault in bringing in the conduct of the parents, he was sympathetic to that when custody cases were being dealt with. I went on to explain the reasons for some of the guidelines that I had put down. He very kindly cut me short and said that there was no need for me to explain because he felt that he could accommodate my view; that all that would be needed would be the tidying up of the wording. As he may recall, I said that I was willing to forgo that aspect of my amendment No. (26) which dealt with the effect of the separation on two children because I believed his amendment covered that, although I felt my amendment was slightly better. The Attorney certainly did lead me to believe last night that he would agree to my amendment No. (25) which deals with the relevant conduct of parents as parents, the relevant conduct of step-parents-I even went into detail as to why I believe step-parents or people associated with custody should be included-and the wishes of the child's parent or parents. Unfortunately, I missed the debate on my amendments by just one minute.
—I do not think that we finished that. Senator Harradine then got the floor.
—I was informed that--
—Order! I said 'The noes have it'. There was one voice. Those amendments have been dealt with.
—Two honourable senators said yes, and one honourable senator said no.
—No.
—Senator Harradine then rose.

—Seeing that there is confusion, perhaps we could have a re-vote on the amendments. If the Attorney-General, under the circumstances, would allow the debate to continue I would be most appreciative. I would also be most appreciative for his answer about the matter which I put to him in discussions outside the chamber. As far as I am concerned, it needs to be clarified. He did not say that he was going to seek further advice. He definitely said that the whole thing needed tidying up. I believe that since then the Attorney-General has sought further advice and that he is not as keen to tidy it up as he was last night. I would be most grateful if the Attorney would allow the debate to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to clarify what we are debating. As I understand it, Mr Temporary Chairman, you declared Senator Walters's amendments defeated, which means that we are just debating clause 25--
—No.
—Yes.

—That is correct, as I understand it. The Temporary Chairman has declared the amendments defeated. We are simply debating now clause 25 at large. If there is to be any further debate on the particular content of Senator Walters's proposition it would need to be rather swiftly turned into the form of an amendment with which we can in fact come to grips. I do not resist that course being followed should Senator Walters or Senator Durack wish to draft another amendment, perhaps less unintelligible in parts than the amendments moved last night. I am sure we would have a foundation on which we could debate this matter. Perhaps we could focus debate simply by such an amendment being drafted around the two particular matters about which I talked to Senator Walters last night-that is, the insertion of a particular criterion cast in terms of the Court having regard to the conduct of parents as parents. Perhaps we could further clarify and sharpen the debate by having another criterion, by which the Court should have regard to considerations relating to the education and upbringing of children. I think an amendment cast in those terms would concentrate our minds on the questions now at issue. I do not resist that course now being followed.

SPEECH.PARA: What I do have to say, however, is that following discussions in this chamber and outside it last night I did take further advice this morning from the Chairman of the Family Law Council of Australia, His Honour Mr Justice Fogarty. I did receive advice from the Principal Registrar of the Family Court of Australia. I have had further advice tendered by another senior academic in the family law area who heard the debate last night and rang to express his point of view on it. I did have sympathy for the general tenor of what Senator Walters was proposing and I still do in the sense that I believe that it is legitimate and proper for the Court to take into account considerations relating to parents ' performance as parents if the Court is effectively to be able to determine what is in the best interests of the child and to have regard, as a paramount matter, to the welfare of the child.

The difficulty, however, which has been put to me very strongly by the people to whom I have just referred, is that there are real problems associated with the reintroduction of conduct language into the text of the Bill. I should like to summarise the points that were put to me, and which I have found persuasive, in the following terms. It has been put to me that over the years the Family Court has endeavoured to educate practitioners in particular not to fill the pleadings in family law matters with personal evidence against the other party to those proceedings. That has, on all the available experience-I think this probably will be appreciated by Senator Durack-a very destructive effect on the parties themselves and has a negative effect on attempts at conciliation.

The view that has been put to me by His Honour Mr Justice Fogarty in particular is that this approach is at last beginning to be appreciated by practitioners in the family jurisdiction and that there is a real risk that the re-insertion of any express references to conduct in the text of the legislation would simply open the way for renewed muck raking by the parties to dissolution procedures, particularly perhaps by less scrupulous practitioners and particularly by those individuals who tend to act for themselves. It has been put to me that the subtlety of the language proposed, which is not conduct at large but rather conduct as parents, would not be likely to be appreciated by many practitioners, by litigants in person or indeed by most magistrates in this jurisdiction, if not perhaps by the judges themselves. There is a real concern to focus attention on parenting capacity as being the crucial consideration in determining these custody and welfare of the child issues. It was put to me that the language of the criteria we are proposing now to insert and in particular sub-paragraph (iv) , which deals with the capacity of each parent to care adequately for the child, is sufficient to draw specific attention to this particular matter.

Last night, after discussing these matters with various senators, including Senator Walters, I had thought it might be quite appropriate to build education and upbringing into the explicit language of these criteria, as indeed was proposed by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. It has been put to me that even that may create difficulties to the extent that it would represent an encouragement to judges and magistrates determining these matters to apply their own subjective views about education, about the respective merits and advantages of private or religious schools versus public or state schools, and so on. Whilst no doubt they will be applying these values and considerations in any event to some extent in weighing and balancing these matters, they should not be specifically encouraged to do so by statutory language on the basis that the language in sub-paragraph (v) is broad enough to encompass a reference to those sorts of considerations.

It is a matter for nice judgment as to just how far one goes in these measures. I do not think I am at odds with Senator Durack, Senator Walters or Senator Harradine in wanting the Family Court to have regard in appropriate cases to a demonstrable lack of parenting capacity on the part of one or other of the contestant for the custody of a child. Of course it is appropriate that the Court should have regard to that and to all the considerations which go into an evaluation of it; but, as I have said, the extent to which one really encourages the parties to this litigation to use that circumstance and provides statutory encouragement to have regard to those considerations is a delicate question. It is a nice question as to how far one really encourages parties, as a result of that occurring, to get back into, through the back door, as it were, all the mud slinging, and diatribe and personal accusations that have been such an unhappy feature of family law litigation in the past and which we have been trying to avoid.

The main point on which I finish, is that with which I started. Any encouragement to that state of affairs in the pleadings or in the matters actually dealt with overtly by the Court will not encourage the speedier and more satisfactory resolution of marital grievances. It will be a barrier to reconciliation, not an encouragement to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the Committee of the situation we are in at the moment. The question that Senator Walters's amendments Nos (25) and (26) be agreed to was put by me. I then declared that the noes had it. I said 'The noes have it' for the second time and that ruling was not challenged. So the situation at the moment is that we are dealing with clause 25 in its entirety. Senator Harradine is supporting what I have just said. I call Senator Durack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about the situation that has arisen. I accept the explanation of it, but I do not think it should have occurred. We left this debate at 11 o'clock last night on the understanding that we would have the response from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) which we have just had. That response should have been given before the amendments were put to the vote in the way the Temporary Chairman has just indicated. The Temporary Chairman himself probably was not here last night, and I do not want to blame anybody. All I am saying is that the situation was that we all expected to have the explanation the Attorney has just given when we left consideration of the matter last night.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to what the Attorney has said, I believe that the only proper course to take is to postpone further consideration of this clause in order to consider whether or not some other amendments could be made which may accommodate the concerns that the Attorney and Senator Walters and Senator Missen obviously have . There is obviously a clear conflict between the approach of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and that of a number of very expert advisers. I am not surprised at the advice the Attorney has received. It is advice which I received from similar quarters, and it convinced me that it would be undesirable to make any amendments to this clause. The Senate will recall that the Bill I introduced did not make any amendments to it. The fact is that once we embark upon amendments, this statement of criteria, then we have to try to arrive at a decent and satisfactory result.

Obviously there is concern about the criteria in the Bill, and obviously Senator Evans himself shares some of that concern. I do not think it is satisfactory to rely on sub-paragraph (v) to the extent that Senator Evans does. Once we start to specify criteria, we weaken the effect of a general provision such as sub-paragraph (v). I am concerned that it might be used to indicate that Parliament's views were very firmly directed to the first four criteria, that these are the matters which should be concentrated on in the Family Court, and so on.

I suggest that we postpone this clause and have the opportunity to see whether some private discussions might lead to a redrafting of the clause. The Attorney might be prepared to go further and give us the services of his very expert drafter of these clauses. I am sure she would have, with her capacity and knowledge, a real contribution to make. I do not want to have to embark upon drafting something which I do not really believe is a good idea anyway, but I think it would be very helpful if, in the spirit of non-party debate which I hope we are getting back to, some effort can be made to see whether an agreeable compromise can be reached, as we still have plenty of matters to discuss on this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not dissent from the course proposed by Senator Durack. It might be possible to find a form of words, for example in sub-paragraph (iv), which while not expressly referring to conduct might make it clear that the kind of parenting capacity we are talking about extends to more than simply a capacity physically to care and protect, which might be the concern that Senator Walters had. It may be that in the context of sub-paragraph (v) there could be some reference to education and upbringing as one amongst a number of criteria. There might be a solution to this if we can approach it in a calm and sensible atmosphere. In those circumstances I would be happy to postpone consideration of this clause until a later hour.

SPEECH.PARA: I add that I hope it might be possible to complete the Family Law Amendment Bill before the end of today. Not many of the remaining matters are the subject of acute controversy involving large numbers of senators, and I hope that we can proceed rather briskly in putting our views on the remaining matters and then come back to this clause no later than this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: — I want to make it clear that I cannot accept the situation whereby we in the legislature appear to be directed by judges, who are actually in an administrative capacity. Frankly, I feel a little disturbed that since the time the amendments were put forward here discussions have been held between judges and the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) but not with those who put forward the propositions. I am quite concerned about the whole issue not only of what the judges are doing but also of what the counselling services are doing in the Family Court situation. I do not want to get started on that because I am amassing a good deal of evidence about it and it may well be that at some stage something more substantial might need to be said about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That consideration of clause 25 be postponed.
If the Attorney-General will be kind enough to make available some expert assistance we will see whether something can be done during the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will, provided that spirit of co-operation is reciprocated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last line of clause 26 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in which the welfare of a child of a marriage is relevant,'.

. . . in which the welfare of a child of a marriage who has not attained the age of 18 years is relevant,'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

Proposed new clause 29A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next amendment standing in my name has two different and separate matters in it. The first amendment deals with the right of the spouse to maintenance. It is a rewriting of section 72 of the Family Law Act. The second part of the amendment deals with variations in maintenance. They are different subjects. I seek leave to have them dealt with separately.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31) Page 24, after clause 29, insert the following new clause:
''29A. Section 72 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:
Right of spouse to maintenance

'72. A party to a marriage is liable to maintain the other party, to the extent that the first-mentioned party is reasonably able to do so, if, and only if, that other party is unable to support herself or himself adequately whether-
(a) by reason of having the care and control of a child of the marriage who has not attained the age of 18 years;
(b) by reason of age or physical or mental incapacity for appropriate gainful employment; or
(c) for any other adequate reason,
having regard to any relevant matter referred to in sub-section 75 (2).'.

The purpose of this proposed new clause is to rewrite section 72. It states on what grounds people are entitled to be maintained. Over the years there has been some confusion as to precisely what is intended by the section. Perhaps the simple way for me to explain this amendment would be for me to read from paragraph 5.8 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. This amendment is in the terms of recommendation 22 of the Committee. Paragraph 5.8 states:

In relation to s.72, decisions of the court have indicated the possibility of three different interpretations of the phase 'having regard to any relevant matter referred to in section 75(2)'. On the first interpretation, attention would only be directed to the matter enumerated in s.75(2) if the need for maintenance could not be established by reference to the provision of s. 72 itself. It would only be relevant to determine whether there was any other ' adequate reason'. On the second interpretation, s.75(2) would be considered in the interpretation of the phrase 'that the other party to the marriage is unable to support himself or herself adequately'. 'Any other adequate reason' would be given equal weight in determining this matter with the two matters of responsibility for a child and fitness for employment to which s.72 makes specific mention. The third interpretation which is presumably the intended interpretation reads 's.72 as being governed in all respects by s.75(2) so that the listed factors would be taken into consideration by the court in relation to all aspects of the provision'.

The Committee believed, as did the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1974, that the third interpretation was the one intended. At paragraph 5.20 of the report the Committee dealt with the vexed question of the extent to which social service payments and entiltements should be taken into account. This is a matter, of course, which runs into controversy in other amendments to be moved later on.
Paragraph 5.20 states:

5.20 Another line of cases, however, proceed according to the first construction of s.72 referred to in para 5.8. In this view social services entitlements are irrelevant in considering whether the applicant could be said to be unable to support herself.14 Whilst this approach is consistent with the logical reading of the Family Law Act as it is drafted, it is clearly contrary to the intention of the legislature as relevant in the extract from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs quoted in para 5.15. If the recommendation as to the re-drafting of section 72 were to be inserted in the Act this would have the effect of directing an interpretation of section 72 in line with the Senate Standing Committee's original understanding of how it would operate. This would defeat the purpose of the compulsory maintenance provisions of the Social Services Act.

That has been changed, of course, since then. The point is that some confusion and differences of views have been expressed over the years as to what the meaning of section 72 is. The Committee felt that the proposed new clause would have the effect of bringing all these matters into consideration in determining the parties entitled to maintenance. I suggest that the section should be clarified in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has some reservations as to whether it is really necessary to have proposed new clause 29A drafted in the terms that Senator Missen suggests. But on balance we take the view that his amendment should not be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment repeals section 72 of the principal Act. As I see it, nothing in the amendments of the Attorney-General amends in any way section 72. Is that right?
—The only amendment before the Committee at the moment is proposed new clause 29A.
—The only amendment before the Committee is to take out section 72.
—No, to rewrite it as proposed by Senator Missen. It loses nothing of itself. It is just clarification.

—I feel that Senator Missen's amendment does not remove the problems currently in section 72. I have no doubt that I will be corrected if I am wrong, but it appears to me that the amendment removes from the husband his previous legal duty to maintain his wife. It imposes upon a wife a positive, primary, legal duty to maintain herself. It also imposes upon a wife a positive, legal duty to maintain her husband in certain circumstances. It imposes on a husband a legal duty to maintain his wife only in certain circumstances. The amendment disimplies that there is a change in what was previously the concept of the requirement of maintenance, particularly in relation to the wife. The Act imposes a positive duty on the wife to maintain herself during marriage and upon the breakdown of the marriage.
—Not really.
—Well, I would like that explained because nothing I read in section 72 entitles her in principle to maintenance from her husband.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that it really undermines the woman's role as a wife and mother.
