For example, if she has been deserted and the husband has made an application for the dissolution of the marriage, I am concerned to ensure that what was always regarded as his legal obligation to pay maintenance is maintained. I know that the Attorney-General is also concerned about that. He made a statement earlier in the year about that very matter. I wonder whether he could explain further what action is proposed in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to do so. I will not explain what further action is proposed but simply endeavour to explain what the original concept of section 72 is all about. It will be appreciated that its maintenance guarantee provision, which applies irrespective of whether the marriage is continuing or whether it is breaking down, is a general application. It is not squarely related to a dissolution or desertion context. The point of the section is not to undermine the traditional role of the woman as wife and mother but, to some extent, to undermine the traditional picture of the woman perhaps as a chattel or as a pet of the husband in respect of which the obligations flow one way only, from the husband to look after this poor creature who, as a statutory or legal assumption, is incapable of looking after herself except with the husband's support.

SPEECH.PARA: The section has introduced in essence non-sexist criteria for the application of maintenance, which some people no doubt find distressing but which means that in practice, and in the way the section is drafted, each party to the marriage is obliged to look after the other party of the marriage to the extent that, firstly, there is a need on the part of the party being looked after and, secondly, to the extent of the resources available to the party who is doing the looking after. That is the way the section is constructed. It does not focus specifically on obligations, certainly of the husband to look after the wife. Nor does it in any way undermine that obligation of the husband to look after the wife. It creates an additional obligation on the wife to look after the husband in the admittedly unlikely event that it is the husband who is the person with more need and the wife the person with more resources. But in the usual situation, which will be the usual situation-that is, it is the wife who has the need and the husband who has the resources-this section does absolutely nothing, as I read it, and as anybody has read it since it was enacted, to undermine that traditional obligation. I hope that is sufficient to explain to Senator Harradine what it is about. Certainly, as I understand Senator Missen's amendment, it preserves that quality in the original section and just clarifies its application in a number of circumstances where it may be thought to need clarification.
Amendment agreed to.
Proposed new clause 29B.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31A) Page 24, after new clause 29A, insert the following new clause:
''29B. After section 74 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Variations in maintenance payable in respect of children

'74A. (1) The regulations may provide for the annual variation of orders for the payment of maintenance in respect of children by reference to variations in the cost of providing for a child ascertained from estimates of the cost of providing for a child published by the Australian Statistician.

'(2) Where regulations have been made under sub-section (1), an order that is made under this Act for the payment of maintenance in respect of a child has effect, subject to any order of the court that made the first-mentioned order or of any other court, as from each anniversary of the making of the order as if the order had been varied in accordance with the regulations.'.''.

Clause 29B is also a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. It has come in for some criticism and I understand it will be opposed by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I should explain that the Joint Committee felt it was desirable to insert this clause into section 74 of the Act .

TALK.START.PARA: —An idea whose time has not yet come.

—Perhaps the time has not yet come and perhaps inflation is too great. That may be the reason why it is necessary now. Instead of people having to make application, the regulations would provide for an annual variation of orders for payments of maintenance in respect of children. This would save parties having to go back for what are sometimes relatively small changes and incurring the cost of litigation involved. I should in fairness say that there has been some criticism of my amendment. I will probably incur Senator Harradine 's wrath but judges, who shall remain nameless, have taken an interest in these amendments and have spoken to me and written to me, in one case referring to my second proposal for an automatic adjustment of child maintenance orders.

SPEECH.PARA: One judge stated:
This is fine in theory and has always had a lot of support but there are enormous practical difficulties about it.
Another judge has written to me saying:
I do not object to the amendment of section 72.
That is the one we have just passed-
The proposed section 74A (1) seems to me to raise a host of practical difficulties and open up further room for arguments.
He spoke about fractions of cents and so forth, and asked:
'How would you calculate the entitlement, by reference to the original order or the rounded off order?'

There are no doubt some difficulties in that regard, although I do not think that is of major importance. When the Family Law Council considered this recommendation of our Joint Committee in the Council's sixth annual report in 1980-81 it stated in paragraph 1.86:

Council also discussed a recommendation that there be an automatic adjustment, on a periodic basis, of all maintenance orders and registered maintenance agreements in accordance with the Consumer Price Index (Joint Select Committee recommendation 28). Although Council could see that the proposal had a number of advantages, it ultimately recommended that it was opposed to all automatic adjustment to maintenance orders because of the practical difficulties of implementation. The Council notes that the Chief Judge was also opposed to both of these recommendations. As an alternative to the second recommendation, she suggested that judges should be encouraged to build in a discretionary standard form adjustment as part of the order, although such standard clauses should not be for more than three years.

I think it is fair to say that these are the difficulties encountered. I have moved this amendment because it was one of the recommendations of the Joint Committee. It might be difficult to see it being carried at this stage but I think I should put on record both the recommendation which has been made and the statements that have been made about it. I support it but will not go to the barricades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is beginning to sound a little like a cracked record, but I do have sympathy for the aspirations underlying Senator Missen's amendment. I simply am obliged to take the view on advice-I regret Senator Harradine-that it is not practicable; that it simply will not work. The Family Law Council, to whose report on this Senator Missen has referred, has considered this proposal very closely on not just one occasion after the submission of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act but subsequently as well. On both occasions it came down with the conclusion that to try to build in a mandatory statutory adjustment of this kind simply will not work. The way ahead here does seem to lie in the direction of discretionary orders being made by judges of the kind Senator Missen adverted to , and which the Chief Judge has espoused; namely, discretionary standard forms of adjustment as part of the basic maintenance order for a maximum period of, say, three years. The problem is that circumstances vary so much from case to case. It is thought by all the practitioners at the coal face in this area that, as desirable as it might be to avoid this repeated return to the courts to get adjustments to maintenance orders, it simply will not work to have the kind of statutory provision that Senator Missen proposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 30 (Matters to be taken into consideration with respect to maintenance).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (32) Page 24, paragraph (a), proposed new paragraph 75 (2) (f), lines 15 to 23, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following new paragraph:

''(f) the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance or benefit under any superannuation fund or scheme, whether the fund or scheme was established, or operates, within or outside Australia, and the rate of any such pension, allowance or benefit being paid to either party;''.

I foreshadowed this amendment in my speech in the second reading debate. Because I share the view of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that this debate ought to proceed with a little more expedition I do not propose to go over the reasons again. I believe they are summarised in a joint statement issued by Senator Chaney and myself, on 21 January this year, when we were Ministers in the previous Government. In fact, for the sake of the record I might seek leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard. Perhaps Senator Gareth Evans or one of his advisers is familiar with it.

This whole matter of the extent to which the parties or a party to a marriage are able to slough off on to the taxpayer their financial responsibilities which arise from the breakdown of a marriage and subsequent divorce has been the subject of long standing concern. There has been a great increase in total payments for the supporting parent's benefit in particular, and to some extent the widow's pension. These are subjects on which Senator Chaney is much more competent to speak than I am. I am pleased to see that he has now come into the chamber and no doubt will say a few words on the subject. I do not want to go into all the details of it. I am relying primarily on the view that was expressed in the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act on this subject. I adopt its words:

The Committee concludes that the law should re-inforce the policy that, wherever possible, families should be supported by private rather than public means. In furtherance of this policy, relatives should not be in a position to transfer their obligations to support relatives to the community at large where they are, financially, in a position to contribute to the support of those relatives. At the same time those without adequate means of support should be entitled to sustenance from the State to the extent of their need.

That is a principle with which I thoroughly and entirely agree. It is a view which I held when the Family Law Act was brought into operation. I cannot recall , but I do not think any amendment to this provision was moved in the Committee stage of the earlier debate on that legislation. Maybe, against my better judgment, I was talked out of it by somebody, but it certainly has been a long standing concern. I think the concerns that I have had have been reinforced by the practice that has developed. There is ample evidence that people do reach agreements because they are aware of the provision in section 75 of the Act which directs that the Court shall take into consideration eligibility for a Commonwealth or State pension. Without putting too fine a point on it, this is leading to abuse. Major practical problems are involved in determining how adequately to tackle this abuse. It may well be that my amendment alone will not be sufficient, but I put it forward to see whether something can be done.

Perhaps this amendment is not adequate in itself, but I believe it would be adequate provided the Social Security Act were administered in the way in which the previous Government decided to administer it. Under that Act before people could get social security benefits they were required to pursue their rights to maintenance. If the maintenance is being determined without regard to those social security benefits, the right to and the extent of the benefits which they can receive will be determined after the ability to pay of the other spouse has been determined, not the other way around, which I think leads to abuse.

On 11 April this year I was very pleased to read in the Australian some views of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) which, as reported, seem to me to be almost the same as the views of Senator Chaney and me. I draw the attention of the Attorney-General to that article. No doubt he has read it. As a corollary to what is mentioned in the article, adequate collection agencies should be established. That is another matter altogether. I recognise that it is a question of government resources and so on, but I think the time has come when some step has to be taken and something has to be done. I have moved the amendment with that object in mind. Mr Chairman, may I have leave to incorporate in Hansard the statement of Senator Chaney and me?

TALK.START.PARA: —By all means.
—And the newspaper report of the comments of the Attorney-General ?
—I am not so sure about that one.
—Can the Attorney-General not be persuaded?
—Leave is granted to the first request and not the second. Is that correct, Senator Evans?
—Yes.
—I will read the second one.
—Oh, incorporate it then.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Both documents will be incorporated rather than being read.

INTERJECT.PARA: The documents read as follows-
Amendment to provide more realistic maintenance contributions

The Government will prepare an amendment to the Family Law Act so that courts will no longer be obliged to take into account the payment of means tested Commonwealth pensions and benefits when fixing maintenance payments.

The Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack, Q.C., and the Minister for Social Security Senator Fred Chaney said the amendment would be considered with the other proposed amendments to the Act in the next session of Parliament.

The Ministers said the amendment reflected the Government's view that the primary responsibility for the provision of maintenance for children and spouses should be on the separating parties and not on the community at large.

The Government's view was that a person capable of supporting his children and former spouse should not be relieved of any responsibility to do so merely because the dependent spouse was eligible for social security benefits.
Senator Durack and Senator Chaney said the Government was aware that many single parents or separated parents depended entirely on support from the Government by way of social security benefits.

The Government would take no action which would place the stability of those payments at risk. The purpose was to allow a more realistic contribution by the parties to the maintenance figure fixed by the courts. This means that the separating parties who could afford to do so would shoulder a burden previously borne by the taxpayer.

Senator Durack and Senator Chaney said that the Government had taken into account observations made by the Joint Select Committee of the Parliament which inquired into the operation of the Family Law Act.
In dealing with the operation of the present law in relation to maintenance the Joint Select Committee said:

''The Committee concludes that the law should re-inforce the policy that, wherever possible, families should be supported by private rather than public means. In furtherance of this policy, relatives should not be in a position to transfer their obligations to support relatives to the community at large where they are, financially, in a position to contribute to the support of those relatives. At the same time those without adequate means of support should be entitled to sustenance from the State to the extent of their need. This entitlement should not be dependent on the pursuit of often futile remedies for maintenance. However, the State through the Department of Social Security should be empowered to pursue and recover from liable relatives such contributions towards support as is reasonable in the circumstances.''

The Ministers said the Government had also agreed in principle to implement more efficient maintenance enforcement procedures. The Government had asked for a further and more detailed study to be carried out on the options available for better collection and enforcement of maintenance procedures before it finally decided on how the changes would be implemented.
Canberra, 21 January 1983.
Canberra to hit maintenance dodgers
The Federal Government may establish a national maintenance collection agency to force divorced husbands to pay maintenance to their wives and families.
The move would reduce the soaring welfare bill and allow the Government to provide greater benefit to widows and orphans.
The Federal Attorney-General, Senator Evans, told The Australian the Government was ''very alarmed'' at the high level of unenforced maintenance payments.
He also foreshadowed moves to change legislation-probably the Family Law Act-to rationalise ''the relationship between social service payments and maintenance'' .
The Government hopes to introduce these measures by the end of the year.
It is disturbed at the $837 million it expects to have to make in supporting mothers' benefits in the next Budget.
Senator Evans said the social security system was already ''vastly overstretched''.
Forward budget estimates predict the supporting mothers' benefits bill could cost the Government $117 million more next year.
In 1984-85 it will cost $937 million and in 1985-86, $1050 million.
If the Government can slash this bill by forcing spouses to pay maintenance, it could save hundreds of millions of dollars.
The Government was unable to give a figure for the amount which could be saved by the measures Senator Evans foreshadowed, but sources said it could be '' substantial''.
Any changes to the Family Law Act would probably include removal of a section which directs courts to take welfare payments into account when setting maintenance payment levels.
Senator Evans said his department was working closely with the Social Welfare Department in examining how to set up a national maintenance collection agency.
He said he had also set up an internal inquiry within the Attorney-General's Department to ''develop the proposal in some detail''.
''I'm expecting a report from this inquiry in two or three months,'' he said.
''There is no doubt we can reduce the welfare budget if we have a more efficient maintenance collection system operating.''

Senator Evans said there were far too many ''spouses and kids who are suffering as a result of the inability of the present system-largely administered through clerks of courts of petty sessions-to really deliver the goods.''
He said the Federal Government wanted to establish a maintenance collection agency similar to bodies in South Australia and Western Australia.

''There, you have a government agency doing the job of collecting maintenance payments for you, collecting the dough from the offending spouse's paypacket and getting it into the hands of the people who deserve and need it,'' he said.
''You have to ensure people don't renege on their responsibilities.''
'Senator Evans said he envisaged the national maintenance collection agency as ''a source of advice and negotiating help'' for aggrieved spouses and families in need of maintenance.
The agency would co-ordinate court action ''where appropriate'' on behalf of offended spouses.

''It's a matter of professionalising the maintenance system rather than leaving it to the ad hoc method of individuals going along to get what help they can from friendly or otherwise local clerks of courts,'' he said.
Any criteria the Government established for maintenance payments would not be ' 'a crude and simple set of tests.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is always open to conviction by threats, if not by the use of logic and reason. The amendment moved by Senator Durack, which I earlier publicly indicated I would support, is an amendment which, as the shadow Attorney-General said, is but one of the steps which can be taken to change a situation which is causing some concern in the Australian community. I think one can look at that concern from several different points of view: From the point of view of how individuals are organising their lives and from the point of view of how individuals are affecting each other in particular in regard to the growing shift from private provision of support to relying upon taxpayers for support.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the features of the changes which are occurring in Australia at the moment, which seems to disturb many of the people I meet all around Australia, is the growing number of people in the category of single parents who are dependent upon the state, upon taxpayers, through the payment by the Department of Social Security. As I say, that concern is based both on the situation of single parents and the difficulties they face and on the very large increase in cost which has occurred over the last 10 years. The main reason for this increase is not, as some people seem to think when they are making representations on this matter, that there has been a great increase in promiscuity in the community, a great increase in the number of people who carelessly or, some would even say intentionally, become pregnant. The major contributor to the very substantial rise in the number of people receiving the supporting parent's benefit is, of course, the breakdown of marriage. It is into that area that a larger and larger number of people fall each year, to be provided for from the public purse. That situation is one which I do not believe would be reversed by this amendment or, indeed, by any measures which are going to be taken. What can be done however is to do something to reduce the automatic way in which people can transfer private responsibilities on to the taxpayer. I think that this amendment is one of the steps, as the shadow Attorney-General said, which can most usefully be taken.

The present situation is that the Government does not require that a spouse who is left with children to support should seek to take maintenance proceedings against the other spouse. Although there is a provision in the social security legislation to that effect, it was not administered for a long time. Indeed, it was not applied after the passage of the original Family Law Act, I understand at the direction of the Government. It was revised by the previous Government during my administration of the Department of Social Security. I understand that the requirement that reasonable steps be taken to seek maintenance has been discontinued again. The previous Government regarded this requirement as a sensible thing. It was not an absolute requirement that people take maintenance proceedings, but a requirement that reasonable steps be taken, and reasonable time was allowed to enable that to take place.

However, the area with which we are immediately concerned is that when someone does seek maintenance and is relying on the provisions of the Family Law Act the amount of maintenance which is to be paid is to be determined bearing in mind the availability of assistance from the taxpayers, from the state, through the Department of Social Security. That means, of course, a discounting of the demands which will be made upon the other spouse. It involves a conscious act of policy that the assistance shall be available from the taxpayer in any event and that shall be taken into account before determining the level of contribution, if any, which will be required from the spouse. I do not think that it is old- fashioned or tory or conservative or in any sense a negative thing to suggest that responsibilities in this area should primarily be met by the individuals concerned. I say that being aware that in most cases of marital breakdown, or in many cases, there would simply not be the means available to ensure that an adequate income can be provided from the income which is available to those individuals. I accept the inevitability, the necessity and the propriety of the state being involved in providing assistance by way of income maintenance in circumstances in which there is simply not sufficient money involved. But I think the primary obligation ought to lie upon the parties. What that means in practice is that I think the obligation which is placed upon the Court ought to be to look at what the parties have in a material sense and it ought to make its determination on the basis of what is available to those individuals and the state should come in only after that calculation has been made to provide additional assistance where that is necessary. I accept that that will occur in a great number of cases. What I am saying is that at the moment the discounting is to the disadvantage of the taxpayer whereas I think the position ought to be reversed. I think that the individuals concerned should have to call upon their own resources before the taxpayer is called in aid. Again, I say that I do not believe that this is a conservative or reactionary view. It has aways struck me how easily people overlook the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child, which declaration points out the primary responsibility for the maintenance or care of children lies with the parents and that the child has a right to receive that sort of assistance. I believe that the same sort of principle applies here, that the primary obligation lies on the parties and I believe that the present state of the law ensures that there is too much diversion of that obligation or responsibility upon the taxpayer.

The only other point I wish to make at this stage is to say that I note that there has been defeated in the Committee debate a proposal that there should be a two-year provision for divorce, that the evidentiary requirement for irretrievable breakdown should remain at one year and not be changed to two years. I should like to say that, in common with this provision, I believe that it is important that this Act should act as something of a signpost to the fact that the people of Australia, the Government of Australia, do regard marriage seriously. They regard entry into marriage as a serious matter, as an assumption of responsibilities and they regard the whole question of marriage as being something which in not simply to be regarded lightly, or to be regarded as the acceptance of responsibilities which can be so easily or too easily shucked off and put on to the shoulders of somebody else. I believe that the provision that we are seeking to amend is one of those negative signposts in the Family Law Act . I believe that it is an indication to the people of Australia that we easily see that in the event of someone walking out on a spouse there is an immediate direct responsibility on the taxpayer to look after the residue of that marriage . I believe for that reason that it would be a very desirable thing if the section were amended to restore the concept that the Court looks first to the parties rather than looking to the Department of Social Security in meeting these obligations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first clarify something about the article which appeared in the Australian of 11 April and which has been put on the record by Senator Durack and Senator Chaney. While it is a perfectly accurate account of my views to the extent that it emphasises my desire to rationalise the relationship between maintenance payments and the social security system, it is certainly not accurate to the extent that it conveys the flavour that it was me saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Any changes to the Family Law Act would probably include removal of a section which directs courts to take welfare payments into account when setting maintenance payment levels . . .
This is the paragraph of the report from which Senator Chaney and Senator Durack have derived obviously most nourishment in moving their particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We thought we had converted you, that was all.

—That paragraph is not set in quotes. God knows from where it derives but it does not derive from anything that I said. I was talking only in terms of the proposed national maintenance collection inquiry and acknowledging in that context that there was a job of rationalisation to be done . Let me say that I do appreciate that there are many attractions from the point of view of both general principle and our hard pressed social security Budget for the kind of proposal that Senator Durack and Senator Chaney are suggesting, namely, that primary reliance be placed on the spouse to provide maintenance and that social security payments should only come in as a backstop to that rather than as a front line weapon in securing the necessary standard of living for the party in need. But the problem is how far one should go at the moment, while recognising the long term need to change the situation around. It is the Government's view, and one reached in consultation, I hasten to add, with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), that this amendment should not be accepted, certainly at this time, although there is a case for looking at it again when we have the national maintenance enforcement system in place, as I hope will be the case some time relatively early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by Senator Durack to section 75 (2) (f) of the Family Law Act merely has the effect of not requiring the court to take into account pensions or benefits received by a person under any law of the Commonwealth, or a State or Territory. The amendment, as I said in my brief comment on this in my reply to the debate on the second reading, would not prevent a court from taking account of a Commonwealth payment or pension under section 75 (2) (o) of the Act which still provides that the court may take into account:
. . . any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account.

So there would still remain a discretion vested in the Court to take these payments into consideration. Under the old Matrimonial Causes Act, which had no provisions of an explicit kind such as the present section 75 (2) (f) there was, I am told, very considerable uncertainty as to whether pension entitlement should be taken into account or not when assessing maintenance orders, and section 75 (2) (f) was essentially put in there to resolve that particular uncertainty. One of the difficulties that we see flowing from the adoption of Senator Durack's proposal is that it would return the courts to exactly that condition of uncertainty as to whether they should take that into account as they would be able to do under section 75 (2) (o) which was the problem under the previous legislation. I do take the view that persons who are capable of maintaining their spouses and children and who are in need of financial support should not be relieved of this responsibility because the dependent spouse is eligible for social security benefits. I readily accept Senator Chaney's proposition that such a view is not confined to tories and right wing ideologues and other unsavoury souls that might exist around the place. I accept all that. But I also agree, as again I said in my reply to the debate on the second reading, with the view expressed by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act that those without adequate means of support should obviously be assisted by the state and I would not take Senator Chaney to be dissenting from that. Section 75 (2) (f) does in some measure ensure that a supporting parent would have sufficient moneys by way of social security benefits if the absent spouse is not in a position to pay adequate maintenance. The provision, as it is drafted now and with the minor amendments that we are proposing, would seek also to leave the absent spouse with sufficient income to live on so that he or she would be inclined to pay maintenance that may be ordered and maintain himself and possibly a second family. That is the way it is constructed. The people against whom Senator Durack's amendment really seems to be directed do appear to be, from the way in which it would work in practice, amongst the most vulnerable .

The real difficulty arises where payments are made on an intermittent basis; where there is a payment perhaps one week or one fortnight and then a default, then another payment a week or two later followed by another default. In such a situation, which is a commonly recurring one, the problem arises of supporting parents being constantly forced to go back to the Department of Social Security for reassessment and re-establishment of their benefits, with obvious resulting hardship to the supporting parent and children in the interim period. It could be expected that there would be a substantial increase in variation applications , resulting in higher orders being sought. There would be an incentive for respondents to approach the Court and legal aid offices as soon as they could indicate any change in their circumstances.

Moreover, we have difficulty with this proposal in that it is to a considerable extent merely speculative. It has not been demonstrated in anything that has been said-one would imagine that at least Senator Chaney, given his previous position, would have some resources available to him to make this point-that significant savings to the Government would result or, from the other point of view, that benefits such as the preservation of stable marriages would ensue. On the evidence available at the moment there is a minimal obvious benefit but a very evident disbenefit in terms of financial difficulties and additional emotional stress. The prospect of having before the courts more recurring conflicts over these matters is not a particularly happy one.

Finally-this really is a summary of what I want to say-to drive people to rely more on maintenance payments when it is generally acknowledged that there is just no effective maintenance enforcement and collection system presently operating in Australia would, from our point of view, be premature and, in many respects, cruel. I have set up an inquiry into the establishment of a national maintenance enforcement and collection system. That inquiry is very visibly working away at the moment and I hope that it will be able to produce some fruits in the early part of next year. Until then I believe that it is quite premature to reconstruct the section to produce the kinds of results that are being sought by Senators Chaney and Durack, although this is obviously a matter to which further attention will have to be paid closely at a later time when hopefully that enforcement system will be in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is weighty evidence to support the proposal advanced by Senator Durack and Senator Chaney. The weighty evidence is in the cost to the taxpayer of the current provisions of the Family Law Act. I leave aside for the moment the detailed costs and problems that are experienced between the parties involved. Let us examine the cost of the whole family law administration system. These are not total costs. They are confined simply to the operation of family law administration which, in 1981-82, cost $21,977,700. Legal aid in family law matters cost $22,295,319, for a total cost of over $45m to the taxpayer. Those figures represent only one aspect of family law.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the cost of the provision in the legislation which at the moment requires the Court to take into account certain matters, including the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance or benefit, et cetera. I will give the figures from the Department of Social Security on what has happened since 1975. The majority of women receiving a widow's pension are not widows in the normal sense of the term. The amount spent on widows pensions in 1981-I do not have the 1982 figure-was $668.3m. To most people widows are women whose husbands have died. In fact, that is not so. Women whose husbands have died and who are receiving a widow's pension are in the minority. There were 73, 140 such widows. The number of divorcees and deserted wives who obtained widows pensions in 1981 totalled more than 100,000. That represents since 1975 an increase of 162 per cent in divorcees receiving a widow's pension and of 32 per cent in deserted wives receiving a widow's pension. That is not the end of the story.

Let us look at the supporting parent benefit. By far the largest number of persons receiving the supporting parent benefit are separated wives and de facto wives. In 1981 separated wives totalled 53,152 and de facto wives 12,913. The increases in their numbers since 1975 have been 267 per cent and 208 per cent respectively. The figures for males who received the supporting parent benefit are smaller. The number of widowers amounted to only 816. There were 906 male divorcees and 2,184 separated husbands. In stark statistical terms, that shows the enormously burdensome cost of divorce in Australia and, indeed, of the legislation, which requires the Court to take into account the eligibility of either party for a pension, et cetera. Surely that is a matter of great concern to all of us.

I am heartened by the fact that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated that there is to be an investigation-I presume a good deal of priority has been given to it-of the question of maintenance. But I believe that Senator Durack's amendment would enable the Court to review what it is doing in this regard. It is all very well for the judges or the registrars or anybody else to tell us what to do. Let us tell them what to do. We are responsible for paying them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayers, not us.

—That is right. We are responsible for passing the legislation . We are responsible for passing budgetary legislation relating to supporting parents benefits and widows pensions. It is a matter of real concern among the community that there is such a burden in money terms. I am happy that the Attorney-General is amending section 75 to take into account the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance or benefit. I am pleased that the Attorney -General has sought to amend section 75 so that the Court can take into account the following matters:

SPEECH.PARA: The eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance or benefit under-
any law of the Commonwealth, of a State or Territory or of another country; or
any superannuation fund or scheme, whether the fund or scheme was established, or operates, within or outside Australia,
and the rate of any such pension, allowance or benefit being paid to either party;

I think that is important, particularly for those for whom I have been most concerned during the consideration of this matter, that is, the deserted wives, those who are deserted and whose husbands then make application for divorce. However, I see that this provision is re-included by Senator Durack's amendment, and I believe that that amendment deserves support. The Attorney-General said that, even if Senator Durack's amendment is adopted, the Court can take into account any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the Court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account. That is dealt with in sub-section (2)(O). What is wrong with adopting Senator Durack's proposal if the Court has an overall responsibility to take into account any fact or circumstance in accordance with section 75 (2)(O)?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would create confusion and uncertainty in the people you represent, like the old Act.

—No, not at all. The Court, fairly and squarely, then would have to justify what is being done at present; that is, a fix-up, very often, between the parties, having regard to what the taxpayer can pay for the actions of these parties. It comes down to this: People have to face up to the consequences of their actions. The consequences of their actions should not be visited upon the community as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The longer this debate goes on the more confused I get. I am not quite sure what is to be achieved by the Durack-Chaney amendment. The main emphasis in the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act was that there ought to be reliance upon private responsibilities by liable parties to a maintenance order. The Committee sought to develop a scheme, which has not yet been adopted-in fact we have not seen an alternative to it-whereby the Social Services Act would be amended and there would be a method whereby the Department of Social Security could go ahead and enforce the payment of maintenance. Therefore maintenance orders would be effective instead of being, as is the case at the moment, a terrible joke. Many women who have obtained orders have to go back to the Department because the husband does not pay. The husband may pay the maintenance for a while so the wife loses the pension, and the matter goes backwards and forwards.

SPEECH.PARA: What is not at all clear to me is what is to be achieved if the amendment is adopted. I think it is acknowledged that this is only part of the problem. On one reading one could say that it excluded Commonwealth pensions, although the amendment of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) makes it very clear that it does not. A very similar amendment was recommended by the Joint Committee which is recorded at page 79 of its report. Recommendation No. 25 states:

The Committee recommends that section 75 (2) (f) be amended to read: The eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance or benefit under any superannuation fund or scheme, or the rate of any such pension, allowance or benefit being paid to either party.
That is very much the same as the Durack-Chaney amendment except that their amendment relates to operations within or outside Australia. In the note to the recommendation the Committee states:
It should be noted that section 75 (2) (f) would then apply to situations where a pension is actually being received whether from social security, superannuation or other sources.

I do not read the three things together. Eligibility for a pension is one thing, an allowance is another, and a benefit under any superannuation fund or scheme is a separate entitlement. If I have not misunderstood the Attorney-General, he said that this would be dealt with anyway under the catch-all clause at the end which allows for any other fact or circumstance to be taken into account. Those phrases have posed difficulties over the years because judges have tended to say : 'No, it does not include such and such'. Quite apart from needing to rely on that, I cannot see why the Court would not take into account social security pension entitlements, as it has in the past. Therefore, I am at a loss to see what the amendment that has been proposed by Senator Durack and Senator Chaney would do.

Clearly, the situation is unsatisfactory in many respects. People are not meeting their own responsibilities, and a scheme must be found whereby they do so, as far as possible. On the other hand, as has been pointed out to me very often by judges and others who are practising and operating in the social welfare field, undoubtedly people seeking maintenance very often cannot support themselves. There is a lack of money; very often they are in the poverty section of the community. Often women are placed in a situation in which there is not enough money to go around. Perhaps the husband is supporting a new family as well as his old family. Therefore, over the years judges have compromised to an extent by making orders for lower rates of maintenance which are more likely to be paid than if a large amount were awarded to a husband who then disappeared to Western Australia, northern Queensland, or those remote parts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Northern Victoria.

—It is not far enough, Senator. Wherever the husband may disappear to, the Commonwealth is left carrying the lot. There is no black and white situation here. I am not so sure that the judges have not, over the years, in a practical sense, operated fairly effectively in making moderate orders that might be met and taking into account that there will be a Commonwealth contribution. It is a contribution because the children of the marriage have to be educated and looked after. If they are not the Commonwealth will have a very large social responsibility later, probably for a whole generation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all right to talk about the cost of social security. In order of social security costs we are somewhere in the medium area-under half-in the developed world. The other night I read some figures which indicated that, far from being highly paid in terms of social security, Australia is rather on the low side compared with the rest of the world. This will increase because of the aging of our population, the number of children, and the steady rise in the Western world of broken homes and marital breakdown. These factors will cause an increase in costs in Australia, but I believe that is a cost the community ought to bear. I do not think the amendment does more than fiddle around with the problem. I do not think it answers it. I may have misunderstood the meaning of it but, if so, it looks as if the Joint Committee also misunderstood the meaning because it took a different view. I am not sure it is worth while putting in the amendment proposed by Senators Durack and Chaney because I do not think it will achieve the purpose they are seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Two separate groups of people-they are usually wives, as we have all readily acknowledged-are involved in this matter. There is that group of women whose husbands disappear at the drop of a hat as soon as it is suggested that they might make some payment. Social security benefits should be paid to those women, as they are at the moment, until maintenance can be collected. But there is another group of women who object very strongly to the fact that, although they know their husbands have the finance to pay for the education and support of their children and the maintenance of the family as a whole, those husbands are able, because the judges take eligibility for the deserted wives pension into account, to slip their responsibilities altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: Those wives object very strongly to the fact that they are forced to accept a pension under these circumstances. Many of them complain to me about this matter . They say that they are well aware of their husbands' financial situations. In many cases the husband is quite capable of paying for the upkeep of the children yet, because the court takes into consideration eligibility of the wife for the pension, she is forced to accept it. I do not believe that there is any difficulty such as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated-he is quite willing to review the matter eventually-that in the interim period confusion would be created. Some husbands duck their responsibilities deliberately by going off somewhere so that they are not able to be contacted. The maintenance of their wives becomes the responsibility of the Department of Social Security. I hope that the Attorney will look at those two different sections of people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I re-enter the debate to comment on a couple of matters which have been raised. Senator Missen asked what my amendment achieves. It appears to me that at a minimum the amendment achieves the removal from the Family Law Act of the clear statement that as the law now stands the first recourse in the circumstances of a broken marriage is to the taxpayer. Everyone agrees-there has been no difference in the debate between the view put by Senator Gareth Evans and the views I have expressed-about the obligations of the state to maintain people who are without income. That is not the argument. The question is where one primarily looks. To my mind the Act as it stands at present is clear in that it lays down a primary or an existing universal entitlement to look to the Department of Social Security first. I think that is undesirable in principle.
—It is only one amongst a number of criteria.

—It is one. But I think the entitlement to assistance from the state ought to remain independent. It should not be taken into account before the ability of the parties themselves to contribute is determined. I quite understand the points made by the Attorney-General in his comments about leaving the absent spouse enough to live on and so on, but I think that many people are concerned about the sorts of figures Senator Harradine mentioned in the Committee debate. Perhaps we also need to show some concern about the pressures put on people of limited means who are required to pay the taxes to contribute to these pensions. I think a balance should be struck. At the moment the balance is too heavily against the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give some additional figures taken from the pocket compendium of income security statistics issued by the Department of Social Security. There has been a very large growth in this area of dependency between 1972 and 1982. In June 1972 a total of 92,784 people were receiving the widow's pension, which was the form of pension then available. Of course, it also picked up many deserted and divorced wives. In the 10-year period to 1982, the number of people receiving the widow's pension and supporting parent's benefit increased from 92,784 to 338 ,000. The supporting parent's benefit was a new benefit introduced in 1975, I think. It was extended by the Fraser Government to include supporting fathers as well as supporting mothers. In June 1982 the number of people receiving that benefit was about 124,000. Nine months later that number has increased to 135, 000. There is a continuing increase in the number of people seeking the assistance of the taxpayer through these benefits. Again I say that there is no dispute that benefits should be available where there is no other available income. Of course they should. But the question is whether the availability of those benefits should be taken into account in determining the contribution which is to be made by the party to the dissolved marriage.

If we look at the actual amounts involved we see an even more stark change. I do not have constant value dollars; these figures are in dollar terms. In 1971- 72 the Commonwealth paid out $104m in widows pensions. By 1981-82, it was paying out $1,323m. Therefore, by the financial year 1981-82, $1.3 billion was being expended in widows pensions and supporting parents benefit. This is an area of massive increase. It is an increase of over $1,200m in a 10-year period. That simply accentuates the reason why I think we should be cautious about the extent to which we allow what in the past have been private obligations to be transferred to the public sector, in particular, to the Department of Social Security. However, I agree with the Attorney-General that there are problems. There are the problems of intermittent payments. That certainly highlights the need for work to be done such as the Attorney has under way with respect to a maintenance collection agency. Again, there is no difference between the Opposition and the Government or, I am sure, any honourable senators in this place as to the desirability of that sort of reform.

I also commend the matter which was under examination during the life of the previous Government and which I have little doubt that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, will also be monitoring. I refer to the New Zealand experiment where a contribution is required on a statutory basis. Clearly, that sort of rationalisation may be the answer to some of the difficulties which the Attorney has mentioned in his response. I am unable to put before the chamber the level of savings which could be effected out of that $1,300m. Clearly, it would not be the major part that would be saved. It would be a shaving operation , not a massive saving operation. But the Government has shown itself in a sense rather resolute about some of these shaving operations and keeps telling us that we have to bite the bullet on these difficult matters. Again, in this area there are difficulties in the way of making changes but I think those difficulties need to be faced. For the reasons that the Attorney himself has outlined, I believe that the effect would not be catastrophic even in individual cases, because of the wide discretions which are allowed the courts in these matters. I am sure that the courts would administer the slightly more limited discretions which they have in a way which would ensure that in individual cases no harm was done. It would require a higher level of contribution in some cases from the parties to dissolved marriages, principally husbands. I think that would be a thoroughly healthy thing in Australia in 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment. It is a matter about which I have corresponded with various Attorneys -General since 1976, with the exception of the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I think that this section should be removed from the Act. The basis upon which maintenance is frequently worked out takes first into account the full benefit a woman can get by way of a pension for herself and her children. The agreement is then fiddled so that the amount paid by way of maintenance fits in with the full pension requirements. I think this is an abuse of the system. It probably has been going on to quite a large extent. It was something that had to follow, given the wording in the legislation that the amount available under social security should be taken into account. The maintenance agreements that were drawn up and registered took that into account. However, frequently payments additional to that were made to ensure that the full pension was paid. I think that this is a substantial area of abuse and we are not seeing, as the Government frequently tells us is the case, the social security dollar going to those most in need.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly other matters such as the collection of maintenance and the enforcement of maintenance orders need to be attended to. I think it is common knowledge that under the Act anyone who did not want to pay maintenance did not really have to and there was no way of seeing that maintenance was paid. My personal view is that parents should be primarily responsible for the support of their children. Of course assistance should be given through the social security system if the parents, between them, do not have adequate resources to look after their children. However, I think we have the matter completely the wrong way around when we say that the first thing that we should consider in assessing maintenance is the amount to be taken into account under social security. The proposal to make more specific the requirement that entitlements under superannuation funds should be taken into account when assessing maintenance is long overdue. To some extent this can be done and it has been done. But I think this requirement needs to be made clearer so that the partner who received less during the marriage because of money being paid into a superannuation fund can adequately share that entitlement if the marriage breaks down. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government reiterates its position of opposition to this amendment, notwithstanding all the arguments that have been put. Firstly, it will not guarantee the result which Senator Durack and Senator Chaney want it to guarantee or ensure. Secondly, to the extent that it will do anything, it will simply create confusion in practice and not alter substantially what in fact occurs, only the circumstances in which it occurs. Thirdly, to the extent that there is some principled or rational foundation for the trust lying behind the arguments of Senator Durack and Senator Chaney, that is being taken into account by the Government in the context of its review of maintenance collection and enforcement. It is very likely that we will bring down appropriate statutory solutions to this whole problem in the latter part of next year when that exercise is completed. So, at worst it is a little wrong headed at this stage; at best it is a premature amendment and I would urge that it be rejected accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Durack's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 September 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity on the first reading of the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 to talk about foreign ownership and foreign investment throughout Australia, particularly in Queensland. I think that most people in Australia would be somewhat shocked at the figures that are available from the Foreign Investment Review Board in relation to the number of rural properties held in Australia by foreign companies. A cursory look at the figures shows that foreign ownership has controlled 498 rural properties since April 1976. It does appear that a gross amount of money has been involved and that a large number of rural properties are being bought, particularly in Queensland and a number of other States.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine the areas of the 498 rural properties that are held in Australia . If one were to compare that area with the area of some other countries one would find that the area of the 498 rural properties is larger than the area of Greece. In Australia 13.6 million hectares are controlled by foreign ownership, which is four times the size of Holland. With that sort of investment coming into the country I think it is fairly reasonable to expect that State governments which make recommendations to the Federal Government in relation to allowing foreign investment into Australia prior to the Foreign Investment Review Board making a decision should make more reasonable attempts to put before the FIRB the facts and figures. This would allow a reasonable amount of investment in Australia rather than the overwhelming amount which we have at the moment. Problems arise in Queensland and New South Wales. In Queensland alone the area covered by rural investment is larger than the size of Belgium. In New South Wales the area held by foreign ownership is two and a half times the size of Luxembourg.

It seems to me that the sorts of investments and secret deals that are taking place make it very difficult for the FIRB to follow through the investments in the States and to ascertain where investments are taking place. In some cases it is very difficult for the FIRB to know the identity of the company involved. We find that in some States nominee companies have been set up. The nominee companies are making investments for foreign owners. This information is not available to the Australian authorities when they examine the investments taking place in various States. I think that the lack of information about this investment is shown fairly clearly in an answer given by the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, to a question. On 18 August 1982 the former Treasurer refused to answer a question I placed on notice in the Senate requesting details of the names of all foreigners who had invested in Australian rural land in the previous two years and the locations and descriptions of those properties. The then Treasurer refused to give that information. I feel that the people of Australia have a right to know that information. They should be aware of the number of investments that have taken place and what countries are making major investments in Australia. The Treasurer, in his reply, went on to say that publication of the names of the parties and descriptions of the properties would not be considered appropriate. I believe that the people throughout Australia think that it is appropriate that they should know who is investing in Australia and in what countries the companies are being formed to take over rural land throughout Australia.

In Queensland, one can look at the fact that the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, has continually refused to set up a register of foreign-owned land in that State . While he has made the statement on a number of occasions that it would be a fairly simple matter to set up a register of foreign-owned companies, he has continually refused to make that information available to the electors or to the public of Queensland. I believe that after the election on 22 October Queensland will have a government in power which will in no way refuse to bring about a register of foreign-owned land so that the people of Queensland, if not the rest of Australia, will be aware of the investments that are taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon the Premier will change his mind?

—I do not think that the Premier will be there after 22 October. It is all right for members of the Liberal Party to interject. But if one looks at the problems faced by the Liberal Party in Queensland one finds that it is obvious that the Australian Labor Party will win the election and that Keith Wright will be the new Premier of Queensland. The other point I would like to make is that the Federal Government has laid down a number of guidelines in relation to foreign investment in Australia. The guidelines set down by the previous Government on foreign investment and rural lands adopted in March last year depend heavily on the advice from State governments. I have said previously that I do not believe that in some cases the State governments, particularly the Government of Queensland, are giving correct information or advice to the Federal Government to allow it to make a correct decision in relation to investment taking place in Australia. The Government relies fairly heavily on advice from the State governments in determining whether or not a proposal for the acquisition of land would lead to a significant economic benefit. The question I pose at this stage is: Who gets the economic benefit? Is it Australia , Queensland or a foreign investment company?

SPEECH.PARA: I go a little further and examine what the former Treasurer, Mr Howard-the discredited former Treasurer as has been so aptly put by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on occasions-said in answer to a further question asked in the Senate. He said that it was quite possible that some foreign interests may be acquiring small rural holdings which are no longer operational farms and which are exempt from examination under the Foreign Takeovers Act or the foreign investment policy and that the Government did not believe it would be feasible for it to monitor such minor land acquisitions. That in itself is a fairly reasonable statement. But when one looks at what is happening one finds that in some electorates, particularly in the electorate of Barambah in Queensland-of course, I think it goes without saying that it is in the electorate of the Premier of Queensland-a number of rural holdings have been taken up by Japanese companies. Although those rural holdings are not large enough at this stage for an application to be placed before the FIRB, if they were to become a conglomerate then we would find that those Japanese companies would have a very large holding in the electorate represented by the Premier of Queensland. The Japanese companies would have a substantial say in what happens to the rural community and the rural production in that area. If there is a chance that those sorts of companies could come together, even though the holding is small, I believe it should be looked at by the FIRB. I believe that the State government should make some recommendations in relation to those companies seeking small holdings side by side in a particular State.

I go a little further and state that the one thing we need to look at is what is happening in Queensland in relation to holdings. We need to look at what is happening in some of the other States. The only other example I give is the situation as it applies to the Northern Territory. I would like to give an example of what is happening in that area. The Sabah Government controls Monte Jinni Station which is 9,000 square kilometres. It is a pastoral lease. In Queensland, Burenda, a 22,417 hectare sheep stud at Augathella-it is in central Queensland very close to Charleville-is held by foreign ownership. A 328 hectare cattle grazing property is held by foreign ownership in the Premier's electorate of Barambah.

The same Japanese company that owns the 328 hectare property also owns two other rural properties in that electorate. They are the properties that I am talking about that are reasonably close together. They could be easily put together, easily made into a large holding and could return a fairly strong economic profit to the company that holds those three properties. It also could have a very detrimental effect on the people who control the rural community within that area. I point out some further examples in relation to Queensland. I am pointing out only some of these examples because of the Premier's lack of interest in what is happening in his State. I refer to a property called Leslie near Warwick. That property has been held by Australian families for 100 years. It is now held by a Japanese company, having been bought for $1.3m. It was offered to Australian companies and the claim was that no Australian company would take it over. We find in Queensland that so much rural land has been taken over by foreign investment that the rural community is being controlled by overseas companies, particularly Japanese companies.

Another famous investment in Queensland, about which I do not think one need say a great deal, is the Iwasaki project at Yeppoon. An agreement was made with the State Government but we find that just a few months ago the Premier, when the Parliament was in recess, made a statement that because Iwasaki could not meet the terms of the agreement made with his Government, the Government would change the agreement so that Iwasaki could meet the time schedule laid down.

JCL Investment Pty Ltd, a South African company, has gained approval from the Federal Government to establish a hypermarket at Aspley, an outer suburb of Brisbane. Whilst the Foreign Investment Review Board approved the investment by JCL Investment Pty Ltd, I do not really believe that the Premier of Queensland or the State Government really pointed out to the FIRB the problems that would be faced by small businesses in the Aspley community. I do not think I am alone in saying this. I believe a Liberal member of the State Parliament has said on a number of occasions that the small businesses in the Aspley area will find that they will not be able to compete with a hypermarket development in that area. It should be said that hypermarkets will make supermarkets look like ice cream shops on suburban corners. That is how large hypermarkets are. They will take away any opportunity that small business has in the Aspley area to flourish or take in some of the custom from that area. Small business will be strangled by the development of the hypermarket.

We can go a little further and look at the attempted investment in the Jackson to Moonie oil pipeline. We all know that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that that project should not be proceeded with because of the large amount of foreign investment involved. We find that the Premier made a statement to the Press attacking the Federal Treasurer because he stopped the investment by the Koreans in that pipeline.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for No Development he called him, didn't he?

—I think he called him even worse than that, but we will come back to that in a moment. One has to understand that the Treasurer said that an Australian firm-Australian firms were available-should put up at least 50 per cent of the capital to support the development of that pipeline. It was that sort of protection that the Treasurer was talking about, which would have prevented the giving away of our economic say in the way the Premier was prepared to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we should look in some detail at some of the investments I talked about before. I do not think I need to deal in any more detail with relation to the Northern Territory but I think it is worth while at this stage pointing to an interview on Countrywide. The program was screened on 10 November 1982 and the topic was that the Sabah Government owns 9,000 square kilometres of cattle stations in Northern Territory, where it breeds beef for live export to Sabah and plans to set up an abattoir in an all-foreign owned operation. In relation to the development undertaken by that enterprise, one of the correspondents had this to say:

This is the Northern Territory and these cattle are on their way to Malaysia. Tonight they'll be trucked to the port of Wyndham. Tomorrow they'll be on their way to the oil rich Malaysian state of Sabah. The ship that carried the cattle is also owned by the Sabah Government. The management and labour input on these cattle is Australian. The profit and full ownership is Malaysian. The hay, for eight days at sea for 700 cattle, is grown on one of Sabah's Australian cattle stations. So they're now almost independent. They've got the cattle, the transport ship, the feed, and most of all, 9,000 square kilometres of Australia' s top end. The jewel of Sabah's offshore kingdom is Camfield, widely regarded as one of the best places to raise cattle in the Northern Territory. It was purchased five years ago and at the time Australian meat workers welcomed with some trepidation a company that would spend money on improving the place and thereby boosting the annual turnoff. And spend money they have, on new bores, kilometres and kilometres of fences, and three sets of cattle yards, each capable of handling over 10,000 head.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT Senator Sibraa)-Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to talk about the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong, which has come up for some discussion in the community over the last year or so. I want to make particular reference to the decision of the Federal Government, or the Australian Labor Party, to mothball this fine facility or to turn it over probably to the Department of Primary Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The existence and functioning of this laboratory is of vital concern to rural Australia. My concern as a grazier, as a Queenslander from the major beef exporting State, and as an Australian, whose country earns at least $1.4 billion a year from beef and mutton alone, cannot be over-emphasised.

It is a tragedy that this great facility has become the object of an emotional argument-an argument about the place of foot and mouth disease and foot and mouth disease virus in Australia. Dealing with that disease is not the sole purpose of the animal health laboratory at Geelong. It has many functions quite apart from research into foot and mouth disease virus. It is concerned with the diagnosis and control of all exotic animal diseases in Australia. I can understand some of the fears in the community about it but they arise from a lack of knowledge as to what this facility should do. It is a diagnostic and research facility. In the facility at Geelong we have the finest such establishment in the world. What we need to do now that we have the hardware is train the staff and prove up the procedures.

I come back to the central point. The purpose of this laboratory is to research exotic diseases and to develop protection and diagnostic techniques and apply them to the Australian rural industries. There are at least 39 exotic diseases of major significance to the Australian rural community, quite apart from foot and mouth disease, and the control of all 39 is vital to the welfare of the cattle industry, the sheep industry and the pig industry. Some of the more common diseases like rabies, Rift Valley fever and rinderpest need no explanation.

We ought to reflect for a little while on rabies because that can be a human disease as well as a disease of animals. Any parent who has looked after children in a rabiatic area, as I have, would know the worry that comes with the possibility of small children playing with animals infected with rabies. Such animals are often sick and so are easily captured by children. The children play with them, pet them, can be bitten and get rabies. Rabies is one of the most dreadful diseases one can have. I forget my pathology on this disease, but a patient probably has 120 days of agony before he dies, and the treatment is almost as bad as the painful death. It is a horrible disease. Australia has the largest wild pig and fox population in the world. The vectors in which rabies could live and multiply pose problems that are probably worse for Australia than for any other country.

The history of the Animal Health Laboratory goes back 20 years. The Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works approved the construction of this facility in 1974 and no voice in opposition was ever raised by the scientific or farming communities. We have proceeded with the construction of this facility; we have built a building at a cost so far of about $155m. It is an engineering masterpiece; there is no other building in the world like it. Its design has come from first principles. It is as complex as an oil refinery but, unlike an oil refinery where every design is derived from an earlier design and is different only in detail, the complexity of this engineering masterpiece has had to be thought out from first principles. I have undiminished pride, as should all Australians, in the design and construction team that built that building. It will hold 120 large animals and sterilise all their excreta, even their expired air. It is absolutely safe biologically from any movement of viral or other bacterial contaminants out into the outside world.

In passing might I say that since we have put together a design team which has capabilities that no other nation in the world has, the Government should consider, in the way it did with the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority, making that design and engineering team available on a consultancy basis to interested nations such as Japan and a few others to build similar facilities. This is the most sophisticated facility in the world. I have seen only one other viral research laboratory, the English laboratory at Pirbright, which I visited last month. It bears no comparison at all with the Australian facility.

Having had some training as a microbiologist, I understand the fears that the lay community has about dangerous and infectious diseases. It must be emphasised that those dangers can be controlled and are entirely manageable. Moving into the human world, for many years in this country we kept smallpox virus to prepare smallpox vaccines. That is a highly pathogenic virus for mankind. Had it escaped and become uncontrollable in the Australian community, a community which was unvaccinated, then there would have been a significant death toll. We were happy to accept that risk, but we are not happy to accept a lesser risk with respect to animal pathogens.

The matter has been the subject of some informed inquiry. Regrettably, it has received very little comment, but the Australian Science and Technology Council reported on it in the recent past. I commend the ASTEC report to the Senate because it is a responsible, effective and honest compromise on what is a very difficult problem, difficult because of the emotion that surrounds it. What ASTEC proposed will work and it should be applied. Now that the hardware is built, we need to train up the laboratory staff in the techniques, develop the whole laboratory as a working system, prove that it can be secure, and review the situation by 1987, as ASTEC recommends. I accept that, and I think anyone who knows anything about the situation accepts it. We cannot accept the proposition that the ANAHL be mothballed or turned over to DPI. If it is mothballed it will be lost to the Australian community. If it goes to DPI it will not have the research function which is absolutely vital for its growth and effectiveness.

I am astonished that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has supported this proposition. The Minister has never visited Geelong, and I find that astonishing. The Minister for Science and Technology has never visited the most important single scientific establishment in the country. I think it is the most expensive single building we have ever built here. I am forced to reflect on the comment by one of the senior members of the Australian scientific establishment that the Minister for Science and Technology knows everything but understands nothing. Also, I notice that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has never visited Geelong. As far as I am aware, only Senator Chipp and I , of the Federal politicans, have taken the trouble to go down there and see it since it has been completed.

The decision that has been taken to mothball ANAHL is a decision that is of fundamental importance to Australia, yet it was taken without reference to, discussion with, or in consultation with any of the interested parties in the Australian community. It is very important to the security of Australian rural exports. It is very important from a research point of view for the development of new reagents, new diagnostic techniques and new vaccines. When I talk about vaccines in the animal world I am not talking in terms of a few thousand vaccines that can be produced every year. The market extends to hundreds of millions of doses annually. The benefits from the production of those vaccines for the laboratory that is first into the field, both in direct production and in royalty payments, are enormous. We are looking not only at animal research but also at research that has an application frequently to human health problems . I find it astonishing that a Minister who makes so much play of the need to develop a scientific base for Australian industry should turn his back on something that provides an opportunity to develop the real expertise we have in this field.

The criticism of ANAHL turns on security, and that is related to two factors, the mechanical security of the building and the human factor. Mechanically, Geelong is a generation beyond any other facility in the world. All other facilities, such as Pirbright and Plum Island in the United States of America, had their origins in the 1920s or the 1930s or the 1940s.
