They were built at a time when knowledge was nowhere near as complete as it is at present, and I will instance one example. It was not known, for example, that viral transmission could take place through water vapour contamination or droplet contamination through the expired air from animals and travel not for hundreds of yards but for 20 or 30 miles, as is known today. Of course, at Geelong the respired air from the animals is completely sterilised before it is exhausted to the atmosphere. I have been to Pirbright, as I said earlier. The wonder is, when you see those buildings, not that it had outbreaks-one of the criticisms of Geelong is that outbreaks of infectious or exotic diseases have taken place from research facilities, and that is true with the older ones-but that there were not more of them. We can guarantee that the mechanical side of Geelong is such that we can control the escape of micro-organisms from that facility.

The human factor is another matter, but I am prepared to defend the professional pride and training of the staff who work there. There is no defence at all against people who have a grudge against society and who wish to create damage. The opportunities they have at Geelong are no different from those available to someone walking into a powerhouse of a major city and sabotaging that powerhouse and causing a large death toll, with people dying in hospitals and situations like that. The principal criticism stems really from the academic world. It is a very vicious, incestuous academic fight that is at the heart of the ANAHL dispute. It arises principally from a few people at the Australian National University. They are not concerned with the money that went into ANAHL. They are concerned about the maintenance grant of $10m or $12m that would go to ANAHL each year if it were running at full blast. They think that they could use that money better. They have stirred up the rural community with this campaign of fear. They have created also divisions within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

In the past I have spoken of the need for us to discuss scientific and technical matters in this Parliament, and I have deplored the total absence of debate on it. Australia's future turns on the application of science and technology to the community, not on arguments by lawyers like Senator Button, who has just come into this chamber. This week the Senate has been debating the Family Law Amendment Bill, and the Freedom of Information Bill will be coming on for debate. I do not doubt the importance of those from a human interest point of view. The plea I make is that it is just as important for human beings to discuss the place of science in this community. Long ago I foresaw the need for this Parliament to cope with scientific matters. In conclusion, I quote from a speech by Dr Wild, the head of CSIRO. In an address he gave recently he said:

All this brings me to a larger consideration. As we head further into the 80s we as a nation will be confronted with an ever-increasing number of technically complex issues of great importance and interest to the general public. Experience overseas, particularly in the U.S. and Europe indicates that we can only expect these debates to become more heated, confusing and divisive as time goes on. The opportunities that will be presented by these debates for mischief- making by irresponsible individuals posing as experts can only be guessed at. It is of the utmost importance, therefore, that we devise ways of conducting these debates which will minimize these opportunities, and maximize informed discussion. In particular, scientists will need to devote much more attention to translating technical complexities into language understood by the wider community to promote informed public debate.
I completely concur with those sentiments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The matter I raise this afternoon might seem a rather small and insignificant one. I acknowledge that fact, but even though it might be small and insignificant to some people it is of significance to others in the community. I will not be speaking at length but I want to make a few remarks about what I term 'junk mail'. By 'junk mail' I refer to unsolicited articles, almost invariably advertising articles which are distributed to private letterboxes. These items can be such things as brochures indicating specials for the local supermarket, local 'free' newspapers, advertisements for keep fit classes, political propaganda-probably read by only those who have some political bias anyway-department store catalogues and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past few months, I have been criticised because I referred to this material at one stage as 'junk mail, the bane of all householders'. Perhaps I was too sweeping in my comments, to say that this material is the bane of all householders. But I am by no means overstating the case to suggest that it is, at least, the bane of many householders. I have seen many suburban letterboxes on Monday mornings which are so crammed with unsolicited material which has been delivered over the weekend that the normal delivery of Australia Post mail has been almost impossible. I am mindful of the employment generated by this type of advertising. It would not be unfair to say that some of those who distribute the material are underpaid for doing so. Nevertheless, to put a total ban on this type of mail would be detrimental to the employment prospects of a large number of people and, partly for this reason, I have never suggested a total ban.

When I spoke about this matter earlier this year I referred to a report which had been mentioned to me by the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy. This report suggests that the Postal Services Act could be amended to provide that it be an offence for anyone other than Australia Post to place material into letterboxes marked 'For Postal Articles only'. This suggestion drew considerable criticism from some firms which use this type of advertising. One firm forwarded to me a copy of a letter which it had written to Mr Duffy on this matter. In this letter it is claimed that this industry provides work for about 12,000 workers throughout Australia in distributing the material. As well as that, it was claimed, thousands of people are employed in printing the material. I have no reason to doubt these figures and a level of employment of this magnitude must not be taken lightly. The letter to which I have referred said, in part:

Sir, we appreciate a vocal minority are against this form of advertising, but there are steps they can take to prevent this material going into their letterboxes, namely by placing a simple notice on their letterbox prohibiting delivery.

I do not know whether it is a vocal minority only which objects to this form of advertising. It may be that there is a silent majority which finds it annoying. Nevertheless, I agree with the step suggested by the writers of the letter for preventing the material being placed in letterboxes. The suggestion was to place a simple notice on a letterbox prohibiting delivery. But unless there is legislation to give backing to such a notice, it could well prove to be as useless as a 'beware of the dog' sign backed up by a 20-year-old persian cat. I therefore hold that the suggestion of a suitable amendment to the Postal Services Act should be pursued. In this way employees, advertisers and householders who want this type of material delivered and those who do not want it can all be accommodated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this first reading debate on the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 to discuss organised crime and police corruption. I make the remark at the beginning of my speech that I believe most policemen in Australia are highly dedicated and courageous young men and women who, when considering the risks that they sometimes have to take, are grossly underpaid. I pay a tribute to the majority of police in Australia. My remarks today are directed to those despicable creatures-they are in the minority-who are not honest, who wear the uniform and who prostitute democracy. In passing may I say that I have a particular regard for the Victorian Police Force as such and its most distinguished Commissioner, Mr Miller, who I believe is a magnificent person and officer, and also the present Chief Commissioner of Police in New South Wales, Mr Cec Abbott, with whom I formed a close relationship when I was Minister for Customs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Street Royal Commission cleared the Premier of New South Wales of the charge, raised publicly in a program of the then Australian Broadcasting Commission, that he had attempted to influence the administration of justice in New South Wales in the case against Mr Kevin Humphreys. However, Mr Justice Street did not clear the law enforcement agencies of New South Wales. He found that the former Chief Stipendiary Magistrate, Mr Farquhar, 'did influence the outcome of the committal proceedings'-that is, that he caused the Stipendiary Magistrate, Mr Jones, to make a finding which he would not have made but for Mr Farquhar's intervention. This finding raises many questions about the administration of justice in New South Wales which go far beyond Mr Jones's specific conduct of the case and which were not caught by the narrow terms of reference of the Street Commission.

I am dwelling on corruption in the New South Wales Police Force and on the administration of justice because New South Wales is where most of the organised crime in Australia is centred. It is a major source of heroin importation, illegal gambling, vice and those things that make up the $700m a year profits that are going to organised crime in this country. If there is something wrong with the Police Force or the courts in New South Wales, it is not just a State matter, it is a national matter which can affect all Australians. One wonders why it took six years for the matter to be dealt with when, according to the evidence before Mr Justice Street, at least seven stipendiary magistrates knew about it as early as 1977 and the Public Service Board as early as 1978. One wonders about the extent to which police inquiries were interfered with and which senior police, if any, provided assistance to Mr Humphreys in 1977 and 1978. These matters were not brought out at the Royal Commission. Extraordinarily, some of those questions were not even asked. Most importantly, one wonders why the restrictive terms of reference were not widened-as it is, both Mr Wran and Mr Justice Street say they expected the other to do so if it became necessary. The necessity to inquire into the administration of the law in New South Wales in general, and police corruption in particular, may be judged by the fact that this is not the first time queries have arisen about law enforcement in New South Wales.

I cite some cases that are on the public record that scream out for answers. I refer to the Shirley Brifman affair. In June 1971 Shirley Brifman named the then head of the New South Wales Special Breaking Squad, Fred Krahe, as the man to whom she had paid $100 per week protection money for several years. In a record of interview totalling 60 pages, Brifman alleged that Krahe and 33 other detectives, also named, had received stolen goods, organised bank robberies, distributed counterfeit money, fixed court cases and framed criminals. I am not talking about Chicago, Mr Deputy President, I am talking about Sydney, New South Wales.

An investigation was commenced but before it produced any results, Brifman was found dead in Brisbane. At the request of Queensland Police, no coroner's inquest was held. Police treated it as suicide-a most incredible situation. Further allegations about Krahe's involvement in a car stealing racket were made but as charges were being prepared Krahe was allowed to retire as medicaly unfit with a police pension. He was given a private investigator's licence which he retained until his death in 1981 and used to carry out many controversial assignments including work for the developers of Victoria Street, Kings Cross, and an inquiry for the Nugan fruit company. On some of his work he is reported to have worked in close co-operation with the New South Wales police.

I turn now to the Bartons' case. Investigations into the corporate activities of the Bartons began in 1973 and several million dollars and seven years later showed a nil result when most of the fraud and conspiracy charges were dropped by the then Attorney-General, Mr Frank Walker, acting on the advice of the Crown Solicitor. Mr Gruzman, the Barton's former legal adviser, had charged that Mr Walker and Mr Wran had obstructed Mr Gruzman's investigations into some of the complex corporate dealings involved. Mr Gruzman withdrew these allegations when he was granted $100,000 costs by the Crown. On the same day, the Crown withdrew eight outstanding charges of false swearing against Mr Gruzman. This is not Chicago I am referring to, but Sydney, New South Wales.

I refer next to the Merv Wood case. Mr Merv Wood was appointed New South Wales Police Commissioner in 1976. Following numerous allegations of unchecked illegal gambling and apparent direct contact between Mr Wood and gambling identities, a dossier on police corruption was released by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Mason, and Mr Wood announced his resignation. According to Mr Wran, a police inquiry into the dossier disclosed only one serious allegation about events, which were unspecified, which took place before the shooting of two women who worked for one of the illegal casinos. To this date, no action has been taken about that dossier or the allegations.

The next matter is the matter of Roy Cessna, one involving the importation of cannabis valued at $1.5m. This case was heard as a summary matter in the magistrates court after the valuation figure had been changed to 'some value'. In the New South Wales Parliament charges were made that this alteration took place at the behest of the then Police Commissioner, Mr Merv Wood. The case was heard before-guess who-Mr Murray Farquhar. It was his last case. He sentenced one of the two defendants to 18 months gaol, with a non-parole period of eight months, and released the other on a bond. I repeat, this did not happen in Chicago but in Sydney, New South Wales.

I turn now to the alleged $5,000 per week gambling bribe. In October 1981 the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Mason, alleged that he had been offered $ 5,000 per week to do nothing about illegal gambling in New South Wales. A year later the independent member of Parliament for the South Coast, Mr John Hatton, alleged that the offer had been made by a former Liberal member of parliament, Mr Tim Walker. To my knowledge, and to the knowledge of newspapers, to this date , no action at all has been taken to investigate this allegation.

I refer now to the matter of compensation for Abe Saffron, one of the most notorious, despicable human beings, if one can use that term loosely, living in this country. In July 1978 the New South Wales Government found that a building owned by the Public Transport Authority had been illegally sublet by Sir Paul Strasser and another developer to two companies owned by Mr Abe Saffron and that the building now housed a gambling club, a brothel and a sex shop. The New South Wales Government chose to buy out the lease-this is almost incom- prehensible-at a cost to the public purse of $2.6m. There is no record of any action against the gambling club or the brothel.

Let me turn to the Bill Allen affair. In 1981, Premier Wran appointed Mr Bill Allen Deputy Commissioner of Police, even as misconduct investigations against Mr Allen were in progress. Following disclosure of these investigations, an inquiry was established and found that Mr Allen had maintained contact with Mr Saffron, had tried to bribe a sergeant, had obtained free airline tickets from a person who wanted to get a casino licence and free accommodation at Caesar's Palace from the Bally poker machine company and in San Francisco at the expense of Mr Waterhouse, who was also interested in obtaining a casino licence. Mr Allen was then Deputy Commissioner of Police in New South Wales. He was allowed to retire with a pension of $17,000 and an immediate lump sum payment of $37,000 . No legal action was ever taken against Mr Allen.

As I have said, this all reads like an extract from a novel such as The Godfather or a novel on mobster rule in Chicago or New York in the 1920s. In fact, this information was published in the National Times on 24 June of this year. I find it incomprehensible that no legal action was taken by any of the people or organisations named or identified in that article. We know that some of the people who were named in the article have always been very quick on the draw in issuing writs for defamation when their names have been used or misused. In this case, although specific allegations were made, no writs have been taken out and it is now several months since the article was published.

The National Crimes Commission summit conference earlier this year resulted in a disgusting exhibition of petty little State politicians pushing their precious State rights. Even though organised crime is flourishing their main concern seemed to be that that did not matter as long as States' rights were preserved. It now seems that the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, whom I compliment today for his patience and fortitude at that conference, will have considerable opposition to overcome before he can use the avenue of a crimes commission to tackle organised crime and police corruption in this country. I should have liked to have asked him whether he would undertake to refer the matters that I have raised to the Crimes Commission but its establishment seems a long way away . However, the matter still remains extremely urgent.

I therefore ask the Attorney-General whether he is prepared to establish a royal commission, at Federal level, to inquire into police corruption and political corruption in Australia, particularly in the two States that I have named, one run by a Labor Government and the other run by a National Party Government. I proceed with my request on the assumption that the governments of the States concerned, the Wran Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government, have nothing to hide and would co-operate with the Federal Government in organising such a royal commission. I would assume that both of those Premiers would be as concerned about organised crime as those of us in this chamber and, seeing that these matters that I have raised, all of them serious matters, have received no investigation since they were disclosed, it would seem to me that a royal commission at Federal level with State co-operation is the only solution. I press that matter before the Federal Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table various papers, letters and telex exchanges between the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, relating to the Alice Springs-Darwin railway; papers by Australian National, entitled 'Planning and Design of the Alice Springs-Darwin Railway'; submissions from the four mayors of the Northern Territory, the Lord Mayor of Darwin, Mr Cecil Black, the Mayor of Alice Springs, Mrs Lesley Oldfield, the Mayor of Katherine, Mrs Patricia Davies and the Mayor of Tennant Creek, Mr Alf Chittock; and various other documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like first of all to refer to the document submitted by the chief civil engineer of Australian National, Mr Smith, entitled 'Planning and Design of the Alice Springs-Darwin Railway'. It is a most comprehensive document and I draw it to the attention of honourable senators and to the public in general. It is self-explanatory and refers to the proposed railway line to stretch some 1,440 kilometres from Alice Springs to Darwin. It has been mooted over the past few years and has now come to the stage where it is practically ready for construction. Planning and designing for the railroad project continues. This year some $65m is available to cover the planning and designing phase to bring it to the stage where construction can commence. Some 100 people- planners, designers, surveyors, engineers and the many support personnel-are still employed to bring the project to the point of readiness for actual construction. That is very heartening.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated in the documents that have been tabled in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, there is an exchange of letters and telexes between the Prime Minister and Mr Everingham between the dates of 16 September last year and 24 August this year. There is also a joint memorandum from the Premier of South Australia and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory in support of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and notes of meetings between the Prime Minister and representatives of the Northern Territory and South Australian governments and officials of the Department of Transport dated 18 August 1983. All this advice is self-explanatory and all the documents are public. The Prime Minister has indicated that an inquiry into the railroad should be held although one would ask why it is necessary for such an inquiry when previously this project was at the point of construction.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is whether it is worth spending the money on it. You would not argue about that, would you?

—The interjection asked whether it is worth spending money on it. The Prime Minister in the previous Government, Mr Fraser, supported by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Doug Anthony, indicated that he believed that this was the case and the project had been agreed to at that stage . I am not here now to debate that point. It was also indicated by the Prime Minister that the Northern Territory should contribute to the railway. In response to that, Mr Everingham explained that the Northern Territory was funded on the basis of responsibilities which had been transferred to it. This did not include railways. The Commonwealth Grants Commission made regular assessments of the Northern Territory's funding situation and always concluded that the Territory was underfunded to meet its responsibilities. The Prime Minister noted too that the Commonwealth could also do with more funds. He emphasised that the inquiry would proceed and invited South Australia and the Northern Territory to co-operate in the structure and details. He emphasised, too, that if that co- operation was not forthcoming the Commonwealth would go ahead on its own basis. Of course, that was an unwarranted threat because both South Australia and the Northern Territory had agreed wholeheartedly under the circumstances that they would participate in this inquiry to bring about its completion and in an endeavour to ensure that as little time as possible was lost. Mr Everingham also noted that the Commonwealth was imposing the inquiry on the Northern Territory regardless of the views of the Northern Territory or South Australia. In these circumstances he agreed that the officers would participate with the Commonwealth in preparing the terms of reference, et cetera. However, Mr Everingham noted that the Northern Territory would not be able to indicate whether it would co-operate with the inquiry until a Commonwealth attitude to the terms of reference and other relevant details was clear. I call upon the Government to bring about the terms of reference for the inquiry and to name the inquirers as quickly as possible to avoid as little delay as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators would have noted some two weeks ago-there was considerable publicity in the media-the arrival in Canberra and here at Parliament House of the delegation of the four mayors of the Northern Territory. Also included in that delegation was Mr Noel Fullerton, who is a well known cameleer not only in the Northern Territory but also in Australia. It was he who brought his camels down from Central Australia and he made a rather imposing figure at the doors of Parliament House when he pleaded with the Government to continue with this project. For the next few minutes I take the opportunity to discuss briefly the submission of the four mayors who came from the Northern Territory. Their submission began:

May we, as the elected leaders of the four local government authorities in the Northern Territory, voice our disapproval on behalf of Territorians at the decision of your Government to require from Territorians a 40 per cent contribution towards the total cost of construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway.

Many words have been spoken since then and in the advice to the Prime Minister from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, he indicated that the Territory was not funded in a manner to allow such money to be applied to the railway. The submission of the mayors continued:

It is totally un-Australian to deprive 120,000 Australians of a basic service which is available to virtually all other Australians and especially if account is taken of the spin-off effect of the Railway in terms of direct job creation, trade, tourism, etc. for not only the Northern Territory, but many other parts of Australia.

Amongst the points that they brought forward, they commented that the rail link would enable Territory companies to look to penetrate the larger southern markets and similarly southern companies would be able to tap previously economically inaccessible areas in the north. This would create a healthy trade growth in both the north and south. The result would be more jobs. The submission went on to say that a reliable transportation link would improve trade with South East Asia. It stated:

Darwin will become an economic alternative to the cluttered ports of the south and with regular shipping into the Port of Darwin the transporting of Territory and Australian goods overseas and the importing of goods especially from south- east Asia will be evident. This development as an import and export centre will result in the growth of service industries.
The result would be more jobs. It continued:
The completion of the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway will significantly bolster the number of tourists coming to the Territory.
It continued in that vein and stated:
We are confident that with the Railway there would be a boom in tourism and as such a growth in services required at all tourist centres to cater for this boom .

The result would be more jobs. It went on to stress that during the construction phase there would be direct employment for about 300 people over the life of the project. The multiplier effect of this full employment during the construction phase would have a significant impact on employment in a multiplicity of other industries. They estimated that at least 750 new jobs in the Northern Territory and a further 1,100 new jobs in Australia would be generated during each year of the construction phase. It went on to point out, also, that there would be a tremendous spin-off around Australia, for instance, in Whyalla. It stated that 150,000 tonnes of steel rail will be used and will in all probability be produced at Whyalla. The submission continued:

A total of 2.25 million concrete and steel sleepers will be required for the project. One thousand culverts, 25,000 metres of culvert pipes and 100 individual bridges will be required. Earthworks will require 17 million cubic metres in embankments and 3 million cubic metres in cuttings.
The result, of course, would be more jobs. It continued:
When the Railway becomes operational, it will immediately create 240 new jobs in the Northern Territory.

It is of interest to note, too, that seven to 11 new locomotives will be initially required and this will rise to 27 or 31 locomotives in due course. Five hundred new freight wagons and 25 new passenger cars will be needed. This will probably rise to 2,000 freight wagons in due course, This plant will probably be built and maintained in New South Wales and South Australia and will contribute substantially to employment in the iron, steel and heavy engineering industries. The result would be more jobs. The mayors consider that the impact on the communities that they represent would be most significant. Retail, manufacturing, mining, pastoral, agricultural, service and tourist industries will use the urban centres as hubs to transport their requirements and products to and from suppliers and markets. The result would of course be more jobs. The submission continued:
On a wider basis, the Railway will greatly increase the potential for development of resource based and export oriented industries in nothern Australia.
It refers also to the defence aspect, a matter that is of tremendous importance:

The availability of the Railway will enhance Australia's northern defence capability and assist, if commenced from the Darwin end at an early date, the development of Tindal Air Base at Katherine. Furthermore, Darwin is the only Capital City and the largest community in Australia not being served by rail.

Once again, more jobs would result. The tabling of these documents makes available to the people who are most interested in these projects the exchange of correspondence that has taken place between the two leaders-the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham. Also, it indicates the role that Mr Bannon has played in conjunction with the Northern Territory. So I look forward to this inquiry with considerable interest. I ask the Government to allow it to take place and to nominate an inquirer. It is of tremendous interest to see that Australian National is still carrying out design activities. This most essential work will come to a close by -some say-the end of this financial year. By then the project will be ready to go. I hope the inquiry will be carried out quickly and that no undue delay whatsoever will be occasioned when it has been completed. I believe there can be only one result, a result that will confirm the necessity for the railway, one that will confirm that the proposal will be financially viable. With all these matters going forward I hope that there will be a recommendation in, say, one year's time will result in construction of this most important project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to refer to a number of matters. They fall into the category of local matters as far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned. They are important to people of the Australian Capital Territory and to me. This is, I think, an appropriate time to raise some of the issues. This morning the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) tabled a statement in which he dealt with the extension of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. I commented then that I was pleased the Service would be made available in Canberra as soon as possible and, hopefully, at the time he mentioned, that is, November.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to another matter in the area of Veterans' Affairs. On 29 May this year the Minister announced that a regional centre for conducting repatriation medical examinations and dealing with repatriation claims would be established in Canberra. This was greeted by the local veteran community with pleasure. Many veterans in Canberra and the surrounding districts will be able to take advantage of such a centre. The Minister said specifically that the regional office would be for the purpose of serving the southern region of New South Wales. So far nothing more has been heard about the establishment of the office. I remind the Minister of the fact that he announced that it would be set up and ask him how long it will be before it becomes available. I ask him to expedite the establishment of the handling of repatriation claims and the conducting of medical examinations in the Australian Capital Territory. It will be of great assistance to veterans and widows in this area. At present they are frequently required to visit Sydney and to correspond with departments based in Sydney. This is cumbersome. For people who have the sorts of problems with which veterans often deal it is more worrying that the Department is decentralised in that way. This morning I referred briefly to the transport problems as far as Canberra is concerned. The same argument applies to veterans who are in this category.

I now refer to a matter which involves the Department of Territories and Local Government and concerns the Australian Capital Territory obtaining from both New South Wales and Victoria a reasonable share of the profits of lottery tickets sold in the Australian Capital Territory for New South Wales and Victorian lotteries. A former Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, negotiated an agreement with the then Liberal Government in Victoria that 75 per cent of the profit from Australian Capital Territory sales would be returned to the Australian Capital Territory. That has happened. Such a payment does not eat into administrative funds; it comes out of surplus funds. Prize money, administrative costs and so on are deducted before the money comes back to the Australian Capital Territory. The previous Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, believed that 100 per cent of the surplus moneys should be returned to the Australian Capital Territory and was negotiating to that end. It may be that we will or will not ever succeed in getting back 100 per cent of the money to which I refer, but at least we are getting 75 per cent from Victoria.

The agreement that was finally reached with New South Wales was that it would pay 33 1/2 per cent, backdated from July 1982, and 50 per cent as from October 1982, but the agreement was only to be in force until 30 June this year. I ask the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) what has happened to the negotiations-or more specifically, I guess, the money? A report in the Canberra Times of 14 July stated that talks had begun between Australian Capital Territory officials and the New South Wales and Victorian governments to finalise arrangements. I have not heard anything further since. I would want to be sure that any final agreement involved the payment of the money from 1 July this year when the last agreement ran out. I want to see that we receive a reasonable share at least, if not 100 per cent, of the funds that can go into our Community Development Fund for use in the Australian Capital Territory. I ask the Minister to expedite the negotiations with a view to resolving the matter.

In the Australian Capital Territory, as in other States, there is an agreement between the Master Builders Association of the Australian Capital Territory and the Government for an apprenticeship scheme which operates to provide opportunities for apprentices within the building industry. It has been, as was stated in the Master Builders Association annual report, a most successful scheme. A number of young people have been provided with opportunities that they would not have had otherwise. A matter I have raised before and raise now is the question of the Master Builders Association paying payroll tax on the moneys that are used for this scheme. The scheme was set up under the Liberal Government, and it was a scheme which I applauded. Right from the beginning I have pressed Ministers to get together to work out an arrangement for the payroll tax to be exempt to enable more moneys to be available to indenture apprentices in the building industry. Perhaps one of the problems is that so many Ministers are involved in coming to a decision on this matter-perhaps the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Territories and Local Government. One of the problems we have is that a number of Ministers are involved in just about anything that goes on in the Australian Capital Territory. The real beneficiaries of such an exemption would be young people in Canberra who would be able to obtain apprenticeship training which would not be available to them otherwise. I ask the Minister for Territories and Local Government to take up this matter with his colleagues with a view to exempting this scheme from payroll tax.

Also, I ask the Minister to table the report that he has had for some nine weeks now on the review of the National Capital Development Commission. The community wants to know what is in the report. It is an important document which reviews an important authority in this community. The review was commissioned as a result of a decision reached following the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The Minister received the report some nine weeks ago. He said that he wanted an opportunity to read it, which was not unreasonable, but sufficient time has now passed. He said that he would table the report in the Budget session and he has, I believe, had time to do so. I ask that he give immediate attention to releasing the report so that the community can study it in great detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sessional order, I call on Questions Without Notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and refer to his comments on 6 July, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: There are people with hundreds of thousands of dollars, even some millionaires, who are receiving the service pension.

I refer also to his later threats about naming names in Parliament. Does the Minister not agree with his former leader, Mr Hayden, who in March last year said that this sort of argument about millionaires receiving pensions was 'a cruel and emotional device to cover up the Government's real intentions', those real intentions being 'to justify ripping the pension off ordinary people with modest savings they have worked for all their lives'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner has asked me a question about the substantial assets which some applicants have declared when they have made an approach to the Department of Veterans' Affairs through any of its six branches which come under my jurisdiction. In applications for a service pension some people have declared substantial assets in the form of cash which has been placed in family trusts, bank accounts and trading accounts in such a way as to avoid an income from such deposits. This happened to such an extent that officers in the various State branches drew it to the attention of the head of the Department, Mr Volker , and then conducted an inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: We found that some people who had received lump sum superannuation payments in excess of $100,000 or people with over $200,000 in a trading account-honourable senators would be aware that such accounts do not attract interest-were able to claim successfully for payment of a service pension in consequence of their not receiving any substantial income. So the remarks I made at various Returned Services League congresses were true both in substance and in particular instances. People with substantial assets are in fact and not in fantasy so organising their affairs as to avoid the responsibilities of providing for their own retirement. I do not resile from the statements I made. I believe that in the circumstances the Government had no alternative but to have an examination of the whole problem of assets and incomes as they related to service pension applicants.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that over the next five years there will be 190,000 potential service pension applicants. If we multiply that figure by the amount of $35,000 which, in current dollars, would be the average amount to which they and their spouses are entitled over that period, the total sum is considerable. We are quite happy to pay that, on the basis of the legislation that was introduced in 1935, to persons who are not in receipt of income. Fortunately, the forms which applicants fill in for the service pension require them to provide details of assets and income, as distinct from the forms for aged or invalid pensions. I was not gilding the lily when I made my comments. I was expressing the concern of my Department and of the Government when I made my comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Gietzelt for his remarks, but I wonder whether he might address himself to the remarks of his former leader, Mr Hayden, and to whether or not his statement during the Lowe by-election was one of the reasons that led to Mr Hayden's demise as Leader of the Labor Party.
—Order! I do not know that that is a supplementary question.

—I make one other point, Mr President. I ask Senator Gietzelt to advise us how many people dealt with in each State branch of his Department fall into the millionaire category, as he describes it, and, as he claims, should be dealt with by the legislation proposed by the Government.

—I am not in a position to indicate how many potential millionaires or millionaires in fact were breaching what I consider to be the spirit and morality of service pension legislation. I am reasonably confident that something like 10 per cent of all applicants for service pensions had sufficient assets to provide for their own weekly needs.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and refers to the statement he made to the Senate this morning with regard to the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. He stated that centres have been established in all State capitals and Darwin and, in addition, will be opened shortly in Canberra and Townsville. I applaud this initiative, but I am still concerned that difficulty may be experienced by Vietnam veterans in remote areas in gaining access to this Service. Can the Minister advise the Senate precisely what assistance is available to Vietnam veterans in outlying areas which would facilitate their access to the Counselling Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulties of assisting country clients entitled to be assisted by the Department of Veterans' Affairs are long standing. The problem for veterans generally is growing because they are becoming older. For those who served in Vietnam we have a specific problem. Many of them have moved to country areas because of the nature of their illnesses or the problems of adaptation to civilian life. The problems of providing a counselling service have been recognised by the present Government and various arrangements have been entered into in order to take at least some steps to solve the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer specifically to the fact that each of our Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service centres will accept reverse charge telephone calls from country clients. That means, of course, that the charge is borne by the Department and not by the person seeking assistance. Depending upon the nature of the problem facing the Vietnam veterans, our counsellors will visit country centres to contact the veterans and to liaise with existing community resources in those areas to assist not only the veterans but also their families, if that is the sort of counselling that is necessary. In my statement this morning I indicated that, to improve the service in regional areas, we are extending operations to Canberra and Townsville. It has been decided recently that, where a Vietnam veteran has a disability or problem that is accepted by the Department, if he is referred to us by his local medical officer or to the Counselling Service he is entitled to reimbursement for any of the travel expenses he incurs in coming to the city for the sort of treatment he needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Government's proposed assets test and, in particular, to the deemed rate of 10 per cent to be applied to all non-exempt assets in assessing income for pension purposes. Does the Minister agree that there are certain assets which do not produce any income but which are part of everyday living? I cite the example of a couple who retire on 50 acres or so; their home will be exempt from the assets test, but the rest of the property will not. Why has the Government rejected Treasury's recommendation that a lower deemed rate be applied to these types of non-financial assets thus placing an additional burden on ordinary Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I point out that the 10 per cent deemed rate is the same deemed rate that applied before 1976 when interest rates were considerably lower . We consider this to be a generous deemed rate. Secondly, Senator Reid alleged that the Treasury recommended a lower deemed rate. I am afraid I do not recollect having seen that recommendation of the Treasury in any papers but I will--
—Nobody has.

—I do not think anyone has. I certainly cannot remember anyone in the discussions we had recommending a lower deemed rate. Thirdly, the honourable senator referred to the example of a person living on 50 acres of land. We have announced, as applied in the previous assets test, that people on rural properties of the type about which Senator Reid talked are in need of special consideration and I agree that that is so. In fact, I think that under the previous assets test, as Senator Reid said, the general rule was that the house plus a quarter of an acre or so of land was all that was allowed to be exempt. I have indicated to the Department, as I have in discussions with the pensioner organisations, that I believe that that is too harsh. I believe that we should have, in keeping with the flexibility that was in the previous legislation, a more reasonable approach to rural properties and land of that type. I would be interested in hearing Senator Reid's views on what is a reasonable amount of land under those circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: I say in general that assets that are not capable of producing an income, assets which are locked up in trusts, for instance, to which people cannot get access, will in fact not be deemed to produce income. We have to come to a satisfactory arrangement about the sorts of properties Senator Reid has referred to. We will be spending the next couple of months talking to various groups in the community so that we can come up with a satisfactory situation. That is why we did not rush in, to use a rural analogy, like a bull at a gate, with firm recommendations which were rigid and which, undoubtedly, would have aroused, reasonably so, the ire of people in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question by saying that I would have asked it yesterday but I was attending a meeting of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which sat all day in accordance with a resolution of this place. I address my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. In view of the importance that the Government has placed on establishing new industries in Australia, when can we expect a decision on the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee? What will be the implications of the report for high technology industries in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to assess the implications of the implementation of a report such as the Espie report for high technology industries. In a sense, the Espie report is recommending taking something of a plunge into the future. I will come back to that aspect of the Espie recommendations in a minute. I make the initial point, in answer to Senator Richardson's question, that for a number of years expert committees-the Crawford Committee, the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia and, more recently, the Espie Committee-have advocated the greater availability within Australia of venture capital or risk capital to support new and high technology industries. I think it is fair to say that governments-particularly the last one-were particularly remiss in taking any action to deal with the suggestions made in those various reports. Many governments overseas, most successfully the United States Government, have embarked on very imaginative ways of encouraging the availability of venture capital for new industries. The whole Silicon Valley experiment, which has been highly successful, was based on the availability of venture capital encouraged by the United States Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The present Government wants to see more capital available for these purposes in support of high technology industries in Australia. The Espie report, to which Senator Richardson referred-I notice that Senator MacGibbon referred to this topic in a scintillating speech that he made during the luncheon period- recommended the establishment of private sector management investment companies which would marshal equity capital for investment in firms with a high growth potential in high technology areas. I think there is an additional important element in the Espie proposals. It is not just a question of marshalling capital . The suggestion implicit in the Espie proposals is that that capital and those businesses should have management expertise available to them as well as money.

The Espie Committee suggested that the subscriptions to the management investment companies should be tax deductible to compensate for the difficulties faced by firms raising venture capital, particularly the very high risks involved. The Government, of course, as has been seen in the newspapers, has had the Espie report under consideration for some time, together with other means of increasing the availability of venture capital such as through the Australian Industry Development Corporation. Major decisions will be announced very shortly in respect of the Espie Committee report and the AIDC. The Government has already made decisions to provide the Australian Industry Development Corporation with extra capital-$12.5m was allocated in the Budget-to expand its gearing ratio to 1 : 15, to remove it from the requirements of the Australian Loan Council in respect of its borrowings and to provide it with a Commonwealth Government guarantee. That will vastly strengthen the position of the Corporation in terms of the assistance it will be able to offer both to new industries and to existing Australian industries anxious to upgrade their technological performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Social Security. Is it true that because the proportion of old people in our country is increasing rapidly the time is at hand when fewer and fewer young people will be earning wages and paying taxes to support more and more old people who will be asking for pensions ? Has the Leader of the Opposition stated that the coalition parties will abolish the assets test when they are returned to office? How then can the Government expect a standing committee of this Senate, which has been asked to report on this and allied matters, to discuss the matter objectively if half its number have already been committed to destroying the assets test? Will he now reconsider the Australian Democrats proposal for, not a Senate committee, but a royal commission into this question and into the questions of income security, taxation, wealth distribution, national superannuation and a scheme for a guaranteed minimum income for all Australians? Can the Minister tell us how a group of six hard working politicians, half of whom have been pre-empted already from using their own free will, can help the pensioners of this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Chipp says, it is true that we have an aging population. The proportion of the aged and other social security recipients in the community will increase and the proportion of taxpayers to support them will decrease. That is not only a fact of which Senator Chipp and all Government members are aware but also a fact which has been talked about in recent times by none other than Mr Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, the former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and many other members of the present Opposition parties. I would like to modify one thing that Senator Chipp said. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, said in his statement that on return to office the Liberal and National parties will repeal the legislation pertaining to the assets test, the changes in the taxation of superannuation lump sums and the means test for those over 70 years of age. He said that the coalition will repeal those three pieces of legislation. It will not amend or modify them but will repeal them. As Senator Chipp says, that means that in any investigation of the development of a comprehensive policy by the Opposition parties or in any investigation by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare the Liberal Party and National Party Opposition has in fact pre-empted those three options. That is an absolutely ludicrous and untenable situation.
—It might be a Fraser-type promise. You might not have to worry about it.

—It may be a Fraser-type promise. When Senator Messner came into this place on, I think, 25 August and gave notice of a motion in which he would ask the Senate to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare the matter of retirement incomes, he did so with considerable haste. He did so, I point out, without consulting the Chairman of that Committee, which is the usual practice. I said in the debate here that although it is not in my nature to attribute improper motives to members of the Opposition, I suspected that it might have been done for political purposes. It seems to me, now that the Leader of the Opposition has made his announcement about repealing this legislation, that in fact it may be more likely that it was done with political motives. Therefore, I have some concern about how the Senate Standing Committee can proceed in this matter, with so many of its members tied into another policy.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the establishment of a royal commission, I will certainly consider what Senator Chipp has suggested and I will ask the Government to consider it. At the moment I would not favour it, for this reason: We have had, first of all, in relatively recent times the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. That was a very broad inquiry into poverty, including poverty amongst retired people. We have had the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry. We have had the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, which took into account some aspects of this matter. Some aspects of retirement, particularly superannuation, were looked at by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I would have thought that we have enough information and enough comprehensive views from this community to proceed with a comprehensive policy to reform the present retirement system and lead up to a national superannuation scheme. That is why I said-I am pleased that the Australian Democrats said this also-that I did not see the referral of the matter to the Senate Standing Committee as necessarily pre-empting proper consideration of assets test legislation and other legislation. At this moment I do not see any need for a royal commission. I am disappointed that the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare apparently will be so restricted in its activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Further to the question asked yesterday by Senator Jones, has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims by the Queensland Premier that the Queensland Government alone could fund the Bradfield scheme? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the cost to Queensland taxpayers if this scheme were to go ahead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have heard of reports that the Queensland Premier has stated that Queensland alone would fund the scheme. As I said yesterday, in response to a similar question, had it been anyone other than the Queensland Premier I would not have accepted that those reports were accurate. There are two possibilities, I think, in assessing this proposal. One is that it is just a cheap political stunt cooked up for the Queensland State election, one similar to the cheap stunt cooked up by the discredited former Government when, in its death throes, it was running amok with the cheque book and promised to squander $5m of taxpayers' money on a further inquiry into the Bradfield scheme when the inquiry of Cameron McNamara Pty Ltd commissioned by the Queensland Government was already in existence.

ANSWER.PARA: That inquiry showed that the delivered cost per megalitre of water delivered to the target irrigation area would be 20 times as high as the delivered cost from the Burdekin. It also gave a number of other figures which are highly relevant to the question asked by Senator Giles. One was that the capital cost per irrigated hectare would be $23,000. High quality irrigation land in other parts of Australia sells for around $5,000 per hectare, or a little more perhaps in some cases. The inquiry showed that the capital cost would be $23,000 per hectare and the total cost $1,380m, which is $1,500 for every Queensland taxpayer. In addition, it can be assessed from the information in the Cameron McNamara report that there would be electricity costs for pumping the water of $ 57m a year and a total pumping cost, including electricity plus other charges, of $1,500 per hectare. That means that, in addition to the $1,500 which every Queensland taxpayer would have to provide initially for the capital for the scheme, they would then be lumbered in perpetuity with paying $120 a year a head . If the Queensland Premier is really serious about this proposal as distinct from resurrecting a cheap political stunt for purposes of the State election, it is perfectly clear that the only way in which that could be funded by Queensland alone is by imposing a massive second income tax in the State of Queensland. It is not possible in any other way to accommodate expenditure of that magnitude from State government revenue sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. We get used in this place to the odd dorothy dixer, particularly when an election is about to take place. One could be forgiven for being suspicious about this question. A Western Australian senator asked a detailed question about a Queensland matter. I suggest to you, Mr President, that you have a responsibility to other honourable senators in this place to discipline Ministers if they obviously abuse Question Time as this Minister is doing.

—In response to the point of order taken by Senator Chipp, I say that it is not for the Chair to interfere in the questions asked by honourable senators in respect of any part of Australia. So far as the Minister's answer is concerned, whilst the answer so far has been pertinent to the question that has been asked, I ask him to bear in mind the need for other honourable senators to ask questions and to bring his answer to a conclusion as soon as possible.

—I am very conscious of that, Mr President. I intend to conclude very shortly. I note in passing that there are no Queensland National Party senators in the chamber. If the proposal of the Queensland Premier, who has already saddled the State with a crippling debt, vastly in excess of the per capita debt of any other State, is to be taken seriously it should be viewed as an extension of the fiscal irresponsibility which has already landed Queensland in its ominous debt situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his response to my speech in the Senate last night. Referring to me, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . he chastised this Government about unemployment when this Government has been in office for only 5 1/2 months. He chastised this Government at a time when there is every sign that the alarming decline in employment has been halted .

I remind the Leader of the Government that his view last night was that the alarming decline in employment has been halted. Has he seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication on the labour force of Australia which was published today? Has he seen that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, between July and August employment decreased by 52,000, the number not in the labour force increased by 70,300, and the labour force participation rate decreased from 60.4 per cent to 59.8 per cent? I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: In light of the figures published today, does he persist in his view that the alarming decline in employment has been halted and does he persist in his view that the Government has satisfactorily come to grips with this problem?

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin with the last part of Senator Chaney's question. He asked me whether I regarded the effects of the Government's response to this issue as satisfactory. Of course I do not. Unemployment is an enormous problem in Australia in 1983 and the Government knows and has said publicly that it will continue to be so. Insofar as the ABS figures are concerned, I have not examined them in detail. A number of surveys, apart from those ABS figures, have been published recently and I think they are quite capable of leading me to say that, to quote Senator Chaney, the alarming decline in employment has been halted. I refer to the figures on registrations for unemployment benefit and I refer, for example, to the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd survey and the recent survey by the Victorian Chamber of Manufacturers, in support of that view . Senator Chaney, of course, is raising the question of a decline in the labour market participation rates. That is a matter about which I am not in a position to comment in detail at this stage, not having seen the figures. It is undoubtedly true that for a variety of reasons there has been a decline in those participation rates. I will undertake to examine the figures and give Senator Chaney a further answer in due course.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note that the Leader of the Government in the Senate does not regard a decline of 52,000 as alarming, but I ask him whether he agrees that a reduction in labour force participation rates of as much as 0.6 of one per cent in one month is a clear reason why there would be some evidence of a decline in the registered unemployed, and that that is the equivalent of an even greater rise in the number of those out of work in Australia.

—Yes, I concede that that may be so. If Senator Chaney understands the figures on the decline in the participation rates better than I do, I would be glad to hear about it. I have not examined the figures and I would like to have some detailed consideration of them before I make further comment on that decline, which is serious if the figures mentioned by Senator Chaney are correct.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. In the Sixty Minutes program on 31 July it was mentioned that over 10,000 scanners have been sold in Australia. These scanners are capable of listening in on police, fire brigade, aircraft, ships at sea, taxis and anyone else using a two-way radio, as well as car phone conversations. Is the Government giving any consideration to banning these scanners or licensing the same, and what, if any, other proposals are being considered by the Government on this question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the large number of scanners now available in Australia. As Senator Crowley gave me notice of her question, I sought information from the Minister for Communications. If the Opposition does not get too excited, I will read that out because it might be helpful in regard to Senator Crowley's concern about this matter. The Minister says that it is true that there is a cheap and widely available range of scanners in Australia at the moment as a result of advances in microprocessor technology. The sale and operation of these receivers for interception is not illegal except where the Telecom Australia mobile radio telephone service is involved. There is no point, as I understand it, in banning or licensing scanners. It is neither practical nor justified because many people, especially young people, find radio a fascinating hobby and learn from the use of scanners. It would be quite ineffective to pass a law making interception illegal, as such a law would be quite unenforceable. However, the Government is examining whether radio communications privacy legislation could be effective if it covered a technological solution to the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: The Sixty Minutes program performed a public service in making people realise that radio transmissions can be easily overheard and I am instructed that the Minister's Department is discussing with Telecom Australia the special case of the Telcom mobile phone system. Of course, in a sense, the Sixty Minutes program had a melodramatic quality to it and I think it is important to realise that, in today's technological society, using the spectrum is regarded by many people, particularly young people, as very much like using a public street. The simple fact of the matter is that if one speaks in the street one may expect to be overheard, and if one uses the radio spectrum one may perhaps expect to be overheard. Undesirable as that may appear to be, it seems to be a matter of fact .

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of a Press statement released on 21 June in which the Minister for Finance said 'most people get tiny lump sum settlements'. He also quoted figures which showed that in 1980-81, according to the latest available statistics, only one per cent of those who had the advantage of lump sum payments received more than $100,000; that 92 per cent received less than $ 20,000; and that three-quarters of those received less than $5,000. What sort of return of annuities would the Minister expect that $5,000 to bring?

—No, I am not aware of the statement issued by the Minister for Finance on 21 June but I will look it up for the honourable senator. I cannot guarantee the accuracy of the figures he has quoted, but they do not surprise me . Those figures are of lump sums which include termination payments for people who left jobs after a few years or at various other periods during their careers . The sort of annuity that one could buy for that size lump sum is very low, but consultations have been held between the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and various sections of those industries which will provide annuities, in order to come to satisfactory agreements for the future. I will pass on the question to the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer, whose responsibility it is to get an accurate answer to the sorts of questions the honourable senator has asked.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It refers to a recent report on government training and employment programs. The report has revealed that young unemployed people have the highest participation rate and have 10 times the chance of receiving assistance that older unemployed people have. As 53 per cent of all unemployed are in the over-25 age group, can the Minister advise what positive action can be taken to accommodate and cater for the needs of people in this age group?

—I have not seen the particular document to which Senator Elstob referred. The comment he made, which is derived from that document, is one which causes concern. It illustrates the difficult problem of a tendency to focus on those in certain age groups as fashionable recipients in the sense of their receiving particular attention in respect of their unemployment situation. In order that Senator Elstob might have a comprehensive answer to an important question, I will direct that question to my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for social insecurity. I refer to the Minister's reply to Senator Sir John Carrick yesterday in which he said, firstly, that the Government was not intending to apply any new rules governing the disposal of assets between now and the introduction of the assets test and, secondly, that the existing deprivation provisions would apply, they being that if people sold or gave away assets in order to qualify for the pension or related benefits they would be deemed to have retained those assets for the purposes of the test. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that under current provisions a pensioner may have unlimited assets, say $100,000, in non- interest bearing funds such as a trading bank without prejudicing current pension rights? Is it not a fact further that under current provisions a pensioner may spend those funds without prejudicing pension rights? What will be the position if such a pensioner in the period prior to the introduction of the assets test purchases jewellery, antiques, works of art, a boat, a caravan or other such personal possessions? Finally, I ask the Minister: If there are to be limitations, will he please spell out precisely what those limitations will be?

—In answering the last part of Senator Lewis's question-I will not try to match his brilliant Victorian wit-I say that if a person purchases jewellery or goes on a trip across Australia, in exchange for a sum of money, of course he will not be deemed to be avoiding the income test or the assets test; he never has been. I said that there was provision in the legislation for people who deliberately, in a manipulative way, hand over a sum of money to a relative, for instance, in exchange for nothing and who, in fact, have that money paid back to them bit by bit. That is deemed to be depriving themselves of an income. That was so under the old assets test and will be so under the new assets test. I will certainly obtain for Senator Lewis the legal details as to how the old assets test operated. I will give Senator Lewis and this Parliament, when they are finalised, the exact details of what we consider to be deprivation or not under the new assets test. We are talking about gross deprivation of assets or income. I assure Senator Lewis and every pensioner in this country that that will not apply-it never has-to someone who actually purchases something and gets , in exchange for a given amount of money, goods equivalent thereto. In other words we are not, as was suggested by an Opposition spokesman, as reported in one newspaper a couple of days ago, suggesting at any stage that if, for instance, someone goes on a trip in exchange for money he will be deemed to have been depriving himself of income or assets.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, spoke at three businessmen's luncheons after the announcement of the election date and that the total cost of those dinners was approximately $24,000 ? Is it further a fact that this $24,000 was paid for by the Australian taxpayer and not by the Liberal Party of Australia? Will the Minister investigate this matter and report back to the Senate?

—I have heard some sordid suggestions of that kind. As a result, I will ensure that the matter is investigated by the appropriate Minister, who I assume is the Special Minister of State, although it may be the Minister for Administrative Services, and bring back such information as I can to the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Minister acknowledge that so far he has given three different estimates of the revenue gain to the Government from the imposition of an assets test? Does he recall telling the Senate on 25 August that the figure was about $ 200m, which had increased to some $300m by Question Time yesterday and which then fell to some $250m by the time of the Minister's interview on Nationwide last night? When will the Minister provide a firm or consistent figure? Is not this financial vagary just another example of the ad hockery which has typified the Government's confused approach to this very sensitive area?

—I have stated quite clearly in this place that to give an actual dollar figure of what will be saved is not possible because we have no real idea , since the assets test was abolished, of the exact asset holdings of people likely to be affected. The best estimate, from the Department of Social Security is between $200m and $250m and I understand that the Department of Veterans' Affairs estimates a further amount of more than $50m. If I am wrong Senator Gietzelt can talk about it. When I spoke about $250m to $300m I believe-I think the record shows this-I was talking about the amount of money saved by both my Department and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If it will make Senator Crichton-Browne sleep any better at night, I will say that the estimate is between $200m and $300m. I do not pretend that that is an accurate estimate. It is probably as accurate as some of the estimates made about the products of some mining activities in Western Australia.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister: In that case why, on three separate occasions, has he given three separate figures which varied by a hundred million dollars?

—The three separate figures which worry Senator Crichton-Browne were, I think, $200m approximately, which was the lower estimate by the Department of Social Security; between $200m and $250m, which was again, on another occasion, an estimate of the Department; and between $250m and $300m which, if Senator Crichton-Browne looks at the record, he will see was a combined estimate by my Department and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If this is a matter of great moment and causes Senator Crichton-Browne not to sleep , I apologise. I do not think it is of great moment to most reasonable people in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer . A statement from the Local Government Association of South Australia in yesterday's Adelaide News stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government had broken an election promise with its reduced funding for local government.
Has the Minister seen that statement? What funds are provided in the 1983 Budget for local government? What further initiatives does the Government propose in respect of local government financing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to that report. Of course, it is not correct that any election undertaking about local government funding has been broken. Commonwealth payments to local government come from a number of sources, the best known, probably, being the income tax sharing arrangements. There has been a small but, nevertheless, real increase in funds provided to local government under those income tax sharing arrangements in this financial year as compared with the previous year. Senator Archer asked a question about that yesterday.
—This is an identical question and should be ruled out of order.

—It is not the same question at all. Funds are also provided under a number of other Commonwealth programs. In total, this financial year payments to local government will be increased by $307m, which represents a 45 per cent increase on payments in the previous year. The Minister for Territories and Local Government announced last month that there would be a comprehensive inquiry into the funding of local government. That is one of the additional initiatives which the Government has in mind. In closing, I say that the reason the tax sharing related payments to local government increased at a slower rate than in the previous year is, of course, directly attributable to the enormous depression which the previous Government inflicted upon the country and a consequential decline in taxation revenue, those payments being directly related to such revenue. For example, in the year ended June, real gross domestic product fell by 3.9 per cent as against the previous June. That sort of shrinkage, that sort of contraction of the economy, which incidentally was the only full year contraction in the economy since the depression of 1961, the only full year in 22 years in which there was a real decline in GDP-a decline of nearly 4 per cent-had very substantial influences on tax revenue and therefore on payments to local government from the Commonwealth under the tax sharing arrangements in this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: I stress again that there has been a 45 per cent increase in total payments from the Commonwealth to local government in 1983-84 as against 1982-83. In view of a number of disturbing pieces of information that have come to the attention of the Government, in particular the degree to which some State governments have progressively reduced their funding to local government as the Commonwealth has accepted a greater responsibility in that area, and for other reasons, the Government has decided and the Minister for Territories and Local Government has announced that a comprehensive review of the financing of local government will be undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the fact that Australian wine is exempt from sales tax. Is the Minister aware that the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation has decided that wine produced from Australian tropical fruits is not exempt from sales tax? Can the Minister give any reason for such a decision? Will the Government support an amendment to the Sales Tax Act when it next comes before the Senate so that Australian tropical fruit wine can be placed on a par with grape wine?

—I am not sure whether Senator Macklin is proposing that the Government should move to impose a sales tax on wine or to remove the sales tax which has been applied to drinks produced from tropical fruits, apparently by a discretionary decision made by the Commissioner of Taxation in interpreting the Act. I will refer the question to the Treasurer. I add that some people might see the discretionary decision of the Commissioner as being anomalous with the application of taxation rules in other areas. I do not propose to pass judgment on that. I do add that there are a number of anomalies in the sales tax and other taxation Acts and that this Government, although it has been in office for less than six months, has already moved to remove a number of those anomalies. I will convey the question to the Treasurer for consideration by the Government at some future time.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to the editorial in the June 1983 issue of the New South Wales edition of the Business Bulletin? Was there any justification for the editorial heading: 'Don't Buy Australian Says Federal Government'? Has the abolition of the tax rebate on the first $1,000 of dividend income had the dire effects predicted by the Business Bulletin?
