—I do not think it would be fair to say that the publication to which Senator Colston has referred is disreputable, but it is an inconsequential publication and the conclusion it reached is absolutely wrong. The Government, in making its decision to remove the pre-election stunt cooked up between them by the discredited former Treasurer and Prime Minister, that is, to exempt from income tax the first $1,000 of dividend income--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister began answering the question with a quite defamatory remark against the publication referred to, and under the cover of privilege. He then went on to refer in his usual way to the previous Government. He has wasted a great deal of this Question Time and I ask you to call him to order, Mr President.
—I ask the Minister to make his replies short and to the point because a number of people want to ask questions. I believe that the Minister is not out of order in his remarks to date.

—That was one of the decisions announced by the Government in the May statement. I was directly associated with that decision and I certainly do not resile from it at all. Of course it has not had the dire consequences which this inconsequential publication claims that it has. It was one of those measures which the Government took in the knowledge that hidden expenditures, which have come to be known as tax expenditures, of the type which proliferated under the previous Government were enormously costly to the revenue and therefore imposed greater tax burdens on all pay as you earn taxpayers. As an industry assistance measure or an investment incentive measure it was also quite ineffective. For all of those reasons-that it was inequitable, that it was ineffective in achieving its stated purpose, and that the Government had inherited a chaotic financial situation from its predecessor-the May decision was made and has been completely justified.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing both the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence. I refer to a proposal made recently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, that Australian defence forces should begin to make their presence felt on the western reaches of the Indian Ocean, along the east coast of Africa. How does the Government reconcile the Foreign Minister's proposals with the cuts that have been announced in the Budget for the joint defence exercise, known as Kangaroo '83, off the Pilbara region of the Western Australian coast? Would not the increased expense involved in the proposal for a presence in the western region of the Indian ocean prejudice the already great necessity for increasing defence resources on the other side of the Indian Ocean, namely, the west coast of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In raising the question of Australia's policy towards the Indian Ocean area the Foreign Minister did take pains to emphasise that Australia had key interests involved in that region. Activities there by Australia, whether in the form of aid or naval visits or at the diplomatic level , clearly need to reflect in an organised way our own independent role as a major littoral country. We can do this, as Mr Hayden emphasised and despite what Senator Durack has said, with only modest expenditure. We can increase our capacity to exert influence in this very important region, which is contiguous to Australia, without spending a great many dollars.

ANSWER.PARA: The point made by Mr Hayden in addressing himself to this issue is that Australia, while acting in its own self-interest, would also be playing a valuable role in support of broader Western objectives in an area which is of vital concern because of its oil producing capacity, its trade routes and its potential obviously to threaten international peace and security. Australian naval visits to Indian Ocean countries have been taking place for a number of years. It is the view of this Government that those visits are well regarded and do serve a valuable foreign policy purpose. Subject to financial considerations- we will certainly be taking into account the sorts of points Senator Durack has made-and subject to further discussions within the Government, it is the view of the Government at the moment that such deployment should continue in a manner which is consistent with Australia's broader objectives in the region.

Similarly, it is the view of the Government that there is scope for us to sharpen the focus of our aid effort to east Africa and to the island states of the Indian Ocean. Australia has a number of important interests in this area which justify this concern. The position that Australia has taken and our support for arms limitation and nuclear non-proliferation indicate that. As Mr Hayden has indicated, we would support the convening of a conference to discuss the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace should a consensus emerge at the United Nations. For all these reasons and in that context I believe, and the Government believes, that the emphasis that Mr Hayden has given to this issue should be understood by the Opposition rather than being subjected to the kind of sniping we have just had from Senator Durack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney- General has not answered the specific point I made. How can this added expenditure, which he concedes may be modest, be reconciled with the cuts in the Budget for Kangaroo '83?

—Nothing that Senator Durack has said in any way detracts from the force of the propositions I was advancing. Kangaroo '83 is to be perceived as a totally separate exercise. It has to be justified and the expenditure for it has to be justified in its own terms in the Australian defence effort. We are talking here about foreign policy initiatives, some of which would involve naval visits in the whole of the Indian Ocean area. Senator Durack might perceive a connection that exercises his brain cells and hormones but it is not one that moves me.
—I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Having risen in my place for four days straight without having been called-
—I did six days once.
—Some of us get a most curious feeling in this place. I want to know on what basis questions are being called in this House when one has to go for four days without being called.

—I have seen people rise and I have given the call to them as they have risen. I have also given the call in relation to the number of questions that honourable senators have asked previously. I know that Senator Missen is in that category as are others but a time limit is involved and I cannot do anything about that. Senator Missen's problem today will be taken into account in any future calls.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chaney asked a question of both Senator Walsh and myself concerning the progress on discussions relating to the seabed boundary between Indonesia and Australia in the light of the recent oil find at the Jabiru No. 1 well. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following information which I now give to the honourable senator and to the Senate.

QUESTION.PARA: Sea bed boundary agreements with Indonesia were signed by Australia in 1971 and 1972. These agreements determined the boundary in the Arafura Sea and in the area south of West Timor. The boundary further west was left for later talks. A gap was also left in the boundary south of what was then Portuguese Timor. Before a boundary agreement could be reached with Portugal, East Timor was incorporated into Indonesia.

Between 1979 and October 1981 four rounds of discussions were held between Indonesia and Australian officials to consider, amongst other things, drawing a boundary in the area of what has become known as the Timor Gap. However, these discussions were inconclusive. We are ready to hold further rounds of discussions as soon as the Indonesian side is ready.

I understand that the Jabiru No. 1 well is located on the Australian continental shelf to the south of, that is, on the Australian side of, the 1972 agreed seabed boundary with Indonesia. Indeed, Senator Walsh made that point yesterday. It is therefore to the west of the Timor Gap area, and should not be relevant to the continuing discussions on the Timor Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I add one additional fact to what Senator Evans has stated. As I said yesterday, the Jabiru well is outside the disputed area. I have since been advised that it is some 200 kilometres from the disputed area.
—There is a renewed interest in the whole area of exploration.
—Yes, several.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Martin asked a question relating to an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald commenting on the proposed appointment of Phillip Adams to the Australian Film Commission. I am now in a position to provide the following information in answer to Senator Martin's question: Sir James Cruthers, the present Chairman of the Australian Film Commission, has indicated to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment his intention to resign from that position. In the light of this, the Government is considering the appointment of his replacement. Honourable senators will be aware that the appointment of the Chairman of the Australian Film Commission requires Executive Council approval and it would be therefore improper to make any comment prior to the Council's approval. I assure honourable senators that no consultation has taken place between Mr Adams and this Government regarding recent amendments to the taxation incentives provided for the Australian film industry.

QUESTION.PARA: Turning to Senator Martin's other specific question, the answers are, seriatim, no, no, yes and in part.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Reports

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922 I present the annual reports of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for 1982-83, the Department of the Parliamentary Library for the period 1 January 1982 to 30 June 1983 and the Joint House Department for 1982-83. The reports which I have just presented on the operations of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department for the year ended 30 June 1983 have been required by the Public Service Acts Amendment Act 1982.

INTERJECT.PARA: Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff

The Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff has provided a reliable service throughout the year, not only to the two Houses of the Parliament but also to parliamentary committees. The Department continues to be involved in studies being undertaken for the establishment of an information storage and retrieval system for the Parliament. Computer technology and its application to parliamentary reporting are under close study by the Department with the prospect of improved services to members of parliament in the near future.
Department of the Parliamentary Library

The Library's report is in two parts. The first, reports on activities in 1982 and completes a series of calendar year annual reports which commenced in 1978. The second section reports on the period January to June 1983 and contains a number of statistical tables expressed in financial year periods which will be the form used in future years. Demand for research and information services from senators and members continued at a high level during the period covered by the report. Planning for the New Parliament House and the introduction of new technology is being actively pursued and is likely to lead to a period of change for the Library which will be reflected in the years ahead.

I take this opportunity to draw the attention of honourable senators to the retirement of Mrs Bobbie Sluyters in June of this year on medical grounds. Mrs Sluyters had worked in the Parliamentary Library for nearly 20 years and gained wide respect from senators and members. Her name is particularly associated with the Current Information Service and her energy and helpfulness to senators and members deserves to be noted. I know that honourable senators would wish me to express on their behalf our best wishes to Mrs Sluyters for a recovery in her health and a happy retirement.
Joint House Department

I am also pleased to table the first annual report prepared on the operations of the Joint House Department. As well as providing services for this provisional Parliament House the Joint House Department is involved, to a significant extent, in the planning and development of services and facilities for the new Parliament House and references to those responsibilities occur throughout the report. I commend these reports to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 September 1983, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was called on yesterday there was some comment on it from Senator Harradine, Senator Macklin and me. I had only a short time to comment on it and wanted to add a few words. I propose to do so now. I was opening up the fundamental problem that has been revealed to us by the decision of the High Court of Australia in the Tasmanian dam case. That case has now fully revealed, I think for the first time, the enormous Executive power which is held by the Commonwealth Governemnt in its negotiations for and ratification of treaties. Under our system of government, following the British precedent, it has always been traditional that treaties are a matter for the Executive Government and not for the legislature. By and large that worked quite satisfactory when the domestic implementation of treaties, or the power to implement them in domestic law, was used very carefully and cautiously.

SPEECH.PARA: But in view of the situation revealed in and the history of the Tasmanian dam case, it is now quite clear that the power to enter into treaties enables the Executive Government to arrogate to itself enormous new powers, powers which it adds to the legislature. In other words, by the Executive act the Federal legislature gains tremendously new powers at the expense of State parliaments. The problem that we can have is that, by entering into treaties without reservations in regard to the powers of State parliaments and without regard to other limitations in the Constitution of Commonwealth powers, an international obligation is entered into. It is clear from the High Court decision that it takes a very broad and generous view of what is an obligation under international law. I would have thought there were very serious doubts about whether the particular treaty in the Tasmanian Dam case did create such obligations, but the High Court held that it did. Therefore, the power of this Parliament is pre-empted. When the Government has entered into treaties and acquired those obligations it can come into this Parliament and say: 'Look, we have this international obligation and we are required to give effect to it'. Therefore we should use this constitutional power that we now have and give effect to it. It can do that despite the fact that there could be a very considerable change in the traditional balance of power under the Federal system .

It is clear that this Parliament now has to take a much closer interest in negotiations for treaties, certainly before they are ratified, and also in the question of ratification. The time has come when new and greater interest by the Parliament is required. We will have to give a lot more thought to it. I know that Senator Harradine has already proposed a parliamentary committee and is talking about introducing a Bill. I hope that honourable senators will take a very live and close interest in proposals to do something about this very serious situation which has arisen as a result of the Tasmanian dam case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to be speaking today because I must admit that, if I had had to speak yesterday, I would have been very short of breath after Senator Durack's contribution yesterday in which he criticised the Government for giving information but not giving enough. In fact, in the previous Parliament, we only had a one-line operation. I find it very difficult to sit here and listen to some of the hypocritical statements made about what goes on in this place when one considers what happened under previous governments. However, I believe that there ought to more material. I have taken some interest in this because of concern in the community. I have done some totalling up and so far have found that under the Fraser Government-my survey is not yet complete-105 bilateral treaties and 92 multilateral treaties were signed and ratified. Not once during all that time was there any noise from members of the then Government about treaties having to come to this Parliament. I support very strongly-
—For heaven's sake be honest.

—Senator Walters had her chance when in government and did absolutely nothing. She is making a statement again. She makes pious statements in opposition but said nothing while in government. The Parliament ought to have more say about treaties. I for one believe that the Senate ought to have an integral role similar to that of the Senate in the United States of America. I refer not so much to bilateral treaties because most of those are at a level of operationalising policies in terms of double taxation and other administrative details. But I believe that the multilateral treaties are of distinct importance in policy terms to this Parliament. I believe that the tradition of their having been exclusively the role of the Executive Government ought to cease and that they ought to become part of the legislative role. However, that will have to be a developing debate in this country and I am pleased to see, for whatever reason , that that debate has started. I hope it will be constructive so far as the type of role the Parliament can contribute to policy making in these areas is concerned. I hope we will not have a reiteration of the types of statements made already about this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly about what has been said because I think perhaps it is less than an accurate description of the history. Details of international treaties and conventions entered into by Australia have been made known to the Senate and the detail of such treaties and conventions have been available to honourable senators to debate. What has now happened is a desirable further development. For the convenience of honourable senators, a summary is provided and this saves them the time of reading the original treaty in order to be able to sort it out. I do not think it is fair to criticise the former Government for failing to make information available when in fact, without any obligation on it to do so, it followed the principles of, firstly, consultation with the States on any treaty before entering into it and, secondly, of tabling in the Senate, as a Senate procedure, information of the fact of the treaty or convention and the document itself so that it could be made the subject matter of debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the idea of further consideration and debate of treaties and I think we are processing a desirable development. I would like to see the process taken considerably further, but that is a personal view which may be shared by some honourable senators and not by others. In the light of what Senator Macklin said , I make the comment that, while agreeing with his general principle of more discussion about these matters, I do not think he was entirely fair either to the previous Government or, in particular, to the former Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only because of the complete inaccuracy and unjust remarks of Senator Macklin. I agree that more consultation should take place. Senator Macklin accused us of not having said anything when we were in government. That was purely and simply because at no stage did our Government ever attempt to usurp the powers of the States as has the present Government.
—It signed the treaty on conventions.

—Of course it did, but it did not take Tasmania to the High Court of Australia. The previous Government said that it would never use the external affairs powers. It said that if our State wanted to dam the Franklin then it could dam the Franklin. It did not use the external affairs powers. It used the external powers on exports. It has never used the external affairs powers as the High Court has now interpreted. For Senator Macklin to stand there and misrepresent the former Government in the way he did is nothing short of hypocritical.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Government are trying to ridicule this.
—Oh!
—Senator Grimes will know that the feeling in Tasmania has not abated. Senator Grimes was not game to have a public meeting in Queenstown. He took his leader down there.
—Senator Walters, you are getting away from the subject.

—I am talking about the treaty that took away the State powers. I am merely pointing out that the result of the Government's usurping the powers of our State has landed the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, in a situation where, when he took his Leader down to the west coast of Tasmania last week, he was not game to have a public meeting. He was not game to go out on the Crotty Road to visit the men doing the work. He slunk in and walked up the streets. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was kissed by three women in Queenstown and we were told that this was a warm welcome. The people of Queenstown kept off the streets. The only people who did appear wore black arm bands. The Warden invited the people along to a reception, the majority of whom refused the invitation. The ones who did go wore black arm bands. Senator Grimes says that I am incorrect in saying that the feeling in Tasmania is still very high on this issue. He knows darned well that he is not game to go down the west coast or call a public meeting. He is not game to go out on the Crotty Road, nor is Senator Tate nor are any of the other Tasmanian senators in the Government. We have only to look at the popularity of the Government in Tasmania at the moment to know that if an election were held now we would not have one honourable senator from Tasmania sitting in the Government.
—Before calling the Attorney-General I remind him that I have allowed a wide-ranging debate to take place. I would be grateful if he would return to the subject of treaties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have every desire to return to the sober consideration of the matter which is before us; that is, the way in which this Parliament should deal with treaties. I rise for one purpose only, that is, to scotch the canard which is running once again in this place that something dramatically new happened to our constitutional law with the decision in the Tasmanian dams case so far as the external affairs power is concerned. The truth of the matter-for anyone with an ounce of literacy and understanding of Australian constitutional laws-is that since 1936 and the Burgess case it has been perfectly clear that the external affairs power will be construed by the High Court of Australia, in an appropriate case, to enable the Parliament to legislate for the domestic implementation within Australia of an international treaty obligation. That much has been clear.
—You tell that to Justice Gibbs.

—If Senator Walters did Mr Justice Gibbs the courtesy of reading his judgment she would clearly appreciate that Mr Justice Gibbs has acknowledged that that is and ever has been the state of the law, at least since 1936 when it was clearly articulated by the High Court. There is a question as to how far the external affairs power reaches, but there is unanimity in the High Court. Since the 1930s that power has been available, in an appropriate case, where there is a genuine international obligation. Equally, there is unanimity in the High Court that treaties cannot be used as a mere device, artificially, to attract legislative power to the Commonwealth in situations where that power would otherwise be lacking. It is a matter of looking clearly and carefully at the treaty obligation in each case to determine whether it is a genuine external obligation for Australia. That principle was articulated as far back as the 1930s. That principle was affirmed in the Koowarta case last year and in the dams case this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Successive governments of all stripes and colours have from time to time relied upon the external affairs power as sole or supplementary legislative support for important pieces of legislation. When, in 1975, the Labor Government introduced the Racial Discrimination Act based on the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, it was not opposed by the then Opposition on any ground associated with the use of the external affairs power. In fact, that legislation was passed finally unanimously by this chamber. There have been plenty of instances of legislation being passed in the last seven years in which there has been a reliance on the treaty power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Narcotics is one example.

—Narcotics is one example, and there is legislation about migratory birds, certain technical and scientific matters of one kind or another and environmental matters. There is no fundamental point of principle in issue here. There might be between individuals in this place, but certainly not as between the major parties in terms of their performace over the years. The hysterical nonsense that is peddled and perpetrated by people such as Senator Durack, who ought to know better, is, I believe, to be deplored.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Labor Government's exercise of the power available to it under section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution will only be exercised, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I and others said in the aftermath of the dams case, sensibly and responsibly and in situations where there is both genuine domestic need for national legislation and where there are genuine international obligations which Australia must meet. We will exercise that power with due regard to those considerations-the international obligations and the reality of those obligations-and we will exercise it with due regard to domestic political sensitivities. We do not propose, and never have proposed, to use the external affairs power or the existence of treaty arrangements as a vehicle to stampede around the country doing things for which there is no justification other than a desire for legislative aggrandisement by the Commonwealth. Finally, I believe that our good faith in this respect and our desire to have openly and overtly on the table the details of the treaty arrangements into which we are entering is demonstrated by the way in which, for the first time in detail, the character of those treaty arrangements has been brought to the attention of the Parliament in the way in which the tabling has been brought forward on this occasion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT BILL 1982 [1983]
In Committee
Consideration resumed from 21 October 1982.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw the amendment moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) when the Committee last considered the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, Clause 3, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Restriction on operation of retail sites
''3. Section 10 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of sub- section (3):

'and if the corporation does not take advantage of the power it has, in relation to the market for the retail sale of motor fuel, for the purpose of eliminating or substantially damaging a person, being a competitor in that market of the corporation or its agents or of a body corporate related to the corporation'.''
The Government believes it would be pre-emptive to proceed with the amendment at this time given the nature of an inquiry that is being undertaken to which I will refer in more detail in my speech.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will remember that on 23 September last year I introduced a private member's Bill to amend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Act so that petroleum companies would be precluded by law from selling petrol at retail outlets. I remind the Senate that the companies involved are mostly multinationals-Amoco, Ampol, BP, Caltex, Esso, Mobil, Shell and H. C. Sleigh. The Bill passed the second reading and was in consideration by the Committee when the debate adjourned. At the time of the adjournment the present Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, as spokesman then for the Opposition, had moved an amendment which had the effect of negating my moves to ban petroleum companies retailing petrol and, instead, imposed the condition that companies, if they were to have assess to retail sites, not abuse their potential power in the market-place to damage other retailers. My Bill was not debated again before the election of 5 March. Through the forms of the Senate I was able to re-place the Bill on the Notice Paper at the stage reached upon the double dissolution of the Parliament-namely, second reading passed and in Committee, with Senator Evans's amendment, which Senator Tate has now removed, before the Committee. The Bill, minus Senator Evans's amendment, is now before the Senate. Because of the effluxion of time it is necessary for me to move, as an amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, leave out 'and before 1 January 1983', insert 'and before 1 January 1984'.

In moving this amendment I wish to remind the Senate of the effect that my Bill will have on the petroleum retailing industry. The effect of this Bill, with the new amendment, would be that after 1 January 1984 no exceptions to the overriding section 10 (i) would be permitted. That section states:
A prescribed corporation-
that means a petrol company-
shall not operate a retail site.

The history of this is that towards the end of 1980 the then Liberal Government introduced its petroleum retail marketing legislation but reneged on its undertaking, its firm promise, of 30 October 1978, when the so-called Fife package was announced-that oil companies would be prohibited from retailing petroleum through direct sales sites. The then Government decided that total divorcement was not necessary to achieve its objectives and that a reduction of about 50 per cent over a two year period in the number of retailing sites would be adequate. It has never been satisfactorily explained to me why a firm undertaking by a Liberal Government, that given on 30 October 1978, should have been changed a few months later almost 180 degrees the opposite way. There have been rumours of oil company executives boasting about how they got at the Liberal Government and of multinational oil company executives indicating that they were able to change the Liberal Party's mind and achieve that 180 degree about-face. However, there has been no satisfactory explanation from the Liberal Party of its change of mind on this issue.

Each integrated oil group was allocated a quota of sites. The maximum number of company owned sites allowed under the 1980 legislation was 989 for the year beginning 19 September 1981. On 18 May 1983 this was reduced to 401 sites. The present Government amended the petroleum retail marketing sites regulations on 17 May 1983. The effect of this was to extend the current situation so that the number of sites will not be reduced to 401 until 1 January next. It is remarkable how political parties seem to accede, for reasons never stated, to the wishes of the multinational oil companies. The objection of the Australian Democrats is that that is always at the expense of the independent Australian owner, thousands of whom have been sent bankrupt by the multinational oil companies in the last five years.

I understand that the entire structure of the industry is now being studied by an informal committee within the Department of Industry and Commerce and that a report will be forthcoming about the end of this year. There has already been a royal commission on the petroleum retailing industry, which released its findings in 1976. As a result of that report the then Liberal Government believed it was absolutely imperative to get multinational oil companies out of the retailing business so that they could allow the Australian battler some chance of survival. But oil company representations seem to make stronger impressions on political parties in this country than do royal commissions. Further studies of the industry will be of some value, but look at it as much as we will, the basic problem remains the same. The solution is offered to the Senate in the legislation before it with my current amendment included.

The problem is the pre-eminent involvement of the major oil companies in petrol retailing. The existing legislation only goes half way. Oil companies are still involved at every level of output from production to retail sales. The oil companies are doing very well and are very happy with the existing arrangement. I ask members of the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the independent senator here today, to contemplate the fate of the Australian independently owned service stations if the multinational oil companies are so extraordinarily happy with the existing legislation. The Democrats say that the only solution is to get oil companies out of petrol retailing. It is a solution that both the Liberal and the Labor parties in Queensland apparently endorse. Before I proceed, I challenge speakers from the Liberal and Labor parties who will follow me, because their remarks will be given the widest publicity in the Queensland media. A fascinating item appeared in yesterday's Courier-Mail:
The Liberal Party had stolen Labor Party policies dealing with oil companies operating retail petrol outlets, the State Opposition--
the Labor Party-

small business spokesman, Mr Milliner, said yesterday. Mr Milliner said the promise by the Liberal Leader, Mr White, to clean up the service station industry had been Labor Party policy for some time.

I ask Senator Tate, who is to follow me, to explain whether it is Labor Party policy to get oil companies out of the retail business or is Mr Milliner, its State spokesman, telling lies? I believe it is an explanation not only the Senate but also the Queensland people ought to be given. The article continues:
'The about-turn by the Liberals on this is amazing,' Mr Milliner said. 'If they were so concerned, why didn't they do something about it when they were in government?'
That is a fair question. The article continued:
Mr Milliner said that just before the 1980 election, Mr White had addressed a meeting of service station proprietors in Brisbane where he promised to clean up the mess.
'But he forgot about it after the election,' Mr Milliner said.

'If the Liberals have not been able to achieve anything on a state level, why had they not approached the former Federal Liberal Government to implement the findings of the Royal Commission on Petroleum?

I ask Senator Peter Rae, who will follow me for the Liberal Party in this matter , whether he or his Party has been approached by Mr White to clean up this mess, as Mr White promised in 1980. Mr Milliner is reported as concluding:
'It is Labor Party policy to free the operators from the restriction imposed on them by the oil companies.'

This statement was made yesterday. Was Mr Milliner stating current Labor Party policy or not? I will not be impressed with Labor Party opposition to this private member's Bill on the ground that there is an informal inquiry and that we must wait until it is made public. As I said, we had a royal commission in 1976. This matter has been under intense study. One does not need an informal Public Service inquiry, which is a rather strange way of doing things, to elicit the truth about whether an injustice is being done to independent service station operators. The main reason why I believe the explanation, or the excuse, of relying on that informal inquiry should not be accepted is that we have already had a leak, either from that committee, from a public servant on that committee, from someone in the Minister's office, or from the Minister himself. I draw the attention of the Committee to an article entitled 'Revamp of petrol retailing likely', written by Ian Perkin and appearing on page 1 of the Weekend Australian of 3-4 September. The article states:

Because the Department of Industry and Commerce committee has yet to complete its report, the likely restructuring recommendations are not known, but they are expected to include: A further reduction in the number of company-owned and operated services stations-the largest stations which dominate trading in most major capitals.

I have an unbounded admiration for Senator Tate, but surely this is a matter to which a Minister should be able to respond. I want Senator Tate's advisers to give him an answer to a question. Did the Department leak information to the Weekend Australian that a likely recommendation of the committee would be for a further reduction in the number of company-owned and operated service stations rather than a phasing out, as well as three other suggested recommendations? The Government might say: 'Wait. Let us hold up this Democrat Bill until we have that report'. I would like to know now from the advisers to the Minister, through Senator Tate, whether in fact that is going to be one of the recommendations and why it was leaked. We will be pressing this matter to a vote today to ascertain how fair dinkum the Australian Labor Party is about removing multinationals from petrol station sites, and how fair dinkum the Liberal Party is. This Bill will ensure that the lessee operators and independent retailers are given a fair go in the future, that full competition is retained in retail petroleum markets, and that small business people are protected from the predatory pricing actions of the big oil companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the opposition of the Government to the passage of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill introduced by Senator Chipp. I think it is necessary briefly to outline the history of the matter. It has to be conceded that the previous Government introduced its petroleum marketing legislation in 1980-honourable senators will recall that the package of legislation was made up of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act-after a very careful consideration of the problems confronting the petroleum retail industry. That legislation was not hastily brought into this chamber. It was a result of careful consideration of the many matters to which Senator Chipp has quite rightly adverted. The sites Act required the major oil companies to effect a reduction of approximately 50 per cent in the number of direct retail outlets that they operated at 30 May 1980. This was substantially completed by September 1982. The amendment that Senator Chipp proposes would have the effect of bringing about total divorcement of oil companies from petrol retailing, and that would be a fundamental change to the intention and effect of the sites Act. It was quite clear at the time--
—It was promised, though.

—I understand, of course, that at the time of the passage of that 1980 package of legislation some degree of divorcement was considered necessary for the sorts of reasons that Senator Chipp has outlined. The trend towards vertical integration in the petrol retailing industry had caused concern due to its effect on independent small business in the industry. There was concern that increased vertical integration would have long term anti-competitive effects. The then Government was conscious that some oil companies might unjustifiably react to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act by converting outlets from franchisee operation to company operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision as to the level of divorcement then incorporated in the legislation was to some extent arbitrary. Of course, it was decided that a target of 50 per cent would be set. It was a question of deciding on a level which would achieve the then Government's objectives with the minimum practicable degree of intervention in the industry. The previous Government, I understand, did not believe that the complete divorcement of major oil companies from the direct operation of service stations was either necessary or desirable. It considered that the restriction of oil companies to a small number of sites in proportion to total site numbers would prevent any danger of excessive vertical integration or market power. At the same time, a possibly pro- competitive element is retained in the interests of consumers.

In opposition we did not oppose the introduction of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act with its provision for 50 per cent divorcement. The divorcement decided upon in 1980 was phased in. Some companies had to convert the method of operation of a large number of sites. This needed to be done in an orderly and efficient manner and without disturbing existing contractual arrangements. But one major difficulty in the legislation has come to light. The Act has a wider than intended application to oil company agent operated depots where some fuel is retailed at the site. Pending amendment of the legislation to rectify this problem, the previous Government, as an interim measure and to avoid disruption in the industry, increased company site allocations to take account of depots. The increase is solely due to the need of companies to have quota cover for depots. The present Government has continued this practice pending amendment of the legislation, and I emphasise that.

On 18 May of this year, and I think that this is of concern to Senator Chipp, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, announced a limited review of the petroleum retail marketing legislation following a pre-election commitment by the Government. The review is aimed at amending the legislation to clarify its operation and to overcome certain problems which have arisen. I think I can provide, insofar as it is within my power, an answer to Senator Chipp's question. Certainly the article from which he quoted purporting to indicate that recommendations had already been decided upon in relation to the outcome of that review is a total and absolute fabrication and certainly the information was not given to the reporter concerned by officials of the department most closely concerned in this matter. Apart from that part of the article which speaks of the undertaking of this review, the rest is a figment of the imagination of the author. The fact is that officials from the Department are in the process-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling me that that is not true?

—I am telling the honourable senator that it is untrue insofar as it purports to indicate that recommendations on a wide range of matters have already been decided upon by the Government and that the review, therefore, is of scope and character other than was indicated on 18 May by Senator Button. Officials from the department are even now in the process of consultation. They are consulting with the oil companies, certainly, but they are also consulting with operators of retail outlets, State government departments and other interested parties. All those who will be affected by this legislation should be consulted, and that process is being undertaken now. In the course of that review information on the effectiveness of the provisions of the existing legislation, including the level of divorcement, is being examined. Surely Senator Chipp will concede that it is quite proper, quite ordinary, common even, for a government within the first six months of taking office to make its own assessment, and its own review, of the state of the industry, the impact of the present legislation on that industry, and on the basis of a thorough review, having made its own assessment, then to come into the Parliament with its considered response to the situation. This matter will be brought back to the Parliament on the basis of the Government ensuring that a satisfactory balance is struck and maintained between the interests of consumers, service station franchisees, owner-operators, and the oil companies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government opposes Senator Chipp's amendment on the simple grounds that it believes it would be quite unreasonable to proceed in an arbitrary fashion before the review is finalised and without full consideration being given to the facts that might emerge in the course of that review. The effects of full divorcement on oil prices to consumers is subject to controversy. That is something we would have to be very aware of in coming to any final conclusions. I think also that Senator Chipp pointed out in the course of his remarks-it is very relevant-that excluding depots, which I referred to earlier, oil companies currently operate some 400 retail outlets out of a total of some 11,000 service stations in this country. We are not speaking of a large number. There has already been a very effective reduction in the numbers. Currently only 400 out of some 11,000 service stations in this country are operated by the oil companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that has helped the oil companies not hindered them, at the expense of the small person.

—The oil companies opposed even that reduction in their retail site allocation. As I said, this occurred against the then wishes of the oil companies in 1980. In any case, I am trying to put in perspective that only 400 retail sites out of 11,000 service stations are currently operated by oil companies. On this basis, the proposed amendment, which seeks somewhat to jump the gun and bring about total divorcement before the review properly undertaken by the Government is completed, is opposed by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — This matter has a fairly long history, to some of which reference has been made. When this Bill was debated in the previous Parliament on 21 October 1982 the then Minister for Social Security, now the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney), said:

SPEECH.PARA: To conclude, the Government--
he was referring to the then Government, the now Opposition-
is opposed to the amending legislation which has been put forward by Senator Chipp. It does not believe that a requirement that on or before 1 July 1983--
I pause to say that Senator Chipp's amendment would make it the beginning of next year and that is appropriate--

there should be a total divestment by the oil companies of their remaining sites is a reasonable thing to impose upon them at this stage. The Government does not believe it is necessary to protect the competitive position or to protect the basic interests of retailers. Accordingly, we will be opposing the amending Bill .
Earlier, he had said:
So, in assessing how we should approach the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill introduced by Senator Chipp, we have a primary obligation to the consumers.
A little later he said that he did not believe that the interests of the consumers required the total divestment of the oil companies of their interests in petrol retailing sites. He further stated:
In this context it has the potential to bring about anti-competitive or non- competitive conditions.
He also stated:
I adopt one of the very substantial reasons put forward by Senator Evans for opposing this Bill.

He was referring to the present Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, who had spoken on behalf of the then Opposition, the now Government. I mention these points to make it quite clear who was saying what. Senator Chaney continued:
The Bill proposes what I regard as a dramatically sudden divestment of the remaining oil company sites.
There are a number of other comments such as:

A very small proportion of petrol station sites are controlled by the major companies. That is a factor in determining the Government's attitude that there is not at this stage excessive vertical integration.

Other points were raised by Senator Chaney. I am explaining why the Government at that time, the now Opposition, would not support the Petroleum Retailing Marketing Sites Amendment Bill 1982 introduced by the Australian Democrats. That position remains unchanged.

However, bearing in mind that history, I will make some further comments. The matter of petrol retailing sites has a long history, as has been said already, I think, by Senator Chipp. In 1976 the Collins Royal Commission on Petroleum reported, amongst other things, on the petrol retail market. In general, the report criticised the dominance of the nine major petroleum companies in the retailing of petroleum and said that that oligopoly was causing unfair competition or rather, I presume, an unfairness in the lack of competition or in the nature of the competition. It criticised the discriminatory pricing and unfair dealing with dealers, particularly independent dealers, that is, those not tied to a petroleum produce.

The former Government's solution was to seek a divorcement of sites, that is, a ban on the number of sites operated by major oil companies. In 1978 when it was announced that legislation would be introduced the Government wanted 100 per cent divorcement. That was subsequently reconsidered and, as has been said, the final conclusion was that a total divorcement was not necessary and that provision for 50 per cent divorcement would be adequate at that stage. This reduction took proper account of the commitment which some companies had made to this form of marketing. I think it would be appropriate to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the commitment to this form of marketing by the various companies in Australia varies very substantially. There are some companies which I imagine would not be particularly concerned if this legislation went through. Other companies have very substantial investment in marketing retail sites and a very substantial part of their whole marketing policy is related to their participation in the retailing aspect.

I well recall the efforts of the late Mr Phil Jelli of New South Wales, one of the original founders of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. He was a very active man on behalf of the interests of the service station proprietors of New South Wales and Australia. He had a long-standing devotion to this cause and put the case for the small person, the small man, the small operator against the big company. I think that in many ways the case put forward was extremely convincing. It pointed out that there were inequities, discrimination and times when individual operators were unable to obtain a reasonable deal, a fair go, in their negotiations with the oil companies. When an oil company both owns the site and is the sole supplier, it is quite obvious that the bargaining position is very unequal. It is that inequality of bargaining position which is a matter of very real concern to many people involved in the consideration of questions related to this industry. Is the inequality such as to create distortions and inequities? Are those distortions and inequities of such severity that their continuance is unconscionable behaviour in Australia?

I trust that the further investigation-the Government has given an assurance that it is being undertaken-which the Department of Resources and Energy is undertaking of the success or otherwise of the operation of the 1980 scheme introduced by the former Government, will be carried out with reasonable expedition and thoroughness to ensure that it will be available before Parliament rises at the end of this year. If the Government is in a position to give an assurance of that nature-it is my understanding from inquiries which I have made that that should be possible-I imagine that a case can well be made out for waiting until that review of the operation of the 1980 legislation has been made available. I refer also to some of the other points which Senator Chipp made. He said that we have got all the information we need, we have had a royal commission, we have had this and we have had that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven years ago.

—There have been many changes since then. Not the least significant of the changes were the 1980 amendments and the 50 per cent divestment. But further and more important-reference has not been made to this point so far-is the fact that a number of State governments have decided to intervene in this field. A distortion of the operation of the system of petrol retailing throughout Australia has been created as a result of the separate independent intervention of State governments in limiting prices and imposing other forms of regulation in relation to this area of economic activity. There is no identity of approach between the States. In four of the States there is legislation; in two of the States there is no legislation. The legislation in the four States is not identical in its form and has differing effects and implications. That is a factor which needs to be taken into account by the Department of Resources and Energy when it considers the success or otherwise of the 1980 amendments introduced by the former Government in an attempt to overcome what were accepted as some of the distortions and inequities which were created.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is extremely draconian to require virtual immediate 100 per cent divestment by the oil companies. The investment implications as well as the implications with regard to trade and marketing are significant. In the circumstances of the factors I have mentioned-that is, that State governments have intervened, there has been a variety of other distortionary legislative intervention in this field since 1980 and there is the action taken in 1980-it is reasonable now to say: 'Let there be continuation and completion of an assessment of the situation before any severe action is taken'. Anticipating that there will be forthcoming from the Government an assurance that we can have a further chance to discuss this matter, the Opposition would propose to continue to say that we will not support the carriage of the Bill at this stage. That is the position that we took in October last year.

I would also say, in commenting on what Senator Chipp said about the oil companies being happy with the 50-50 situation, that that is not my understanding from discussions I have had with some of the oil companies. They are unhappy with a number of aspects. Certainly their operating profits for the past financial year indicate that very few of them would have smiles on their faces in relation to their operations of recent times.

With regard to the Queensland situation, it is my understanding that an undertaking has been given by the Liberal Party with regard to cleaning up the service station situation. I cannot answer whether a request was made to the former Government. I would have to make inquiries but, since it has been raised, I can only say to Senator Chipp that I will make the inquiry and obtain an answer as soon as I can. If he then wishes that information to be given publicly in this chamber, then I shall do what I can to make it public in this chamber. I can do no more than make that offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are sounding like a Minister already.

—It will not take long, the way this Government is going, before I have the opportunity to change sides. I guess that, on my record, I am intended to be permanently on the front bench in opposition. That is not an unhappy situation as far as I am concerned; I just hope that the rest of the party has plenty of opportunity to be in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only have the complications of pricing State by State created considerable questions, which have been raised by me and others in this chamber, but also I think the operation of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and the freight equalisation scheme are matters which need to be taken into account in the survey of this area because we have still, to me, the inexplicable situation of up to a one-third differentiation in price between the prices paid at the principal urban outlets, one State to another. Senator Tate would well know one of the States to which I am referring-our State of Tasmania-which experiences an inordinately high price most of the time. I well recall once having been in several States on the same day and seeing a more than one-third difference in the average price between the States. It seems incredible that that situation can prevail with the operation of the freight equalisation scheme.

So one imagines that there are severe distortions being created by State legislation, amongst other things, and that these distortions will all be part of what will be reviewed. I hope, therefore, that not only will we be seeing a review of the operation from the point of view of the interests of the consumer, the small or individual independent retailer, the lessee retailers of the major companies as well as the oil companies themselves-that is, the total interests of all of those involved in the industry-but also that we will have a look at the forces which result in the huge disparities in price from State to State. If the review can give us some sort of reasonable answers to that as well, then I think it will have been well worth waiting for. Having expressed those thoughts, I indicate that the Opposition will seek and expect to receive the assurance that I have sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this debate as I have had an interest in this area over a number of years. I would like to express a point of view which might not conform with the point of view of either side of the chamber. I do not believe that the 1980 legislation worked. It was bound to fail . I think that what has been proposed by the Australian Democrats will also fail . The review to be undertaken by the Government must take a new approach. It is fairly obvious that forces are at work in the market-place, both in the refining of petroleum products and in their distribution. Those forces have to be properly understood and, if I might say so, properly controlled.

SPEECH.PARA: This is now an urgent matter because in Queensland the distributors of petroleum products face bankruptcy due to the uneven nature of the pricing policy. I do not think the problem will be solved by divorcing the oil companies and taking them out of the market-place. The Australian Government needs to take the matter firmly in hand. It should consider this as a matter of national importance. It involves national conservation of an important energy resource, and it relates to certain defence elements as well. For that reason the Australian Government must look at taking to itself the power to control this source of energy. I believe it is necessary to move quickly to a position where we have a national corporation controlling the oil industry. That would take it out of the hands of the major oil companies and the major oil importers.

TALK.START.PARA: —To nationalise the whole industry?

—It is not a matter of nationalising the whole industry in the terms in which the honourable senator would put it. I know he would say: 'You are nationalising the industry'. I am saying it is an important area of energy that ought to be under the control of the Australian people. That can be done only through the Australian Government because of the variety of positions that the States take. I am not saying that we ought to do this without the co- operation of the States. I think we ought to come to an understanding with the States so that we have control over refining policies and can regulate the wholesale price. Varying wholesale prices are available to people in Queensland and that is distorting the market-place. Some have access to a good wholesale price; others do not.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, the wholesale price has not been established. The wholesale price now set by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority is not the price at which the petrol is sold. There is a variety of wholesale prices and a variety of price supports, and some have access and some do not. Those who do not, suffer. The sooner we establish a wholesale price for fuel and the sooner we determine that all shall have access to that wholesale price the better. The sooner that we rationalise freight charges up and down the coast of Australia the better because some people are at a disadvantage to others. We are trying to control this very important industry by partial methods. We will not succeed. We will succeed only if we set up a corporation to control the import of fuel and not allow some companies to take advantage of the spot markets overseas to distort distribution of petroleum within Australia. I believe that the sooner we reach that position the better. I trust that the review will take these matters into account.

I also hope that the various political parties will accept that this is a national responsibility and that we have to deal with this matter with that national responsibility in mind. I say again that what happened in 1980 failed. What is proposed by this legislation will fail. I hope that the review will come up with an answer. There is, within the Australian Labor Party platform, a policy to set up a hydrocarbons corporation. The sooner we establish that corporation and take the industry out of the control of multinationals the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to some of the matters raised by honourable senators. In relation to Senator Peter Rae's contribution on behalf of the Liberal and National parties and, in particular in relation to the timetable-he was concerned that this review ought not go on endlessly-I am informed that it is hoped that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) will have the results of the review by the end of October. Of course, the Government will then have to make its own decision as to whether further amendment to the legislation is warranted. It would then be a question of trying to find a place for such legislation in the timetable of the Parliament if it were thought desirable. Honourable senators will, I think, concede that the timetable already looks to be fairly crowded.
—What about a debate on the report?

—The review will be in the hands of the Government, one hopes, by the end of October. The Government will then make a decision, not only as to its own course as regards legislation, but also-I take Senator Messner's point-as to whether the substance of it ought to be made available for wider consideration in the general business community and amongst the various political parties which have an obvious interest in this mater. I must say to Senator Peter Rae that I cannot give any assurance that the scope of the review would be such as would enable the whole question of the pricing of petroleum products within Australia to be the subject of any recommendations or conclusions by those undertaking that review except, of course, insofar as competitive elements in the mix between independent owner-operated retail sites and company-owned retail sites would have an impact on the price of the product that would be offered to the ordinary consumer. But I believe that that is the extent to which this review will be able to take into account the question of the final price of a petroleum product to the consumer. Basically it is a review of those two pieces of legislation. To that extent it is confined to the question of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act rather than the larger questions which are, of course, quite proper for any government to consider.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp raised the question of the Queensland election and the apparent decision by both the State Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party to put forward a policy which would have an effect, insofar as it is within the power of State governments, on the operators within the retail market in that State. The Federal Government's decision to hold the review emanates directly, I suggest, from its pre-election statement on business regulation in which it indicated that whilst its policy is to restrict the involvement of the major oil companies in the retail market, it acknowledged in that statement on business regulation that there may be price competitive arrangements in permitting the major oil companies to have some share of the retail market. But this Government stated quite clearly that the involvement of those corporations must be restricted to protect small businesses operating in the market. That is the key criterion of that policy document. The object of the review then is to ensure that small businesses operating in the market are protected. To that extent, whatever decisions have to be taken in relation to the involvement of the major oil corporations will be taken. Indeed, as I said, this review is a direct fulfilment of that pre-election statement.

I believe Senator Georges raised quite a different criterion for the Government to have before it in deciding on the proper mix of the involvement of the major oil corporations in the Australian market, not only in the retail market, but also in the refining and, indeed, the exploration in relation to petroleum products. I believe that in raising those matters quite properly, he has alerted us to the very real misgivings that are proper, I think, for any Australian to have about the dominance of companies which owe their allegiance, in the main, to overseas shareholders in relation to their activities in this resource which is so sensitive to Australia's development. As I said, this relates not only to the extraction of those resources from Australian wells but to the bringing in of the product from overseas, refining it and then distributing it throughout the nation in a way which is then, of course, crucial to the operations of businesses throughout the economy and, indeed, to the whole social life of Australia. But insofar as that is again a wider issue than is being undertaken in this review, the Government cannot say that the review itself will answer the sorts of questions raised by Senator Georges.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are sounding like a Minister, too.

—I am doing a small apprenticeship here. The Government maintains its position that to accede to this amendment at this stage would be to pre-empt the review. I do not believe that it is reasonable to expect the Government, in its first six months of office, to put aside the opportunity to come to its own assessment of the facts and, on the basis of that assessment to bring legislation into this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pursue two points a little further. The first is whether we could be given some assurance that the Government will facilitate a debate in this chamber on the findings of the review because otherwise one could be led to have some doubts as to the basis upon which the Government proposes to deal with the review. I am not saying that I am seeking an undertaking that the Government will take any specific action. Obviously it would be unreal to say that it would introduce legislation or take any of the other actions to which Senator Tate referred. But I think it is not unreal or not unreasonable to seek an undertaking from the Government that there will be some discussion of the results of the review before the end of this session, that is, before we rise in December or whenever. That, presumably, will be something over a month after the report is completed, typed and made available to the Government for its consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point to which I refer while that further request is being considered is that I think it is only fair to say, on behalf of the petroleum companies, that I understand from discussions and observations that I have made that there has been a very significant and, if I can make a small pun, Australianisation of spirit so far as those oil companies are concerned. I find that most of them appear able, and claim that they are able, to act with a very substantial degree of independence as Australians, in the domestic interests of Australia, and that they have very substantial autonomy in their operations. I think it would be unfair not to mention, in view of some of the remarks that have been made about multinational or overseas companies, that observation from experience, for what it is worth. I look forward to receiving an assurance from Senator Tate that those companies will be able to hear a little more about this subject before the end of the session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have already indicated to honourable senators that the Government will have this review-it is a departmental review, though with the widest possible consultation with the industry and the State governments concerned-in its hands at the end of October. I do not think it is normal to enable any chamber of the Parliament to have before it the findings of a departmental review made for a Minister. I did say that I saw no reason why the substance of the review could not be indicated to the Senate in the course of some appropriate debate or discussion on the general topic. I believe that if such a debate were to take place, or some such discussion were to be facilitated , quite clearly Senator Button would have available to him the findings of the review. In the course of that discussion no doubt he would indicate the sorts of considerations which would lead the Government then to decide on appropriate legislation. That is as full an indication of the Government's desire to facilitate further discussion as I can give. I will certainly make known to the Minister, Senator Button, the request of Senator Peter Rae. Given the Minister's bipartisan support for our rejection at this stage of the Chipp amendment I believe he will wish to accommodate the honourable senator in that request.

—Before this matter is finally disposed of in this chamber I seek again to find out whether, in the same spirit as that in which I have tried to deal with Senator Chipp's request about the Queensland situation-I have just been out of the chamber for a moment to try to get some response-Senator Tate may himself be able to get a response and assure us that there will be a ministerial statement in one form or other in relation to this matter before the end of this session. I do not necessarily expect the actual report of the department, in the form presented to the Minister, to be made available-simply a ministerial statement on the subject before the end of this year. That is the formal request which I make to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Assuming that the advice that the review will be completed at the end of October is correct, I give the undertaking that the Minister will make available to the Parliament a statement along the lines that Senator Rae has requested.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, negatived.
Bill reported negatived; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, and in order to enable the Standing Committee on Social Welfare to
(a) complete its inquiry into children and youth under institutional and other forms of care, commenced in the previous Parliament and continued in this Parliament, and

(b) undertake the inquiry into retirement income systems, which was referred to it on Tuesday, 6 September 1983, with the requirement that the Committee report on or before the first sitting day in August 1984,

the Committee consist of eight senators, four being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and four being senators who are not members of the Government, to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or independent senator or independent senators.
(2) That nothing in the foregoing resolution affect the appointments to the Committee of senators who are at present members of the Committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May 1983, on motion by Senator Jack Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Democracy Bill 1983 is the same as the Bill which was introduced by Senator Siddons and passed by the Senate in November 1981. At that time, the present Opposition, which was then in government, indicated that, although it had a basic sympathy with the ideals of employee participation which the Bill expressed, it could not support the Bill. In opposition, we are still of the same opinion. Before I elaborate, I should like to run through the background of the question which the Bill seeks to confront and through the record of the previous Government in this regard. As I said, the Opposition believes not only that increased employee participation in decisions in the work place is itself a goal to be sought but, perhaps more importantly, that it is a goal which it is important should be pursued through voluntary negotiations between management and the work force. Not only should discussions be entered into freely by the prospective parties; they should also be conducted at a level of individual enterprises and companies so that the most appropriate form of organisation of the enterprise could be found. One of the principal aims underlying increased employee participation is, after all, the creation of an environment within which both employers and employees can experience a greater level of job satisfaction. Such an end can surely be more consistently and easily achieved by voluntary approaches to the question rather than by legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1978 the present shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, who was a member of the Fraser Government, announced a policy of employee participation and the means to be used to work towards it as an important objective in the field of industrial relations. It was considered then, as at the time of Senator Siddons' s Bill, and indeed still today, that support for legislation to encourage higher levels of employee participation could not be given. The most cogent reason for that opinion is that employee participation is still at an early and experimental phase in Australian industry and any worthwhile contribution through the legislative process can come only when there has been some real experience of how such schemes would work in practice. It is simply not sufficient to transpose experiences in other countries, or indeed the limited examples in Australia of the Repco organisation and Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd, and apply them to every other Australian enterprise holus bolus.

In government, we pursued an approach towards the problem in two broad elements : firstly, a process designed to facilitate discussions between employers and trade unions in order to develop programs and strategies; and, secondly, a rejection of a prescriptive approach which would simply draw up an overall plan of practices by all enterprises, regardless of size, complexity or particular circumstances.

I believe that the Bill now before the Senate reveals its shortcomimgs since essentially it presents a ready-made off-the-peg scheme, with no room for manoeuvre or adaptation to individual circumstances by interested parties. There is, for example, no provision for the appointment to the Industrial Democracy Board of employers per se. The Bill calls for three members of the Board to be nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, one by the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and three by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. On top of that, employer organisations can clearly expect to have problems with a structure of employee participation in which individual enterprises would have to accept a degree of control over their financial affairs, and even their day to day financial decisions, which would be highly impracticable. Beyond that, it is clear that there can be no single blueprint for employee participation which would satisfy or suit the financial structures of all enterprises which might be considering some from of employee participation.

Section 20 of the Bill is perhaps most crucial in terms of financial administration for any enterprises that are governed by the scheme. While there is no need at this time to go into the finer details of the taxation incentives and so on suggested by the Bill, it is clear that the provisions of this section , because of their superfluous details, such as, for example, the insistence on separate monthly profit and loss statements for each group involved, would cause great and costly rigidities and would produce inefficiencies. Indeed, there would appear to be some degree of confusion in the minds of the proponents of this Bill since the Bill quite clearly refers to 8 per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise, while there has been reference by Senator Jack Evans in his second reading speech to a figure of 14 per cent. But in either case, whether it is 8 per cent or 14 per cent, a totally arbitrary figure like this is , of course, clearly unsuitable as a starting point for the establishment of an industrial democracy scheme on any large scale.

The Bill would also have the effect of preventing companies with fewer than 10 shareholders from even being put on the Register of Industrial Democracy Enterprises. This would deprive small companies-those most in need of them-of the tax exemptions offered by the Bill. While the Bill seems to be overly precise in the wrong ways, other sections of it are not sufficiently precise in spelling out the conditions which would be necessary to protect the rights of parties in industrial democracy enterprises. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has pointed out that section 25 would have the effect of making the decisions of the Industrial Democracy Board to list enterprises in the register or, conversely, to remove names from the register final and conclusive and not subject to any right of appeal. Of course, registration by the Board would be crucial for an enterprise to obtain any benefits.

On a more general level, the Bill pays no attention to the resources, skills and training needed to introduce such practices. It would be wrong to suppose that a magic wand, in the form of a Bill, whose consequences have not been thoroughly thought through, could be waved and that the result would be instant industrial democracy.
