The reality is that goodwill, effort and expertise are needed in great quantities. That is the only way that this will be resolved; not by legislation. The Opposition is opposed to the Bill for the reasons that I have outlined and, most importantly, because it seeks to impose a single form of industrial organisation on all enterprises which might wish to introduce a degree of employee participation. We believe that it is not only impracticable but also inequitable and unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government commends the objectives of the Industrial Democracy Bill 1983 introduced into this House by the Australian Democrats, but we will not vote for it because we oppose the means by which the objectives set out in the Bill are proposed to be realised. However, by introducing the Bill, a vital question has been raised about the industrial relations health of the country, and that should be acknowledged. I note from the remarks of the Opposition that their emphasis is that industrial democracy should emerge by voluntary means rather than from legislation. Certainly the Government has a view about the type of legislation that might be necessary but if it is left purely to voluntary means, as it has been until now, Australia will languish behind the rest of the world in the promotion of industrial democracy in the work place. That has been our record. To perpetuate that view would mean that we would fall further behind, and that is not desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our view that industrial democracy is vital and it is necessary to advance that issue broadly and on a basis on which it can take root and flower. When it does, not only does the work place become more humane and decision making more attuned to the needs of people as well as plant, equipment and profit and loss sheets, but also there are fewer industrial disputes and usually an accompanying increase in productivity and profitability for the companies. We do not argue for industrial democracy from the point of view that it should be seen only as a means of increasing profitability and productivity. It should be a means of humanising the work place. But, as we have said, while commending the objectives of the Bill, we argue against what is contained in it to implement those objectives. I hope to enumerate some of our concerns about what is involved in the Bill and indicate to the Australian Democrats, particularly Senator Jack Evans, who is arguing the case from their side, that we invite them to join the consensus in the community that the Hawke Government has created and add industrial democracy to part of that consensus so that the whole community can move forward in this regard.

As has been pointed out, in the last Parliament Senator Siddons introduced a Bill on industrial democracy. At that time the present Government had a number of amendments but essentially supported the direction of the Bill. The Bill that has come forward this time is, as I understand it, an exact copy of the previous one. Our approach now is to say that the most constructive way of pursuing industrial democracy is to do it in a way in which the parties can be brought into a context of addressing the issue and developing for themselves the most appropriate form of industrial democracy in the work place. When the previous Bill came before us, the political and industrial context in Australia was vastly different. Then we had the Fraser Government which had one of the worst industrial relations records of any government that has ever graced the government benches in the Federal capital-a Government characterised by a confrontationist mentality and by a mentality of union bashing refined to a fine art by Mr Viner when he was Minister for Industrial Relations. That approach was rejected by many employers as well as by unions and, ultimately, on 5 March this year, by the electorate. In the climate of a government with no policy on industrial democracy and a hostile and divisive industrial relations approach, it was essential to support a positive initiative then being taken by Senator Siddons. Now the context is vastly different.

I will point out four main reasons why I believe the intentions of the Democrats can be accommodated within the strategy of this Government. Firstly, the policy of the Australian Labor Party in its industrial relations platform sets out at division E a distinct and clear set of objectives with respect to industrial democracy. It is not appropriate here to quote all of those but, to make the point, it is perhaps necessary, given that they are consistent in many respects with the objectives of this Bill, to quote the introduction to the industrial democracy policy in our Party's industrial relations platform. It states:

Industrial democracy is a natural extension of the democratic right of working people. The greater participation of workers in decisions affecting their working lives will lead to greater job satisfaction and will provide oportunities for the more efficient operation of enterprises.

It is desirable for employers and employees to be encouraged to be involved in genuine industrial democracy projects which achieve a sharing of power and responsibility between management and employees within an enterprise or industry .
These projects should be designed so as to allow for the special needs and features of the industry or enterprise concerned.

The first point that I make with respect to our approach is that it is embedded in our Party policy. It is consistent in general terms with the objectives of this Bill and I believe that those concerned with this issue can take heart in the sincerity and genuineness with which the Government takes up this matter.

Secondly, it should be mentioned, of course, that the whole thrust of our platform and our mandate is one of national consensus and reconciliation. In the spirit of the prices and incomes accord and the National Economic Summit Conference, we say that industrial democracy is congruent with those objectives, with that means of doing things and that philosophy endorsed by the electorate. We are moving in this sense to reflect our concern for conciliation and consensus in the work place by means of industrial democracy.

Thirdly, and importantly, the National Labour Consultative Council, a tripartite council comprising employer organisations, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government, and chaired by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, has established the Committee on Employee Participation. On 29 August that Committee was advised by the ACTU that the Siddons Bill should come forward for a complete review so that some aspects to which the ACTU could not feel committed when that Bill was before the House previously could be examined and further considered and also so that provisions for alternative approaches to the development of industrial democracy could arise. That Committee has set down a number of points of view about the legislation which is before us which I will come to in a moment. The important point is that the Committee is now in the process of developing strategies as to what ought to be done in this area which it will recommend to the Government.

The fourth point relates to merit. In this respect I find myself agreeing, although for vastly different reasons, with some of the remarks made by Senator Durack in his address a moment ago. In terms of industrial democracy the Bill imposes a prescriptive approach. That is the aspect of it which we find most difficult to accommodate. It is our view that industrial democracy, by the very definition of the words one uses, implies a situation in which one cannot say: ' This shall be the case'. Democracy is inconsistent with a dictatorial approach. Democracy requires a context in which people, through a process of power sharing , can make decisions for themselves. We cannot impose democracy. We must allow democracy to flourish. Therefore, on the fourth point in our general approach to the Bill, we say that for the obviously right reasons it pursues the wrong direction and mistakes a basic need to create the context for proper democracy within the work place by imposing a prescriptive approach.

As I said a moment ago, the National Labour Consultative Council's Committee on Employee Participation has considered the Siddons Bill. The Committee has eight qualifications about it. It is as well that these are noted. The first point which the NLCC Committee makes-I remind the Senate that this is a body comprising employers, unions and the Government; it is a tripartite body, and these are views arising from tripartite consensus-is that the blanket approach proposed fails to acknowledge the individual needs and circumstances of the enterprise and its employees. According to the Bill, a register is to be created . If one turns to clause 20 of the Bill one can see what are the prescriptions for industrial democracy. Clause 20 (1), the introductory clause, states:

The Board shall list in the register each enterprise which in the opinion of the Board exhibits a marked degree of industrial democracy in its structure and operations and substantially complies with the following criteria: . . .

Four criteria are set out in sequence, but there are two immediate tests to qualify. One is that there must be a marked degree of industrial democracy and that, secondly, it substantially qualifies. Unless those two tests are met no relief by a tax method as proposed in this Bill about which we are concerned arises. It seems to us that that two-test introduction creates a strait-jacket which can strangle growing initiatives towards industrial democracy. The following four provisions place, in my view, an undue emphasis upon employee shareholding and profit sharing which, while admitted into the wide context of possible variance of an industrial democracy approach, are not, I believe, mainstream solid approaches that are likely to arise or should necessarily be given heavier weight than what could be a much more useful way of evolving an industrial democracy program.

The second point which the NLCC Committee makes is that insufficient emphasis is placed on the need for joint development of practices at the enterprise level . That flows from the point I have just made. Thirdly, the Committee says that the provision of the benefit of reduced taxation to some enterprises at the expense of other providers of revenue could be questioned on equity grounds. Next the Committee states:
The additional incentive of reduced taxation would appear to be unnecessary if the aims of greater efficiency and productivity laid out in the Bill are realised.
The Committee adds:

Attempts to qualify for tax deductions may become the basic aim of many enterprises, leading to the introduction of 'paper' schemes rather than the development of viable and meaningful forms of employee participation.

We, as a Government, are concerned about any opportunities for tax avoidance. We are concerned that the real intent and real spirit of industrial democracy is able to flourish. It seems that by linking tax concessions to industrial democracy we open the possibility for those who have already indicated a ruthless initiative to exploit any tax loophole to try to develop paper schemes which are not meaningful but which perhaps can be pointed to as industrial democracy schemes by employers or companies. That argues against the spirit of what the Bill seeks to achieve. The NLCC Committee goes on:
The membership of the proposed Industrial Democracy Board does not include employer representation.

One must have regard to that because, clearly, the context of tripartitism is an essential context for industrial relations. Employers form one part of the triumvirate and, therefore, ought to be admitted to that decision-making process . Further the Committee states:
It should not be for such a body to decide what is and what is not industrial democracy.
Of course, it is referring to the Board. It continues:
This is a matter for joint agreement within individual enterprises.

That is the consistent thread of my remarks. It is no good having a superior body sitting in judgment on what constitutes democracy and what does not. Democracy is to be found by the practice of it in the work place in forms that can be evolved over time, and grow and become real. Finally, the Committee states:
A complex inspection system requiring considerable resources would be required to check the legitimacy of new and existing applicants.

Of course, the Bill does impose such a scheme. The NLCC takes the view that that is not a desirable development. The Committee on Employee Participation was well aware of the concern of the Australian Democrats about this legislation, but was worried about its contents and the way in which realisation of the objectives was to be achieved. I understand that the Committee decided-this may not yet have occurred; obviously it is a departmental matter-to issue an invitation to the honourable senator sponsoring this Bill to be included in the discussions of the NLCC Committee on Employee Participation that is addressing itself to the very issue to which this Bill addresses itself. I understand that an invitation to attend the Committee's November meeting will be issued.

I think it can be clearly and reasonably put that there are very real concerns held by front line battered veterans of industrial relations about what this Bill contains. They are not condemnatory of it in a dismissive sense. It is an encouraging development. But the approach needs to be evolved within the tripartite nature of the NLCC and, of course, with the assistance, if such an invitation can be accepted, of the Australian Democrats spokesman.

I wish to add my considerations about other aspects of the Bill. Firstly, with respect to the provision in the Bill relating to consultative councils, the system of election laid down excludes the union structure in the work place. I do not think it is desirable that such an exclusion prevail. In fact, it is much more desirable-it is healthy-for the union structure to be enlisted in the industrial democracy process and be the means by which employees can express their objectives and goals in terms of participation. If the Bill were to be enacted and such a provision were to apply we would set up in the work place two potentially conflicting structures-the consultative committee or council and the combined unions in the work place. What we are about is trying to find a means of bringing everyone together and not establishing a fundamental organisational conflict. I think that is an aspect of the Bill that would need consideration should it ever be taken further.

The other aspect of this Bill which I think needs comment on, is that it excludes healthy, emerging forms of industrial democracy which are not contemplated by the structure of this Bill. In my experience companies which are involved in developing these programs do not particularly welcome being named, thus attracting attention in the media as something extraordinary. Therefore, without naming particular companies, I will simply say that I am aware of one, a mining company, which has been quietly working at developing an employee participation program, an industrial democracy program. It is beginning to show signs of remarkable success. My understanding is that already nine various tiers of hierarchical control in the company have been reduced quite considerably to five such tiers. Thus the process of decision making is brought closer to where most of the workers are employed, at the bottom level of the structure, and a proximity between management and employees is able to be achieved.

The success of that structural alteration has enabled negotiations between various unions and management to emerge in provisions for multi-skilling and so on. In the normal run of company-union negotiations, that is an area of great difficulty and conflict, yet in the structure and context this company has been able to create it has emerged easily and with the approval of both participants in the negotiating process. The whole atmosphere of the company is one of a learning environment and encouragement for training. There is an understanding of the obligations of the company and its needs on the part of the employees, as well as an understanding by the company of its obligations and the needs of the workers. The reality that is emerging is that many of the workers are becoming more confident of participating in events, not only in the company, but also in the general community. Thus they are becoming more useful citizens to the community as well.

I am aware of another company in what many commentators from an industrial relations point of view regard as the blighted iron ore province of the Pilbara. This company, despite fairly continuous disputes in other areas, has of late a remarkable record because it has wholeheartedly embraced the concept of industrial democracy. It has embraced that concept on the basis of recognising a need to supply the information to workers to enable them to participate properly . One cannot create a structure that invites participation without supplying the information necessary for informed, intelligent and meaningful participation. This company has taken that course and as well has encouraged its workers to train themselves more effectively to be better participants in the decision- making process. It is a process of evolving democracy and one that is an encouraging example of how best to handle industrial relations in an area noted for poor industrial relations.

I note that in the second reading speech that accompanied the Bill remarks were made about practices of industrial democracy in overseas countries-Scandinavian countries, West Germany and Japan were mentioned. Certainly, those countries have a form of industrial democracy vastly more developed and effective than anything in Australia. In my maiden speech, in fact, I remarked that if one wants to examine how to improve industrial relations, one should look at countries with a tradition and heritage, a cultural background similar to our own and which have a better industrial relations performance to discover the difference between what those countries do and what we do in industrial relations.

If we look at European countries, particularly West Germany and to an increasing extent France, we will find that what distinguishes their industrial relations system from ours, among other things, is a sophisticated employee participation industrial democracy approach to joint decision making. It is present there, absent here. The dispute level is low there, higher here. One can draw from that a salutary lesson, namely that Australia should at least catch up . In catching up we should not ape or duplicate the structures other countries have. We should put an Australian accent on industrial democracy. We should apply an Australian approach and evolve our own means of expressing it.

That brings me to mention Japan. It provides probably the starkest example of a country whose procedures we ought not follow. Japan has a vastly different cultural context from Australia. It has a paternalistic form of management which involves quality circles and employee consultation. It also has life-long employment in the key major industries and thus complete job security. It is able to absorb vast technological change rapidly. However, the cultural context of Japan-the life-long commitment and loyalty of an employee to an employer and an employer to an employee-does not typify Anglo-Saxon or indeed Western society as a whole. Thus, we cannot select from the Japanese experience one aspect that appears favourable and compute that automatically as being applicable to Australia. We need to distil the principles that make the Japanese example effective and apply them in a way in which they are Australian and take on an Australian form and expression.

I know that that is exactly what this Government is doing through the NLCC based on Labor Party policy and direction. That is a more appropriate way of proceeding than is provided in this Bill. However, I conclude by saying that the Australian Democrats are to be commended for raising the matter. The Bill brings the question to centre stage, which is important. Thus, the debate on how we go about achieving an improved level of industrial democracy is able to be joined. For the Government's part, we will vote against this Bill in the knowledge that we are developing such a program ourselves and we invite all parties in this Parliament to join in that development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Industrial Democracy Bill 1983. It has the worthy object of encouraging the introduction of industrial democracy in Australian enterprises. As one who has supported industrial democracy ever since I was elected to the Senate in 1976 and for many years beforehand, I have been very interested in this Bill and its progress. However, despite its excellent object the Bill unfortunately does not fulfil its expressed purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: As I listened to Senator Cook I could not help but agree with practically everything he had to say, not only about the Bill but also about industrial democracy generally. I could not help but think to myself what a great pity it was that in November 1981 when former Senator Siddons introduced this Bill someone in the Australian Labor Party, which was then in opposition, did not stand up and make that sort of speech. If the Labor Party in 1981 had joined with us in making those sorts of speeches about the Bill and in drawing to Senator Siddons's attention the defects of his Bill, it may very well be that the Bill introduced by Senator Jack Evans, an Australian Democrat, in this Parliament, instead of being identical to Senator Siddons's, may very well have been a Bill this Senate could have supported. Unfortunately, in 1981 the Labor Party, then in opposition, played politics with this Bill. It got Senator Siddons to agree to some minor amendments and then supported his Bill in an attempt to embarrass the then Government by playing politics. The consequence of that is that today Senator Cook has to stand up and explain to the Democrats why the Labor Party, now in government, will not support the Bill. Although it supported it in 1981 it will not support it now for the very reasons Senator Cook expressed today and which we expressed in November 1981.

I turn now to industrial democracy and employee participation. Shortly after Mr Fraser came to government in 1975 he established a ministry of productivity. In due course a national employee participation steering committee, comprised of people from all sections of industry throughout Australia, was established. That committee produced a couple of reports. The first, published in 1979, was entitled 'Employee Participation-A Broad View'. Unfortunately that broad view seemed to have got lost somewhere in the quagmire of documentation which is produced in this Parliament and perhaps has not had the publicity around Australia that it should have had. The question 'What is employee participation? ' is posed on page 1 of the report. The following answer is given:

A number of different terms have been used in discussions in this field, e.g. employee participation, worker participation and industrial democracy. Different meanings have been attributed to these by different people but the common thread running through them all is employees having a greater say in the decisions affecting them at work.
That last sentence is absolutely vital and I draw it to the attention of the Senate. The whole object is for employees to have a greater say in decisions affecting them at work.
The report poses a number of other questions, one of which is: How? That question is answered at some length. However, the first paragraph states:

Practical applications of employee participation vary in the degree and scope of employee involvement in decision making, and will be appropriate under varying circumstances. They include situations where employees:
are informed
are consulted
decide jointly with management
decide themselves
That is how one gets involved in employee participation. In this respect I would like finally to quote the following paragraph from the report:
We believe that employee participation cannot be introduced through legislation but that it should be developed on a voluntary basis, in response to social and community trends and needs.

That thinking is along the lines of what Senator Cook said, with which I certainly agree wholeheartedly. We cannot enforce employee participation by direct legislative means; we have to encourage employee participation or industrial democracy. That certainly can be done.

I would like to draw attention to some books that have been written on this subject. I refer particularly to a book entitled Up the Organisation written by Robert Townsend and published by Coronet Books Hodder-Fawcett Ltd. A copy of the book, which I think was first published in 1970, is in the Parliamentary Library and I recommend it to anyone who is interested in worker participation. In particular I recommend it to employers and managers throughout Australia. The book is easy to read; it is light and humorous. It is sub-titled: 'How to stop the company stifling people and strangling profits'. The author talks about some fundamental models of management. According to the book, there are two models of management. The first is that which sees power as the means of achieving aims- management by power, by control from above. That form of management has been practised in the military services, the church and institutions of that nature for centuries. Some enlightened companies and managers are beginning to understand and, in fact, have been adopting, for decades, another form of management. That form of management encourages each employee to use his or her capabilities to the utmost, to take an active mental interest not only in tasks but also in what the business is doing and where it is going. People are encouraged to participate in their daily work, not to treat it as some menial task that has to be performed from eight in the morning till five in the afternoon without interest, whether that task be putting a wheel on a motor car as it goes along an assembly line or whatever. Employees are encouraged actually to take a mental interest in their work. It can be done.

I draw attention to the report of a speech made by Mr Graham Spurling, the Australian Managing Director of Mitsubishi Motors Aust. Ltd, which appeared on 31 May 1982 in the Australian Financial Review. The speech was made at a seminar attended by Australian and Japanese businessmen. In that speech Mr Spurling drew attention to what Mitsubishi was doing in Australia. According to the report, he said:
We believe that we have the highest levels of productivity in the Australian car industry and that we can make the best quality product.
He went on to say:

I am not a great advocate of high technology investment as the path to productivity and profitability, and it may surprise you to hear me say, neither are the Japanese. We in Australia are all too ready too look to capital investment as the panacea of our problems. The Australian manager is too prone to saying that technology is the answer to higher productivity.

The defect in this line of thinking is that the result may be just to superimpose high investment on top of an inefficient structure, and when this happens the whole edifice may fall unless it is propped up with government protection . . .

Low cost measures adopted by MMAL to improve productivity included use of a minimum inventory production line system . . . product designs to make the cars easier to build . . . quality circles to enable employees more readily to identify with the company's productivity and quality objectives.
This had all been coupled with Japanese style techniques aimed at improving the trust between management and employees . . .

These are the sorts of systems which can be introduced if company managers will only apply their minds to starting at the very beginning, as is indicated in this report entitled 'Employee Participation-a Broad View'. They should start, with selected staff, to introduce these forms of participation by their workers so that the workers will believe they are making a contribution to productivity. If that happens workers will start to get interested in quality control. They will also start to get interested in the company making a profit so that they can seek some advantage from that profit. In speaking about the Japanese, Mr Spurling said:

Their philosophy is to get everyone, management and labour, working together to maximise utilisation of existing plant, and by so conserving capital your company is better able to ride out the highs and lows of business activity.
Only when every other avenue has been explored do they look to new capital facilities for the answer to greater productivity.

This comes only when they have exhausted all other means of improvement, better organisation and planning, better use of people, all the time tempered with mutual respect and understanding between manager and worker.

Honourable senators will have understood from my remarks that I am talking about participation in management or participation in organisation, not participation in ownership, which is another aspect of participation that can be achieved. I have drawn attention previously in this Senate to a company in my district, Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd. Currently about 76 per cent of that company is owned by present employees, past employees and widows of deceased employees. That company was established shortly after the war by Sir Fletcher Jones, who is now deceased. He was a man of great idealism who wished to bring into his work force the men coming back from the Second World War as participants in ownership as well as workers in the company. When that company started off it was owned 100 per cent by Sir Fletcher Jones and has now reached the stage where the Fletcher Jones family owns only about 24 per cent of it. Of course, that means that the employee-shareholders could sell the company if they so desired.

Participation in ownership has been done in other companies, and in many ways it is a desirable objective, as demonstrated by the Fletcher Jones group of companies. There are a number of ways in which this objective can be achieved. The United States has the Kelso schemes, the employees stock ownership plans, or ESOPs. The Labour Government in the United Kingdom in 1978 introduced an approved profit sharing scheme. This scheme enabled employees to become shareholders in their company and enabled the company to receive some tax benefits as a result of adopting such a scheme. I asked the Parliamentary Counsel to produce for me, as a private member's Bill, a Bill based on the United Kingdom Act, which was adopted and amended by the new Conservative Government in 1980. My private member's Bill is still in the pipeline, but one thing which quite appals me is that the draft Bill produced is 37 pages long. It is so complex that I am concerned that, when I get around to introducing it, it will receive short shrift by people who really cannot be bothered to sit down and read a 37-page private member's Bill. I mention to the Senate that that Bill is in the pipeline.

I certainly recommend to managers and owners of companies throughout Australia that they look at these sorts of schemes. One of the problems has been that for many years the governments of this country have failed to do away with double dipping by governments in taxing dividends twice. That has been done to the great detriment of the companies of this nation. The companies have company tax imposed on them. They then declare a dividend in favour of their shareholders and the shareholders have to pay tax on that dividend. That is double dipping by the Government. The result of that has been, of course, that small investors have stopped investing in companies in great numbers other than for speculative purposes. Most of the investment by small investors in this country at present has some sort of speculative motive about it. The other main group which is picking up shares in the companies around Australia is life offices.

This has been a great problem. Let me take as an example a company which establishes a shareholder-employee participation scheme. Such a company is faced with a situation in which if it declares a profit of, say, $100,000 to go to the employee-shareholders, currently it has to pay $46,000 to the Government out of the $100,000. That leaves the company with only $54,000 to go to its employees. If it were to declare bonuses in favour of those employees the company could declare the whole $100,000 for the employees' benefit. Of course, this is an enormous problem for companies such as the Fletcher Jones group, and schemes have had to be devised to avoid the problem of paying the Government twice.

Having dealt generally with the two ideas of participation-participation in management of organisations and participation in ownership-I turn to the Bill. This Bill tries to achieve both objectives but, as has been mentioned by both Senator Durack and Senator Cook, it starts unfortunately from too narrow a base, that is, the base of the Sidchrome company which apparently has a successful industrial democracy arrangement. I congratulate that company for having such a scheme. The problem was that Senator Siddons, having seen the scheme introduced by his own company and knowing the way it worked, then produced a Bill which tried to arrange for every company in Australia to go along with the Sidchrome proposal. Unfortunately, the result has been a disaster.

I have spoken to Mr Symons who is the Chairman of Directors of the Fletcher Jones group of companies. He was formerly a solicitor in the town of Warrnambool . He was my employer when I first went to Warrnambool. He subsequently joined the Fletcher Jones group as an employee and wound up as Chairman of Directors. He was the brains behind Sir Fletcher Jones's ideas about industrial democracy. He told me after examining this Bill that he would not be able to rearrange the Fletcher Jones organisation to become an industrial democratic enterprise within the meaning of this Bill. If that company could not be an industrial democratic enterprise within the meaning of this Bill, how many companies could be? He said that, as far as he could see, the Bill was impractical and impossible. He believed that very few companies in Australia, if any, would be able to comply with the intricate and complex details of the Bill. I mention to the Senate that Mr Symons made a submission on industrial democracy and participation in ownership to the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. That submission is incorporated in the Senate Hansard of 26 November 1981 at page 2677, and I recommend it to honourable senators for perusal.

I turn now to the Bill. Clause 5 establishes the Industrial Democracy Board. That statutory authority, or quango, if I could use that word, would undoubtedly become one of the most dictatorial quangos that this country has ever seen established. The powers that the Bill proposes for that quango are almost unbelievable. It would have the power to determine finally and without any right of appeal which company is an industrial democratic enterprise and which company is not. There would be no right of appeal. If a company wants to become an industrial democratic enterprise, the Bill sets out a series of matters with which each company has to comply. I will give the Senate some idea of what they are about. Clause 20 (1) of the Bill states that at least 8 per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise must be owned by a substantial number of employees of the organisation. There is no problem at all about this figure. That clause further states:

. . . and such share capital has, in the case of a public enterprise, been allocated at an effective price at least 25 per cent lower than the market price of such share capital prevailing at the time of allocation, . . .

What purpose is achieved by having that in this Bill? If that is what the company wants to do with its own employees, by all means let it do it. Unless the company complies with this, it is out right from the word go. Paragraph (b) states:
the activities of the enterprise are carried out through autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise . . .

Glory be! Do not the employers and the employees, the unions and management, have any right to sit down and work out how they want to run the company? No, they have to comply with this provision. They must have autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise. The Bill then goes on to define what that means:
(i) such groups have not fewer than 10 and not more than 100 members,
(ii) separate profit and loss statements are produced for each group on a monthly basis . . .
They do not have to be produced on a quarterly, bi-monthly or weekly basis but on a monthly basis otherwise the company is not an industrial democracy. It continues:
(iii) such groups cover every activity carried out by the enterprise,

If a company has one delivery van somehow or other it has to have that delivery van included in a working group based on a profit centre, and that group has to comprise not fewer than 10 and not more than 100 members. It is no good having one delivery van, or perhaps a semi-trailer, which picks up the product and takes it to the railway station; some sort of industrial group has to surround that. There are no exceptions. The Bill continues:
(iv) such groups make decisions on group production and cost objectives, production planning, purchasing, work allocation, appointment and termination of appointment of staff . . .

All of these things may very well be desirable. It may well be that these are the arrangements that the company would work out with its employees over time. I am sure that the Sidchrome company does this-that is why it is in the Bill-and I am sure that it is a good thing. But it appears that the mere elimination of any one of those things would make that company not an industrial democratic enterprise. Clause 20 continues:
(v) each group has a group leader . . .

Some of the industrial democratic enterprises already in existence do not have group leaders. People alternate in jobs week about in order to create variety, and there may not be a group leader. This group leader has to meet the other group representatives. What does that mean? Does it mean that the company might lose its tax deductibility if for some reason or other he does not meet with other group representatives? Paragraph (c) states:

a profit sharing scheme has been established in the enterprise, which takes account of profits before tax, in relation to total assets employed, of each group, and which distributes an agreed proportion of profits within each group to employees of the enterprise;

I can see some merit in that idea but I cannot see that one should include it in a Bill as being absolutely essential to the existence of the enterprise. A consultative council has to have been established, and it has to operate in a particular way. The Bill gives six directions as to how that council has to operate. We then come to a board, and the board is allowed to determine further criteria. The board may list in the register a company if it complies with only three of the criteria if in the opinion of the board-it is an absolute opinion- the listing of that enterprise in the register is consistent with the purpose of the Act. Notwithstanding all of this, even if a company goes to all of this trouble to establish itself along these lines, the board still has a discretionary power to decline to list that enterprise in the register as an industrial democracy, on the basis of I do not know what but apparently the board might think these measures have just been introduced for tax purposes, such as those mentioned by Senator Cook.

These are clear examples of why this Bill is unacceptable in its present form. I say again, seriously, to Senator Jack Evans, that I understand what the general purpose of the Bill is and I think it is a great pity that in 1981 the Australian Labor Party did not put these problems on the table before Senator Siddons so that the Australian Democrats might then have applied their minds to improving the Bill to eliminate a lot of this stuff.

I wish that company managers throughout Australia would take note of some of the things which have been said today about employee participation and would apply their minds in some way or other to getting these systems going. Our country would be so much better off if they adopted some of these criteria. I go a step further and say that not only would the country and the companies be better off and more profits be made, but also I see down the track that if the companies do not do it, it will be forced upon them. In some of the Scandinavian countries legislation has been introduced to enforce industrial democracy and employee participation. Unless managers throughout the country start to adopt these procedures voluntarily-there is enormous benefit for them in adopting the procedures-it is inevitable that this nation will start to have industrial democracy imposed upon it. I draw attention to what I believe is the best model of management-that which sees people as the means which encourages each employee to use his or her capabilities to the utmost and to take an active mental interest not only in his or her particular tasks but also in what the business is doing and where it is going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I commence by thanking the previous speakers. This has been a very worthwhile debate this afternoon and each in his own way has contributed to developing some consensus towards the achievement of industrial democracy in Australia. I believe that the overall feeling is that we need much more rapidly to move down the path towards industrial democracy and employee participation, particularly in management decision-making. It is very encouraging to hear all speakers endorse and generally support that need.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern during this debate has been for the misunderstanding of the primary objective of the Industrial Democracy Bill. Senator Lewis indicated towards the end of his speech the concern all of us have that if managers do not move more rapidly towards employee participation on a voluntary basis it will be forced on them. The misunderstanding about this Bill is that it is a Bill to encourage employee participation, not to enforce or prescribe it as has been suggested. It is simply to provide a framework to give some sort of incentive to hasten the involvement of companies in industrial democracy. I do not think that the suggestion by Senator Durack that this is a magic wand approach to industrial democracy is accurate or fair. It is an advance on what has been, until now, a hope and pray approach to industrial democracy. Regrettably, that has not achieved what all of the speakers obviously would have liked to have seen over the past decade.

My concern with the Australian Labor Party response to this Bill is that it has been referred again to a committee and that it will be allowed to die or to fade out, and maybe one day in the dim distant future something will come about. The Australian Democrats do not believe that that is adequate; we believe it is time for this kind of encouragement to be given to employers. It is for employers- nobody is forcing it on them-to apply for registration under this Bill. It is an encouragement for them to do so and an encouragement for them to get their organisations into gear so that they may receive the tax benefit and in addition , whether they realise it now or not, the benefit of having an industrial democratic organisation.

I believe it is appropriate for me, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, to compliment the encouragement which is obviously being given to the National Labour Consultative Council by the Government. I would certainly like to work in harmony with the NLCC to assist in any way that I am able to get the best possible industrial democracy legislation before this Parliament. I only hope that when it comes before this Parliament Senator Lewis is able to bring his party along with him. I hope that it will follow the same philosophical lines that he has expressed today. I hope that we will get industrial democracy legislation through this Parliament with 100 per cent support; not with parsimonious objection just for the sake of opposing, but with genuine consensus towards industrial democracy. I believe that we will not get there soon enough unless this Parliament is willing to legislate to encourage industrial democracy . Obviously the Bill will not be passed by the Senate today. That is disappointing to the Australian Democrats and to a lot of people who believe that there is a need for such legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under sessional order for the consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will now proceed to further consideration of Government Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 30 (Matters to be taken into consideration with respect to maintenance).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think my amendment is known as the Fraser amendment. It originated from the former Prime Minister. Section 75 of the Family Law Act states, in relation to questions of maintenance:

SPEECH.PARA: The matters to be so taken into account are-
(1) The need to protect the position of a woman who wishes only to continue her role as a wife and mother.

When this clause was inserted in the original Bill in the House of Representatives in 1975 I know it was the intention of the Government and others who desired it to improve the language of that paragraph because apart from anything else it was a sexist provision. That position could well be that of a man who wished to continue in his role as a husband and father. For rather good tactical reasons at that time it did not go back to the House of Representatives . Since then it has been a matter for comment. I think it is a matter that should be cleared up by the Parliament.
The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act referred to this matter at page 79 of its report. Paragraph 5.39 states:

It has been submitted that the provision does not go far enough to protect this class of woman because of the emphasis in s. 72 on 'needs'. It is also apparent that the provision as it now stands in the legislation is not worded effectively . Recent court decisions have limited the application of the provision by placing a narrow interpretation on the word 'role' requiring the applicant to wish to continue the roles of both wife and mother.

Of course, as many of these applications relate to divorces, the person will no longer be a wife, and if a man he will no longer be a husband. Therefore, literally, it has some nonsense in it. I might say that I have not taken up the amendment recommended by the Joint Committee. It was longer and unsatisfactory. Rather I have taken up the amendment recommended by the Family Law Committee of the Family Law Council of Australia in its commentary on the Bill of 1981. On page 20 of its draft report to the Attorney-General of the day it stated:

Presently s. 75 (2) (1) provides that one of the matters to be taken into account in proceedings with respect to maintenance is a need to protect the position of a woman who wishes only to continue her role as a wife and mother.
The Committee seeks that that paragraph be replaced by the following--
The Committee then included the words of my amendment which states:
the need to protect a party who wishes to continue that party's role as a parent .

I think that is an important consideration. It would be a pity if, in the somewhat defective language of the clause as it stands at the moment, the clause does not achieve its purpose. Quite obviously it deals with the parental role and the desires of either party. It may be a case of a wife involved in a divorce who has a lot of money. The husband may desire, after the divorce, to continue to see the child and the mother may have to make financial arrangements to provide a contribution so that the child can see both parents. So because of the inherent defect and sexist nature of the phraseology of this clause, and to make it more effective, I move:
(33) Page 24, after paragraph (a), insert the following new paragraph:
''(aa) by omitting paragraph (2) (1) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(1) the need to protect a party who wishes to continue that party's role as a parent;'; and''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Missen's amendment. I congratulate him for moving it. I think he has made a very adequate case for the amendment without my adding to it. I simply express my support for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot go along with that. I go along with the recommendation made by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. It is too ludicrous to suggest that a woman should supply maintenance while the father continues caring for the child.
—It happens.

—I do not know how often it happens or whether that is the situation to which Senator Missen referred. I support the recommendation made by the Committee. I do not believe that it is very long at all. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to protect the position and reasonable expectations of a party to a marriage who had contributed to the welfare of the family during the marriage and that, but for the dissolution of the marriage, such party would have continued so to contribute.
That is different. There is no way I can support Senator Missen's amendment just because it is a sexist thing. Good heavens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the prevailing spirit of almost consensus, I indicate that Senator Missen's amendment is not opposed. Indeed it is applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Page 24, after paragraph (b), add the following new paragraph:
''(c) by omitting paragraph (2) (o) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(o) any fact of circumstance, including any conduct of the parties to the matrimonial relationship, which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account'.''.

I know that to dare to use the word 'conduct' in the amendment is like waving a red rag to a bull to all the judges of the Family Court of Australia. But this is a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. The Committee used those exact words. Section 75 (2) (o) states:
any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the Court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account.

This would also include the attitudes, conduct and actions of the partners to the marriage. It is not limiting; it is very broad. We on that Committee believed that the original intention of making that very broad insertion was to include anything at all that should be taken into consideration by the judges for the justice of the case. I will quote from the report, which states:
In an early decision of the Family Court it was said in relation to section 75 ( 2) (o) that there were at least three possible interpretations of the provision:

On the one side it may be said that the paragraph must be read in conjunction with the other 13 paragraphs of sub-section (2), all of which are basically of a financial nature . . . so as to be confined to facts and circumstances of economic nature. This interpretation is consistent with the overall basic philosophy introduced into the legislation, namely, to remove considerations of past conduct and fault from the determination of matters under the Act.
That is one interpretation. The report continues:
However, it must be said that there are several areas within the Act where conduct is relevant, such as the provisions relating to custody and the power to issue injunctions contained in sec. 114.
I am sure the Attorney-General would admit that conduct of a violent nature by one of the parents is taken into consideration, particularly in the issuing of injunctions. It continues:

The alternative view is that para (o) should be interpreted in accordance with the ordinary meaning of the words contained in it and that 'any fact or circumstances can and do include a consideration of conduct in a proper case; that is-
this is the second type of interpretation-the actual words used-

that it opens the door to the re-introduction of fault as a relevant consideration in questions of maintenance and the settlement of property. The intermediate view and the one in substance put forward (in the case) was that although conduct generally was not relevant to maintenance, nevertheless the court retained, through para (o) a power to refuse to make a maintenance order where the conduct relied on was 'outrageous' or 'gross' and was such that to make an order would offend even the most basic views as to maintenance.

Accordingly the court adopted the third approach and refused to order that a husband pay maintenance to a wife in circumstances where her needs were established and he had the necessary means, but the custody of the children of the marriage had been awarded to the husband and the wife was pregnant to but had been abandoned by her lover. This view of the law was specifically refuted by the Full Court of the Family Court in a later case, it being held that the ' obvious and gross misconduct' test does not apply in relation to s. 75 (2) (o) and that facts and circumstances within section 75 (2) (o) do not include those relating to the marital history of the parties. . .

The report goes on to explain a few of those. I believe that the original intention-the Committee also believed this-was that section 75 (2) (o) should include any circumstance and any matter. The Committee wound up by stating:

It is the Committee's conclusion that there are circumstances in which it would be warranted for the court to take a wider view of the parties conduct. Accordingly it is recommended that the Family Law Act be amended to permit the court to look at factors other than those of financial conduct in determining whether maintenance should be payable and in relation to distribution of property under section 79.
I believe that the interpretation of that particular paragraph by the Family Court judges is wrong and therefore I would like to make it more specific.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters said that her proposal here would prove to be a red rag to a bull. Might I suggest there is evidence that it has also proved to be a red rag to someone whose even most fervent admirers would be scarcely disposed to so describe him. I refer to my learned and honourable predecessor, Senator Durack. I can do no better in answering Senator Walters than to refer to Senator Durack's remarks made in this place on 13 October 1981 at page 1107 of Hansard, when he was responding to the report of the Joint Select Committee. In relation to this proposed change to section 75 (2) (o) he said as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: It is basic to the philosophy of the Family Law Act that the concept of matrimonial conduct as such-as distinct from conduct relevant to particular issues-is no longer relevant in matrimonial proceedings. Implementation of this recommendation would amount to a pointed reintroduction of the examination of matrimonial conduct at large, and would undoubtedly be seen as an invitation in maintenance proceedings to bring up all alleged misconduct of the applicant however long ago and however irrelevant to the issues of maintenance. Any amendment having that result would to a substantial extent reopen the flood- gates to recrimination and counter-recrimination. This would lead to more protracted and costly proceedings, and to a consequent greater strain on limited Court and legal aid resources. It would also reintroduce the rejected notion that maintenance-or the withholding of it-might be used to punish the party ' guilty' of misconduct.

As far as conduct affecting the issue of maintenance is concerned, recent court decisions have clearly established that the conduct of one of the parties to maintenance proceedings that affected the economic circumstances of the other party can, in fact, be taken into account under the present provision. I believe that this is the limit of the extent to which conduct should be relevant.
I endorse every word of that reaction to this amendment and suggest that the Committee now behaves accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Here we have a very strange thing. We have the Attorney-General on the one hand urging us to support his amendments because by and large they are based on the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, and on the other hand he is contradicting the proposal put so lucidly by Senator Walters and using, as his basis, statements made in this chamber by the former Attorney-General. Of course that is from the same stable. It is the advice received from the Attorney-General's Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which I am moving is different now from the one that I originally circulated. It relates to the position in regard to property settlements and dealing with property. I refer to the amendment shown in the printed paper as No. (35). I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (35) Page 27, after proposed sub-section 79 (8), insert the following sub- section:

'' '(9) The Family Court, or a Family Court of a State, shall not make an order under this section in proceedings with respect to the property of the parties to a marriage or either of them (other than an order until further order or an order made with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings) unless-

(a) the parties to the proceedings have attended a conference in relation to the matter to which the proceedings relate with a Registrar or Deputy Registrar of the Family Court, or a Registrar or Deputy Registrar of the Family Court of that State, as the case may be;

(b) the court is satisfied that, having regard to the need to make an order urgently, or to any other special circumstance, it is appropriate to make the order notwithstanding that the parties to the proceedings have not attended a conference as mentioned in paragraph (a); or
(c) the court is satisfied that it is not practicable to require the parties to the proceedings to attend a conference as mentioned in paragraph (a).'.''.

The amendment was redrafted after consultation with the advisers of the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans). It is desired-this is a matter which the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act had very much in mind-to ensure that parties as far as possible attend conferences where there are problems in regard to property. It is intended that the Court should not in such a case make an order unless the parties have attended such a conference with a court counsellor , welfare officer, registrar, and so forth-unless there are reasons why that is not capable of being done. It was pointed out to me that, as originally drafted, my amendment overlooked the fact that the Family Court and State Family Courts have the facilities of counsellors which, of course, magistrates courts and district courts often do not have. Therefore it was imposing too great a burden to require any court to be able to provide this service. It was also pointed out that there may be circumstances in which property settlement is to be achieved and the court is satisfied that attendance at such a conference is not necessary . Again, it may be not practicable for people to attend if they are a long distance away and there is in reality no dispute then to be resolved and the procedure is not likely to be successful. The redraft, for which I am indebted to the advisers of the Attorney-General, is one that I believe covers the situation. It could have the effect that we would no longer have a situation in which many cases go on for long periods and property becomes very much a matter of dispute when, instead, the parties might, by early discussion or conference, have reached arrangements which would have been useful.

In paragraph 7.52 of the second annual report of the Joint Committee there is reference to this and a reference to the Family Law Council's comments. In commenting on delays being experienced and the reasons for them, the Committee said:

In the light of this situation and in view of restraint imposed in regard to the growth of the Court, attention needs to be given to ways of reducing the number of cases which come on to a fully contested hearing. The view of the Court administration is that there are two successful means which can be employed:
conciliation conferences with Court counsellors under s. 62 (1) in cases concerning children;
But we are concerned with the second part here, which states:

Conferences with a registrar or deputy registrar under reg. 96 concerning particularly property and maintenance matters. These methods have proved successful in reaching settlements or at least in narrowing considerably the issues between the parties.

The report goes on to applaud the success rate, in some registries up to 75 per cent, where such conferences have been held. It was the view, therefore, of the Joint Committee that it was desirable to ensure that these conferences did take place at an early stage. It was with this in mind that redrafted amendment No. ( 35) is moved by me.

''(2) Where-

section 87 of the Family Law Act 1975 as amended and in force after that commencement applies to and in relation to that maintenance agreement as if it had been approved under that section as so in force.
''(3) Where-

(a) a maintenance agreement had, before the commencement of this section, been approved under section 87 of the Family Law Act 1975 as in force, or as amended and in force, at any time before that commencement; and
(b) the approval of the maintenance agreement had been revoked before that commencement,
section 87 of the Principal Act continues to apply to and in relation to that maintenance agreement as if sub-section (1) of this section had not been enacted .''.

This amendment substantially rewrites the section 87 maintenance agreements provisions of the Act. Section 87 permits the parties to a marriage to enter into an agreement relating to financial affairs; the terms of which agreement are to be in substitution for the parties' rights to apply for property settlement or maintenance orders under the Family Law Act. To be of any effect such an agreement has to be approved by the Family Court. The Court can subsequently revoke its approval but only in very limited circumstances. The amendment that is now being moved will repeal the existing section 87 and insert a new one. The new one will contain most of the provisions of the existing one and certainly will maintian the basic scheme or purpose of the section as I have just outlined it.

However, the new section will differ from the existing section 87 in two important respects, which I now spell out. First, it will permit the Court's approval of the agreement to be revoked in a wider range of circumstances than exist at present and, secondly, it will confer on the Family Court exclusive jurisdiction to enforce such agreements and to entertain all legal and equitable actions that can be brought under the general law of contract in respect to them . The amendments, conferring exclusive jurisdiction on the Family Court to entertain general contractual actions in relation to section 87 maintenance agreements, are necessary to overcome the undersirable practice that has developed in certain States of parties resorting to the Supreme Court to enforce or to otherwise obtain relief in respect of an agreement that has force and effect only because the Family Court originally approved it.

The amendments to extend the grounds on which the approval of a section 87 agreement can be revoked are as follows: They are to include circumstances where the agreement is void, voidable or unenforceable, or where it has become impracticable for the agreement to be carried out. That is in addition to the present limited grounds of fraud on the Court, fraud or undue influence on a party or agreement of both parties to the revocation. These amendments to extend the grounds in this way are necessary both on account of the new powers of the Family Court to entertain the usual actions in law or equity in respect of contracts and also to achieve some consistency with the wider ground which the Bill in clause 32 proposes should be available for the variation of property settlement orders. I inform the Committee that this amendment has been the subject of quite exhaustive examination by a sub-committee of the Family Law Council and by the Family Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia. Although the amendment is technical in character, as will be evident from the bird's eye view I have just endeavoured to give, it is potentially very important in practice. I commend the amendment to the Senate.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

—What percentage?

—It is roughly 60 per cent. I think the figures indicate that there were 44,088 divorces in 1982, 38.4 per cent of which did not involve children. So 27,158 of the 44,000-plus did involve children. The concerns that have been expressed about this clause have largely turned around to how the Court can be satisfied, as it is supposed to be satisfied, that the welfare of the children has been taken into account, simply on the basis of affidavit material supplied by the parties. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am taking these amendments on the run as I was not consulted in any way about them. I saw the amendments only five or 10 minutes ago. Still, this is one of the things one expects to happen in this place and one has to make the best of it. I was one who supported the original proposal which the Attorney-General put into the Family Law Amendment Bill and which the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act recommended. I still think that is the best proposal. Certainly, I am relieved to see that we are not faced with the fact of welfare officer reports which, with respect to Senator Chipp, would have been a shocking waste of money when there are many more areas of family law with greater priorities for expenditure. Therefore that was not a solution. Certainly these proposals are better than that possibility if we are going to give way in part on this clause.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be interested to know-I am not going to oppose the proposals which the Attorney-General has moved-what consultation there has been on these amendments. The Attorney-General has given us the figures. Something like 27,000 divorces will not be eligible for consideration in this way. I would be interested to know what the costs involved would be. I note what the Attorney said about the fact that there would be requisitions and therefore there may be fewer cases.

I presume this matter has been discussed with judges of the Family Court who are experienced in this matter. I presume the proposals have not been taken entirely on the run by the Attorney-General. Some good, sound, experienced people performing in this area have advised that this is a sensible solution. I would be interested to know to what extent advice has been taken on this or whether it has been done on the run. In either case, it is probably a matter which will have to go ahead now since a settlement has been made with various unnamed parties in this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to press the debate?
—Is there to be a reply to my remarks, Attorney-General?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to reply to Senator Missen. Of course there has been consultation. I have engaged in non- stop consultation with the judiciary on the legislation as a whole and on this clause in particular since I have been in office and have had many viewpoints expressed to me. In the particular context of the situation that arose with relation to this clause in the last 24 hours, I have had consultations with His Honour, Mr Justice Fogarty, who is now Chairman of the Family Law Council, and I proceed against the background of those consultations. But I hasten to add, for Senator Missen's benefit-I regret that I did not consult him, but I was able to add up the likely result on the basis of those I did consult-that I simply do not believe that the proposal in its original form would have been carried in this place. Rather than go through a long and protracted debate and produce a result which would have been in the negative, it seemed to me that discretion once again was the better part of valour.

SPEECH.PARA: In many respects the result arrived at is rational because it accommodates a number of the problems that were articulated by Senator Chipp in his Press release of a few days ago. The amendments meet a number of the problems of a practical kind that have been raised by registrars and others within the Family Court system as to the real utility from an administrative point of view, of a full scale divorce on the paper system because of the point about requisitions and so on. They will meet at least some of the arguments in principle about which we will no doubt now hear from Senator Walters and others. Sometimes, Senator Missen, one just has to put away one's sword, stop tilting at windmills and accept some of the awful realities around us in the quixotic world we inhabit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a somewhat awkward position. Whilst I acknowledge that the amendments that have been mooted by the Attorney-General and which were, as I understand it, founded on Senator Chipp's suggestions, do improve the clause before us, I happen to be opposed to the thing but--
—Would you agree that you were against the whole thing?
—Yes, that is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obviously in a difficult position because the vote is being pushed now. Therefore, I will have to oppose the amendments.
—You can still vote against the whole section. You can support this and vote against the section.

—No, I am not likely to support those amendments. I am voting against them because they interfere with the whole of the section. I find that the amendments help tremendously in that 27,000 divorces will not be allowed to be dealt with in this way, as you have just indicated. But that is not good enough. Therefore, it makes the voting on this very difficult. That is why I particularly asked the Attorney if he would delay the vote until after I had put my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (42) Page 35, proposed section 98A, lines 3 to 25, leave out the proposed section, insert the following new section:

'98A. At the date fixed for the hearing of proceedings for dissolution of marriage, both parties to the marriage shall attend the court, unless the court, in its discretion, determines that the attendance of either or both parties is not practical.'.

The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) told us that divorces involving children-he said the number in this cateogry last year was 27,000-would be excluded from the 'divorce by post' provisions of the legislation. Among other things he said that he believed that it was in fact easier for a judge to assess the situation of children if the parties appeared before him. That, I believe, underlines the whole case that I am about to put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if there are no children.

—Even if there are no children. As the Attorney-General has just indicated, if the parties are before the Court it is very much easier for the judge to assess the real reason for the breakdown of marriage. He will not have to consider something that has been written on a form and sent to him perhaps by a deeply depressed wife who has been deserted for 12 months. As I say, these things are often done in a fit of deep depression. I believe that clause 47 is a destructive piece of legislation. Section 43 of the Family Law Act, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life . . .

If we believe, as I am sure that everyone in the chamber must, that such a provision is in the best interests of the Australian community, if we believe that the family unit is the stable influence in the Australian community, we cannot possibly allow 17,000 people, as was the case last year, let their partners fill in a form. A person need not necessarily alert the partner that he is filling out a form. At some later date a person could get a letter back saying: 'Dear Mrs So and So, you were divorced on such and such a day'. There need be no real acknowledgement that the divorce is proceeding. Does anyone really believe that the divorce by post part of the legislation upholds the view expressed in section 43 of the Family Law Act that the Family Court shall have regard to the protection of marriage and the institution of marriage? How can a judge assess the situation by looking at a bit of paper?

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens now.
—It does not occur at the moment.
—Do you know how many people have to be there before the Court and who they are?

—The Attorney acknowledged a little while ago that I was on the review committee. The Attorney is 100 per cent wrong to ask that stupid question of me. I am quite well aware that only one person has to appear before the Court in an undefended case and that does not even have to be the partner. It can be the partner's legal representative.
—Do you know how many cases are dealt with in that way?

—I am quite well aware of that. I have been ashamed when I have been in the Court and seen divorces go through in one and a half minutes or perhaps even less. I am not suggesting that my amendment seeks a return to the status quo. I ask the Attorney-General not to keep quoting the status quo at me because I am not asking for a return to that. I am suggesting that both partners be at the hearing for dissolution of marriage unless the judge determines that it is not practicable for that to happen.
—Do you know how much agony that can cause in certain cases?
—I do know that I have attended those--
—You are going to force people into an unpleasant situation if they don't want to be.

—That is a ridiculous thing to say. If Senator Chipp believes that should be the case, why make people do anything? The Attorney has just said that he believes a judge could not really assess a case from a form filled out by a distraught wife. How can a judge assess from what is on the form that that is a true indication of the breakdown of marriage? He has not seen the woman; he has not seen the woman's attorney; he has not seen anyone. The woman has filled in a form to the effect that she is seeking a divorce because she and her husband have been separated for 12 months or more. As I said a little earlier, she may be depressed because she is not able to cope with the fact that her partner has not contacted her for over 12 months and she does not know where he is. She is going through this trauma. The judge does not have any indication from the husband whether perhaps there is any chance of reconciliation. There is no indication by the woman that if the husband appeared there could be a chance of reconciliation. The woman just writes on the form that she wants a divorce. She states that she and her husband have agreed to certain maintenance arrangements-I will not mention anything about children at the moment-and that things have been tidied up generally. However, she states that she and her husband have agreed to the divorce. Many women are completely disadvantaged by the fact that they do not know the legal aspects of divorce. They do not have a clue how much their partner is even earning. Therefore, they do not have any idea of what their entitlement might be to maintenance or the division of property. The woman is presented with a form to fill in which will give her a divorce. Sometimes she is not quite sure when. She will get a notice later which will tell her when.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said a few moments ago, the Attorney said that partners must appear before the Court if children are involved. He has underlined the fact that the judge cannot assess properly from a form whether children are being looked after in a correct fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.
—He said it is easier for a judge to assess the situation when the parties appear before him.
—It gives the opportunity to ask questions.
—It gives the judge an opportunity to ask questions.
—If he needs to, which is highly unlikely in most cases.

—That is right, and if the partners of the marriage are before him, again it gives him the opportunity to assess whether the marriage has broken down. It gives him the opportunity to ask questions and to establish whether the marriage has broken down. We have heard during this debate that the number of marriages each year is rising. Since 1975, when the legislation was first introduced, the figures have first of all stabilised and then risen until, as I said previously in this debate, we now have a situation in which there is one divorce for every two and a half marriages in Australia every year. Those are horrendous figures. If we say to the coming generation: 'All you have got to do to get divorced is to fill in a form and post it; nothing else has to be done -'
—That is not true.

—It is true. Once a couple has been separated for 12 months, if they are in agreement all they will have to do to obtain a divorce is fill in a form. As Senator Chipp said, the people concerned will not have to go through any trauma. The whole procedure will be terribly easy; no trauma at all will be involved. If we say that to coming generations, what will they be doing in 10 years' time? As I have said, we already have one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages and 50 per cent of second marriages fail. Those figures are appalling. If we are to say to coming generations, to the children of honourable senators and to my grandchildren, that all they have to do is walk out of a marriage for 12 months, then fill in a form in order to obtain a divorce, they will not even give marriage serious consideration. Marriage will be no better than a de facto relationship, out of which a person can walk at any time. They will have no responsibility whatsoever to their spouse. I think we have reached the situation where we have to say: 'What does marriage in Australia mean today'? If we examine the figures we can see that it does not mean much.
