DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Uranium Mining-Alcohol Abuse-Excise on Grape Spirit

PROCTEXT.PARA: Uranium Mining-Alcohol Abuse-Excise on Grape Spirit

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I should like to speak briefly about uranium and the Government's continued agonising over it. I note the extent of the Government's dilemma with the left wing of the Australian Labor Party in its continued confrontation with the Government. I believe this was amply demonstrated yesterday by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, when I asked him why the Government should allow the development of Roxby Downs on the basis of the other minerals present and not allow the development of Jabiluka in the Northern Territory which has large deposits of gold. His answer was that we can mine uranium at Roxby Downs in South Australia because it has 60 per cent of other minerals. We cannot mine uranium at Jabiluka as it has only 10 per cent of other minerals. The 60 per cent of other minerals at Roxby Downs include copper, which has a depressed market. The 10 per cent of other minerals at Jabiluka is gold, which is in very strong demand. How strange it is to have as the main determinant of whether we mine uranium at a site the quantities of other minerals present. What would happen if we had, say, 35 per cent of other minerals at a site? Could we then mine uranium? What about the other important issues such as the jobs that uranium development will create, the economic development and, very importantly to me and to the people of the outback in the north, northern development, and Australia's reputation? Are these matters not important to the Government? The Government is in considerable confusion in relation to this matter and I believe that that confusion is causing immense damage. In the community, of course, there is also considerable confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the damage which is being done to the present and future markets for uranium. I should like to talk briefly about two aspects of the uranium debate as they affect the Northern Territory. Those are the relationship to the Aboriginal community and world demand. In regard to the Aboriginal community-I speak broadly and mainly of the traditional owners and the Northern Land Council in the Northern Territory in the Kakadu-Jabiru area-I mention briefly an incident involving the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding. It concerns a sacred message stick given by the traditional owners to the Minister. That message stick was given to the Minister to be presented to the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). It was quite an unusual message stick, actually. Only on very few occasions have the Aboriginal people used this method of communication between themselves and the Government. They had asked the Australian Government when it would recognise the signing of the Koongarra agreement in principle. They were asking when they would get a reply, as they waited several weeks. It was decided that the message stick would be sent. It was carved by the leading traditional owners, the old men of the area, and it was presented to the Minister by Mr Blitner, the Chairman of the Northern Land Council. As I said, the Council had complained about the delay in receiving an answer. The traditional owners wanted Mr Holding to take this message stick to Mr Hawke. There is ample evidence to show that this message stick was presented with due ceremony but, in a television media report in Darwin, Mr Holding said: 'I thought it looked like a wooden clothes peg'. He did nothing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes. That angered and distressed the Aboriginal people. I believe that it was a callous and very insensitive remark. I have suggested before that the Minister should apologise to the Aboriginal people. Furthermore, I believe that the non-recognition of the ceremonial message stick and the fact that the Aboriginal people have not received the courtesy of a reply, with all the ramifications of the various moves that have taken place at this particular time, was a means of endeavouring to persuade or pressurise the Aboriginal people not to support uranium mining as they have done in such a strong manner in the last year. I can understand why this would be the case, because that support must be an embarrassment to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the demand for uranium. The world demand for yellowcake is on the increase, especially from politically stable countries. I refer the Senate to an article which appeared in the Australian of 31 May 1983 under the heading ' Looming US uranium shortage spells good news for local miners'. Referring to consumption of uranium by the United States, the article states:
Consumption is rising steadily and will reach 13,793 tonnes next year, but in the meantime, production is continuing to fall and will drop to only 5,445 tonnes next year.

But the US has stockpiles which will satisfy domestic production until 1988, when inventories will amount to two years' supply and the country is expected to become a major net importer at that point.
This is good news for Australia's potential producers, assuming they are allowed to produce and a further optimistic development is taking place.
The article continues:
Major customers of the giant Rossing uranium mine in Namibia, which is 46.5 per cent owned by the Rio Tinto-Zinc group of the UK, are seeking to diversify major contracts due soon for renewal.
The article goes on to say:

Namibia's political future is troubled, which is one reason why major customers wish to diversify their sources of supply. The other is that Britain and Japan feel they are too dependent on one mine as a source of supply.

The article continues in that vein which indicates, of course, that the demand for uranium will pick up, not in the long term but, I would say, in the short term. Australia is in a very strong situation because it is looked upon as a stable country. This cannot be said of other countries which produce uranium, particularly in Africa. The demand for uranium in Europe is increasing. By 1985 France will have 55 per cent of its electricity supplied from nuclear reactors. America will be a net importer of uranium by 1988. Throughout the world there are some 294 nuclear power reactors in operation, with 215 more under construction. I believe that we have an obligation to meet this demand and create jobs, wealth and development. Uranium will bring energy to Third World countries.

I come from the Northern Territory as one of its Federal representatives. I see an enormous challenge for the north and I believe that it has tremendous potential for development. Over the years, of course, one of Australia's aims has been to develop and bring security to the north. When one looks at the tremendous potential of this development, the number of jobs that it will create , the wealth that it will bring with the development of roads and transport, one realises its immense importance to Australia.

Also, the latest oil find, that of Jabiru in the Timor Sea, has an enormous potential for Australia's oil supplies. It is tremendous to look into the future and envisage its use for Australia's development. Hand in hand with that we have production of uranium for not only Australia but also the world. What tremendous importance the north could have. It would no longer be the empty north or the poor north. It would be a north of activity, increasing population and wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the Senate the cost to the Australian community of the deleterious effects of alcohol consumption. Honourable senators will understand that to cost something of this nature is a difficult exercise because of the many variable factors that are involved. For example, it would involve designating the proportion of road accident victims whose plight is a result of alcohol consumption or the proportion of hospital admissions resulting from alcohol induced illnesses. Nevertheless, a definitive survey has been carried out by Dr Drew of the Commonwealth Department of Health. His findings give a good indication of the extent of the problem. Dr Drew calculated that 10 per cent of general hospital costs and 15 per cent of psychiatric hospital costs, amounting to $325.6m in 1979-80, could be attributed to alcohol. In addition, outpatient and non- hospital based medical practice costs took the total cost for health services to nearly $950m in the 1979-80 period. If we look at other areas where alcohol has a significant impact, we see that these costs are further compounded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Office of Road Safety has calculated that in the calendar year 1978-these are the latest figures available to me-the cost to the community of deaths in road accidents was $582m. The cost of road injuries was $437m and of damage to property was a further $752m. Using as a guideline the fact that 50 per cent of fatalities, 20 per cent of injuries and 5 per cent of property damage arises from alcohol related road accidents, the cost in 1978 of alcohol related road accidents was $407m. Allowing for inflation, the figure for the financial year 1979-80 therefore becomes of the order of $450m.

According to an unpublished paper of the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, alcoholism cost industry $2,415 per employee in 1974-75. That figure is the most recent I have been able to discover. It does not begin to take into account other costs of alcohol use to industry, such as accidents related to occasional alcohol use. However, if the 1974-75 figure is adjusted for inflation, assuming no increase or decrease in the problem, the cost to industry purely from alcoholism in 1979-80 was of the order of $890m. When other costs are included, such as a portion of the cost of law enforcement, alcohol related welfare costs and Government-funded programs aimed at abuse of alcohol, the final cost to the community for 1979-80 was about $2,250m. While, admittedly , not all that figure represents a debit in the Budget, to give some idea of the magnitude of the problem, $2,250m represents about 7 per cent of total Budget outlays in that year. If one applies an implicit price deflater to the figure, the cost in the 1982-83 financial year would have been about $3,060m.

The government response to this problem-I add at this point that I refer not to this Government or to the previous Government but to all past governments-has been disappointing to say the least. Contributions to the States for community health programs, only some of which find their way into alcohol and drug abuse programs, have been paltry. In 1980-81, the last year for which this item appeared separately in the Budget papers, the amount granted to the States to be disbursed as they saw fit, was a mere $55m. In that same year revenue from customs and excise on beer and spirits exceeded $900m while State and local governments collected a further $130m in liquor taxes. In its own area of responsibility, the Commonwealth Government has funded the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence and its national alcoholism and drug dependence industry programs. These are valuable programs. The national alcoholism and drug dependence industry program covers 74 private industries and 50 public service organisations, representing about 5 per cent of the Australian workforce. It has been estimated that some 80 per cent of all employees detected as suffering from alcohol or drug abuse are returned to adequate work performance. Yet in the 1982 Budget National Alcohol and Drug Dependence Industry Program was allocated a mere half a million dollars and the secretariat of the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence a further $360, 000. In 1982-83 the national drug education program, which includes alcohol and its effects, was allocated a further $1.8m to support State and Northern Territory programs.

This is a miserable response to a major crisis and a major drain on the finances of the community. It in no way comes close to matching the cost which industry and the community at large has to bear, or the very significant revenues which governments receive from alcohol consumption in this country. I am aware that we have before the Senate at present a Bill sponsored by the Australian Democrats entitled the Liquor Advertising Tax Assessment Bill, which would impose a tax at a rate to be determined on expenditure incurred by companies advertising liquor products. While I am sympathetic with the principle underlying this piece of legislation, namely, the need for a more significant government response to the problem of alcohol abuse in Australia, I do not believe this is the proper way to go about tackling the issue.

Alcohol products are already heavily taxed. I am not in favour of further increasing the level of taxation to the point where the Government appears to be making decisions about the life style Australians should be leading by making alcohol unaffordable to the average person. Used sensibly and moderately, alcohol should not represent a danger to the community and it should not be the place of governments to tax moderate consumption out of existence. Although I do not for a moment suggest that this demonstrates moderate consumption, in 1980-81 expenditure on alcohol products was $4,123m. In terms of employment and in terms of the revenue which the industry contributes to governments, the liquor industry already plays a very important part and should not be placed in jeopardy by over-zealous use of the taxing powers of governments. However, I contend that because governments, especially the Federal Government, already receive significant revenues from this industry, there is a strong case for a redirection of resources towards further programs to curb alcohol abuse. I urge the Government to consider this matter in that light and to increase funding out of existing revenue to organisations and programs designed to combat the deleterious effects of alcohol. In this way the Government not only has an opportunity to make a more meaningful contribution to solving this problem but also can assist in reducing losses of productivity in industry, losses and deaths in road accidents and other costs on the community. Given the costs which I have already outlined, I believe the matter now requires the urgent attention of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff, in his contribution to the adjournment debate tonight, made a number of criticisms of the Government's uranium policy, and in particular of the policy as he considers it affects the Northern Territory. I will not attempt to respond to those criticisms this evening. I am sure my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, will do so at an appropriate time. But I point out that the question of what Australia should do with its uranium resources is a very complex one. Indeed, it is a very controversial one in the community and one to which the Government is giving a great deal of attention and care so that we may resolve it properly, taking into account all of our responsibilities, including our responsibility to ensure the safety of future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in the course of his remarks Senator Kilgariff suggested that my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) had made a derogatory response to the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Gerry Blitner, when Mr Blitner presented Mr Holding with a message stick. I take this opportunity to correct the impression which Senator Kilgariff's comments may have made on honourable senators this evening. I have before me an explanation of the incident by my colleague Mr Holding and I will read it into the Senate record. Mr Holding said that he was given the message stick by the Chairman of the NLC, Mr Blitner, while visiting Galiwinku in the Northern Territory on 20 July. Mr Holding said it was his understanding at the time that the message stick was for him as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and as a representative of the Australian Government. Mr Holding refers to a Press release issued at the time by the Northern Land Council which explained the significance of the message stick and which states:

On July 13 1983 the traditional owners of the Koongarra mine site made a traditional message stick to be delivered to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for the Australian Government and the people of Australia.
Mr Holding continued:
Nevertheless, the message stick has now been passed to the Prime Minister (on 22 August). with the necessary explanation as to its meaning.
Later he said:

It was reported that I failed to respond to the Chairman of the NLC after having received the message stick and the information about the Aboriginal's attitude at Koongarra. In fact, I wrote to Mr Blitner on 4 August, thanking him for the information given to me and assuring him that the views put by the Aboriginals concerned would be considered. I also asked him to convey my thanks to the traditional owners. I do not know whether Mr Blitner did convey my thanks as requested.
Mr Holding continued:

It is asserted by our political opponents what I said in relation to the message stick was 'I thought it was a clothes peg'. I did not say that. What I said was that 'it looked like a clothes peg'. That was said in the context of providing a description of the message stick to a non-Aboriginal television audience. My words have been irresponsibly misrepresented by our political opponents.
Clearly, Mr Holding's words also have been irresponsibly misrepresented in the Senate to- night. I have taken this opportunity to set the record straight.

With regard to the matters raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, I believe Senator Crichton-Browne does the Senate a service by drawing our attention yet again to the enormous financial cost-of course, there is also the great social cost-of alcohol abuse in our community. No doubt all honourable senators are aware of this cost, but still it is important that we be reminded of the extent of the cost and the extent of the problem in the community. Senator Crichton-Browne drew attention to the various Commonwealth initiatives which have been taken by successive governments to try to set up some machinery for assisting people who have become alcohol abusers. He acknowledged that their efforts have had some effect although, on behalf of the Government, I agree with Senator Crichton- Browne that these efforts could be increased because the extent of the problem is very great. I will make sure that my colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, is made aware of the concerns Senator Crichton-Browne raised this evening. I am pleased to note that there will be a bipartisan approach to the steps we can take, as members of the Senate and as members of this Parliament, to assist the community in overcoming these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for having missed my earlier call to speak in the adjournment debate. I do not wish to hold up the Senate for long, but I have one matter to bring to the attention of the Senate. I refer to the wine tax, about which I have spoken before, that is being applied by the Government in the latest Budget. I draw the Senate's attention to a letter I received the other day from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, dated 7 September 1983 wherein he drew my attention to the fact that it was not 'very helpful for you to designate the grape spirit excise as a wine tax '. This is an important matter and shows the depth of misunderstanding by this Government of the nature of the wine industry for the Minister to put his signature under a letter of that kind. As I have pointed out in my earlier remarks, there is not merely one aspect of the wine industry. The spirit side and the table wine side of the industry are integrated; they are totally interlocked. The whole concept of spirit production relates to the maintenance of stability for the ordinary grape grower, particularly in South Australia. The Government does not appreciate that. It looks as though I will have to stand here many times to make that point to the Government until it realises exactly what the nature of the industry is and how it is destroying the industry by this kind of approach.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to press that matter much further because of the time. There is just one other aspect of the problem on which I wish to comment. It was drawn to my attention today by an article that appeared in last night's Daily News in Perth which quoted the adventure of one Mr Gavin Troy, who is a former Labor member for the State seat of Mundaring in Western Australia. Apparently Mr Troy made a special trip to Canberra in the last few days to see the Minister for Primary Industry in connection with this problem of wine excise. I point that out because it shows that it is not only South Australians who are interested in this matter; it is a very widespread problem within the wine industry and it appears to be a bipartisan concern. Upon Mr Troy's return to Perth he apparently reported certain things to the Daily News. The newspaper states:
A bureaucratic blunder is responsible for the reintroduced excise on fortified wine, it was claimed today.
Former Mundaring MLA Mr Gavin Troy made the claim after a meeting with the Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, in Canberra today.
Mr Troy, who lost his seat in a Court of Disputed Returns decision last week, also met with the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin.
Mr Troy today said he was 'quietly confident' that the excise would be amended later this month.
He said it was clear the Canberra bureaucracy did not know what it was doing when it advised the Government on the grape spirit excise.

I think that speaks for itself. I find it rather surprising that, after raising this matter by way of questions and in the adjournment debate on at least three or four occasions in the last few days, we can get no answer from the Government as to its reasons for introducing this tax. Yet a person who is a former Labor member of Parliament in the State House in Western Australia can get a private audience with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and come away with a story such as that and have it quoted in the Press. I find it amazing that this Government has so little concern for the interests of South Australians in particular when at least two honourable senators in this House and one honourable member in the House of Representatives have constantly raised this issue since the Budget and can get no response whatsoever from the Government. On one occasion the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans) made it clear that this was a terribly tedious matter and that he just wanted to get out of the chamber; he did not want to answer us at all. I find that a disgusting way to treat the Opposition. I hope the Government will have a response for us by the time the Senate meets next Tuesday.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.59 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to an article in the May 1983 edition of Australian Penthouse by Dr Geoffrey Smith of Melbourne entitled 'I Spy', which raised questions about the Pine Gap space base and the activities of Australian and United States intelligence organisations in this country, if so:

(a) Was there a 'John Simmons' in the Federal Attorney-General's office in Canberra last year who rang Dr Smith and quizzed him about an article he had written for Australian Penthouse entitled 'The Pine Gap Puzzle', claiming he had breached the provisions of a D notice; and if so, what was the position of this person employed by the Attorney-General's office last year and who instructed him to ring Dr Smith.
(b) Has the Australian Government had official advice as to the operations in Australia of Task Force 157.
(c) Was Task Force 157 set up by United States intelligence agencies to undermine the Australian Government and has it operated as claimed by Dr Smith; and
(d) Is there any substance in the reported claim that representatives from United States intelligence organisations in Australia questioned and threatened Dr Smith.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My attention has been drawn to the article in question.

(a) There was no person of the name of John Simmons employed in the Federal Attorney-General's Office in Canberra or elsewhere last year. No D notice, all of which are on the public record, covers any of the matters in the article entitled 'The Pine Gap Puzzle'.
(b) and (c) I have no knowledge of these matters.
(d) If threats were made to Dr Smith he should make a formal complaint to the Police.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current arrangements for the transmission of programs by Radio Australia to Africa and southern Africa in particular.

(2) Has Radio Australia, in view of Australia's internationally acknowledged agricultural expertise, examined the possiblity of transmitting material for countries like Zimbabwe which emphasise land use and farming techniques; if so, with what result and if not, why not and will the Minister for Communications ask Radio Australia to pursue an examination of such possible programs especially in the light of the drought experienced in both continents.
(3) In what countries and in what cities does the ABC: (a) have permanent employees stationed as broadcasting representatives or program producers; and (b ) pay for such services from non-employees.
(4) What are the names of such persons in each category in (3) and for how long will each of the current arrangements apply.
(5) What are the current arrangements in Zimbabwe and under what circumstances and in terms of what time frame would the ABC post an officer in Harare, Zimbabwe.
(6) Would the posting of such an officer significantly improve understanding between Australia and Zimbabwe.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Radio Australia broadcasts to Africa in English from 0400-0500 GMT and from 0600-0630 GMT. Radio Australia broadcasts to Africa in French from 0500-0600.

(2) Africa is identified as belonging to the secondary areas of target importance for Radio Australia. These areas cannot be serviced adequately from Australian-based transmitters. They may require coverage from time to time via shortwave relay stations.

Radio Farm Forum was broadcast until March 1983 when the program was discontinued, as resources available for its production were inadequate and the product considered unsatisfactory. The situation is under review.
(3) (a) The Australian Broadcasting Corporation maintains 12 permanent offices overseas. They are at:
London-Manager for Europe plus 5 'A' based correspondents and 11 locally engaged office staff.
Brussels-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative) plus one locally engaged office staff.
New York-Manager for North America plus 4 'A' based correspondents and 5 locally engaged office staff.
Washington-One 'A' based correspondent and one locally engaged staff.
Singapore-Manager for Asia plus one 'A' based correspondent and 11 locally engaged office staff.
Jakarta-Six locally engaged staff on contract dealing with Radio Australia correspondence, booklets, etc.
New Delhi-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative).
Tokyo-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative) and one locally engaged office staff.
Bangkok-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative)
Peking-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative)
Port Moresby-One 'A' based correspondent (Representative)
Kuala Lumpur-One locally engaged journalist employed full time.

(b) Contributions are accepted from freelance journalists throughout the world. Many are regular contributors to the news and public affairs programs, while others are assigned on an ad hoc basis as news developments warrant their use.

Staff in London, Brussels, New York, Washington, Singapore, Tokyo and Bangkok are appointed for an initial three year period. Those in New Delhi, Peking and Port Moresby for an initial two year period.
(5) In Zimbabwe, as in other parts of Africa, the ABC:
(a) uses accredited free-lance journalists;
(b) ABC staff, including film crews, principally from the London Office and Australia on special assignment; and
(c) despatches from other broadcasting organisations and from international News Services to which the ABC subscribes.

ABC News is keen to develop its network of staff correspondents overseas and the African continent is high on the priority list in this regard. However, it is a costly exercise and it is unlikely that a posting to Africa will take place in the current financial year.

The choice of a location for a correspondent in Africa will depend on numerous factors additional to the news-worthiness of the area. These factors include the availability of facilities and the geographical convenience of the location in terms of the need to move rapidly to other parts of the continent.
(6) It is not possible to predict what the effect of such a posting would be; however, the decision would be made in the light of possible reactions from other countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Dr Kim Dae Jung, the former South Korean Opposition Leader, have a South Korean passport which the South Korean Government has designated as only being valid for entry into and exit from South Korea and the United States.
(2) Is this designation in breach of international law or accepted international arrangements; if so, in what way.
(3) Has Dr Kim lived in exile in Alexandria, Virginia in the United States since December 1982.

(4) Will the Australian Government give approval for Dr Kim to enter Australia on a normal visitor's visa for a brief period to undertake speaking engagements whatever the status of his South Korean travel documents; if not, why not.

(5) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs meet with Dr Kim, if approval for such a visit is given and if a mutually convenient time can be arranged, so that the Minister and the Government will have the benefit of his knowledge and experience in relation to political developments in South Korea.
(6) What, if any, would be the limitations placed on his entry and exit to and from Australia and what other limitations, if any, would be placed on him.
(7) Was Dr Kim in gaol or detention for most of the period between 1973 and 1982 on charges relating to his non-violent opposition to recent South Korean Governments.

(8) Did Dr Kim say on 10 June 1983, in a prepared and widely circulated speech to the Annual General Meeting of the American Section of Amnesty International, at Emory University in the United States of America:

In 1973, the KCIA (Korean Central Intelligence Agency) kidnapped me from a hotel room (Grand Palace Hotel) in Tokyo (while en route to a speaking engagement at Harvard University concerning opposition to Park Chung Hee's Government). Its agents (KCIA) first tried to kill me in the room, but were interrupted. Then they attempted to throw me overboard into the ocean only to be foiled by active United States intervention. Finally, in 1980, General Chun Doo Hwan sentenced me to death on trumped-up charges.
(9) Did Dr Kim secure 46 per cent of the popular vote in the 1971 presidential election in South Korea.

(10) Were there widespread public and newspaper claims alleging vote-rigging by the candidate who became President after the 1971 election, and by his supporters; if so, what were the key elements of the allegations and what view did the Department of Foreign Affairs form about their accuracy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4), (5) and (6) Entry to Australia is a matter within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I am not aware of Mr Kim having expressed a desire to visit Australia. But should he ask to visit Australia, I am sure that the Government would consider his request sympathetically. Should Mr Kim wish to convey views to the Government by any means I would be happy to learn of them.

(7) Mr Kim has been in prison or under house arrest for most of the period 1973 -82. The various charges under ROK law laid against Mr Kim arose from his position and activities as a leading opposition politician. So far as I am aware , Mr Kim has never advocated violence in his opposition to ROK governments.
(8) Yes.
(9) Mr Kim received 45.26 per cent of the valid votes cast in the 1971 election ; or 43.45 of total votes cast (i.e. valid and invalid).

(10) There were allegations by Mr Kim, his New Democratic Party and others of electoral irregularities. At this distance, however, it is difficult to say precisely how widely their views were shared in the ROK. Mr Kim and the New Democratic Party accused the successful Democratic Republican Party of bribing voters, abuse of administrative power and irregularities in the preparation of voters' rolls, balloting and vote counting. At the time, the advice to the Department of Foreign Affairs from our Embassy in Seoul was that while irregularities undoubtedly did occur, these were probably not enough to influence the outcome of the election. It was considered that the outcome was determined more by the advantages of incumbency, which were certainly used to considerable affect by President Park and his party.
